title: Hyundai Oilbank extends US fuel export deal with Sunoco
summary: Hyundai Oilbank has extended its deal with Sunoco LP to export petroleum products to Hawaii through 2023. The South Korean refiner, backed by Saudi Aramco, has already supplied 3.6 million barrels of gasoline and diesel to Hawaii this year and plans to export a similar volume next year. This extension allows Hyundai Oilbank to further diversify its overseas markets beyond Asia, fostering cooperation with global gas station operators.

title: Canadian Natural Resources boosts dividend 13%
summary: Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. reported a profit of $2.8 billion in the third quarter and increased its quarterly dividend by 13 percent to 85 cents per common share. The company saw natural gas production increase by 25 percent and liquids production by 14 percent year-over-year. CEO Tim McKay also addressed decarbonization efforts, stating that spending on carbon capture and storage projects has already begun.

title: Flame Acquisition Corp. (FLME) to Combine with Sable Offshore in $883M Deal
summary: Flame Acquisition Corp. (FLME) has announced a definitive agreement to merge with Sable Offshore in a transaction valued at $883 million. Sable Offshore will acquire the Santa Ynez Unit (SYU) offshore oil field, previously operated by Exxon Mobil (XOM), which has been shut down since a 2015 pipeline rupture. The deal involves a significant debt financing package and a PIPE investment, with the combined entity aiming to restart operations at SYU despite regulatory and political challenges in California.

title: Marathon Petroleum and Phillips 66 cruise past estimates on fuel demand surge
summary: Marathon Petroleum and Phillips 66 reported quarterly profits that exceeded Wall Street estimates, driven by strong fuel demand and robust refining margins. Both companies benefited from high refinery utilization rates and elevated export demand, with Marathon increasing its dividend and authorizing share buybacks. The favorable market conditions are expected to continue into 2023.

title: Cash key for Chevron and Exxon Mobil as Truist raises stock price targets
summary: Truist Securities has raised its price targets for Chevron Corp. and Exxon Mobil Corp. due to their strong cash positions and free cash flow generation. Exxon Mobil generated over $17 billion in free cash flow last quarter, boosting its cash position by more than $11 billion. Both companies' stocks are rallying toward fresh records.

title: Cash key for Chevron and Exxon Mobil as Truist raises stock price targets
summary: Truist Securities has raised its price targets for Chevron Corp. and Exxon Mobil Corp. due to their strong cash positions and recent financial performance. Exxon Mobil, in particular, generated over $17 billion in free cash flow last quarter, boosting its cash position by more than $11 billion. This news comes as both companies' stocks are rallying toward fresh records.

title: Cash key for Chevron and Exxon Mobil as Truist raises stock price targets
summary: Truist Securities has raised its price targets for Chevron Corp. and Exxon Mobil Corp. due to their strong cash positions and free cash flow generation. Exxon Mobil, in particular, was noted for generating over $17 billion in free cash flow last quarter, boosting its cash position significantly. These factors are contributing to the rally of both companies' stocks towards record highs.

title: QatarEnergy names ConocoPhilips partner for LNG expansion project
summary: QatarEnergy has announced ConocoPhillips as the third and final partner for its North Field South expansion, a key part of the world's largest liquefied natural gas (LNG) project. ConocoPhillips will hold a 6.25% interest, joining Shell and TotalEnergies, which each hold 9.375% stakes. The project aims to significantly increase Qatar's LNG liquefaction capacity, amidst growing global demand for gas following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

title: ExxonMobil, Chevron rake in record Q3 profits following oil price surge
summary: ExxonMobil and Chevron reported record third-quarter profits in 2022, significantly boosted by a surge in oil and natural gas prices. ExxonMobil's net income reached $19.7 billion, while Chevron's profit rose to $11.23 billion, driven by higher crude and natural gas prices despite some moderation towards the end of the quarter. Both companies are expanding production and refining capacity to meet ongoing strong demand, with ExxonMobil's CEO highlighting increased investment despite market uncertainties.

title: Exxon Mobil and Chevron together take in more than $30 billion in net income as natural gas prices soared
summary: Exxon Mobil and Chevron collectively reported over $30 billion in net income, driven by soaring natural gas prices and record refining volumes. Exxon Mobil's stock rallied to a record close after profit nearly tripled and revenue topped $100 billion, while Chevron also posted significant profit and revenue beats. Both companies benefited from a substantial increase in natural gas and crude oil prices.

title: Exxon Mobil and Chevron together take in more than $30 billion in net income as natural gas prices soared
summary: Exxon Mobil and Chevron collectively reported over $30 billion in net income, driven by a significant surge in natural gas prices and record refining volumes. Exxon Mobil's profit nearly tripled with revenue surpassing $100 billion, while Chevron also posted strong profit and revenue figures. Both companies saw their stock prices rally, with natural gas sales prices more than doubling in the U.S.

title: ExxonMobil Nearly Triples EPS But Comes Up Short on Revenue for Q3
summary: ExxonMobil reported a near tripling of its EPS for Q3, significantly beating analyst predictions, but missed revenue growth expectations. While revenue increased by 52% to $112.1 billion, this was the slowest pace in six quarters, and its upstream segment's net income also slightly missed forecasts despite a substantial increase. The company's stock has performed strongly, climbing 79% over the last year.

title: Exxon's Record-breaking Q3 Profit Nearly Matches Apple's
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp reported a record-breaking $19.66 billion third-quarter net profit, driven by soaring energy prices, nearly matching Apple's $20.7 billion for the same period. The company's profits were boosted by its continued investment in fossil fuels and strong natural gas earnings, enabling it to exceed Wall Street forecasts and maintain its share buyback program while increasing dividends. Despite withdrawing from Russia, Exxon is on track to meet investment targets and increase production in key areas like the Permian Basin and Guyana.

title: Exxon, Qatar go separate ways in marketing their U.S. LNG
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp and QatarEnergy have decided to independently market the liquefied natural gas (LNG) from their U.S. joint venture Golden Pass Terminal, dissolving their previous joint venture Ocean LNG. This decision is expected to generate increased value and flexibility for both companies, with ExxonMobil LNG Asia Pacific marketing 30% of volumes and QatarEnergy Trading marketing the remaining 70%. The Golden Pass project in Sabine Pass, Texas, is on schedule to start up in 2024.

title: ConocoPhillips to further tap nation's green biz, growing LNG demand
summary: ConocoPhillips plans to increase its supply of liquefied natural gas (LNG) to China, emphasizing its commitment to the long-term partnership and China's energy transition goals despite market uncertainties. The company also aims to explore opportunities in offshore wind farms, carbon capture, and oil supply, highlighting China's vital role in the global energy transition. ConocoPhillips will participate as an exhibitor for the first time in the fifth China International Import Expo to foster collaboration.

title: Oil output from Brazil's Petrobras dips nearly 7% in third quarter
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras reported a 6.8% decline in crude oil production for the third quarter compared to the previous year, pumping 2.115 million barrels per day. The decrease is attributed to fewer barrels from its Atapu and Sepia fields, the stoppage of its FPSO Capixaba unit, and the natural decline of mature fields. Despite this, 73% of Petrobras's output came from Brazil's pre-salt fields.

title: Reda HPS horizontal multistage surface pumping systems
summary: The article describes SLB's Reda HPS horizontal multistage surface pumping systems, highlighting their applications in various industries like oil and gas, mine dewatering, geothermal energy, and carbon sequestration. It details three main types: Reda Compact HPS, Reda HPS, and Reda Multiphase HPS, emphasizing their reliability, efficiency, and low maintenance. The article also touches upon the history of Reda pumps, tracing their origin back 90 years to Bartlesville, Oklahoma.

title: Stimulation Optimization
summary: This article from SLB details their "Stimulation Optimization" solutions aimed at maximizing stimulation and completion efficiency through integrated modeling and monitoring. It highlights the use of the Schlumberger digital oilfield platform to analyze various factors influencing production and introduces new stimulation monitoring technologies for real-time adjustments and continuous improvement. The offering includes advanced charges, fracturing computer-aided systems, and cement-conveyed frac performance technology.

title: Methane Emissions Management
summary: SLB offers comprehensive solutions for methane emissions management, acknowledging its significant impact on global warming. Their approach focuses on integrated operations, combining software, hardware, and end-to-end solutions to help companies identify, quantify, report, and eliminate methane emissions and routine flaring. This strategy aims to support the industry's decarbonization objectives and build long-term plans for emissions elimination.

title: Exxon shares surge to record high on strong earnings outlook
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp shares reached an all-time high due to rising oil prices and analysts' optimistic long-term forecasts for its cash flow and earnings. This surge vindicates CEO Darren Woods' strategy of investing in oil during the pandemic, leading to significant profits despite past losses and a challenging energy market. The company is poised for a record annual profit, although its market valuation is still below its 2007 peak and its production levels have not increased proportionally.

title: Exxon selling Montana oil refinery to Par Pacific in $310 million deal
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp has agreed to sell its Billings, Montana, refinery and related pipeline properties to Par Pacific Holdings Inc for $310 million. This sale aligns with Exxon's strategy to reduce its refining footprint and focus on higher-value products, ending a years-long effort. The acquisition will expand Par Pacific's downstream network in the western U.S. and is expected to close in the second quarter of 2023.

title: Houston company announces purchase of ExxonMobil refinery in Lockwood
summary: Par Pacific Holdings, Inc., a Houston-based company, announced its acquisition of ExxonMobil's 63,000 bpd refinery in Billings, Montana, for $310 million. This purchase includes associated marketing and logistics assets, significantly expanding Par Pacific's downstream network in the western United States. ExxonMobil stated its focus on higher-value products, while Par Pacific plans to offer positions to all 340 existing refinery and midstream employees.

title: Adams Natural Resources Fund Reports Nine Month Results
summary: Adams Natural Resources Fund, Inc. (NYSE: PEO) announced its results for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, with a total return on net asset value of 19.1%. This was slightly below its benchmark's return of 19.7%. The report also detailed annualized comparative returns, net asset value, and its ten largest equity portfolio holdings, showcasing a strong focus on energy companies.

title: Exxon selling Montana oil refinery to Par Pacific for $310 MM
summary: ExxonMobil Corp agreed to sell its Billings, Montana, refinery and related pipeline properties to Par Pacific Holdings Inc for $310 MM. This sale reflects Exxon's strategy to reduce its refining footprint and concentrate on plants along the U.S. Gulf Coast and in the Midwest, as well as sell oil-producing properties to boost returns. The deal for the 63,000-barrel-per-day refinery, which includes pipelines and terminals, is expected to close in the second quarter of 2023.

title: Par Pacific Announces Acquisition of ExxonMobil Billings Refinery and Associated Marketing and Logistics Assets
summary: Par Pacific Holdings, Inc. announced a definitive agreement to acquire ExxonMobil's 63,000 bpd Billings refinery and associated marketing and logistics assets for a base purchase price of $310 million. This acquisition is expected to enhance Par Pacific's scale, geographic diversification, and existing Pacific Northwest market position, with anticipated synergies exceeding $30 million. The transaction is projected to be immediately accretive to Adjusted Net Income and Free Cash Flow per share and is expected to close in Q2 2023.

title: Exclusive: Exxon exits Russia empty-handed with oil project 'unilaterally terminated'
summary: Exxon Mobil announced its complete exit from Russia after President Vladimir Putin expropriated its assets, including a 30% stake in the Sakhalin-1 oil project, following seven months of discussions. The company did not receive compensation for its assets, valued at over $4 billion, and its interests were "unilaterally terminated" by the Russian government. This departure highlights the ongoing clash between Western companies and Russia over energy in the wake of the invasion of Ukraine.

title: Products and Services
summary: This SLB page details the company's extensive range of products and services, categorized into key areas such as Decarbonizing Industry, Innovating in Oil and Gas, Scaling New Energy Systems, and Delivering Digital at Scale. It highlights technologies and solutions aimed at energy innovation, emissions reduction, and operational efficiency across various sectors. The page also features new market offerings and recent news releases from SLB.

title: Is AT&T Stock a Buy Ahead of Earnings?
summary: This article evaluates AT&T stock ahead of its earnings report, highlighting its renewed focus on telecom, improved financial position, and attractive dividend yield. Morningstar considers AT&T T undervalued with a $25 fair value estimate and a narrow economic moat. The analysis also covers the bulls' and bears' perspectives on the company's prospects and risks.

title: Eni (E) Begins Vegetable Oil Export From Kenya's Agri-hub
summary: Eni (E) has commenced exporting vegetable oil from its Makueni agri-hub in Kenya for bio-refining at its Gela bio-refinery in Sicily. This initiative is part of Eni's strategy to expand biofuel production, with targets of 2,500 tons by year-end 2022 and 20,000 tons by 2023, contributing to global efforts for cleaner energy and net-zero emissions. The company also exports Used Cooking Oil and aims to cover 35% of its biorefineries’ supply by 2025 through vertical integration of agri-feedstock.

title: Who’s to blame for California’s high gas prices?
summary: Governor Gavin Newsom has blamed oil companies for high gas prices in California, proposing a windfall tax on their profits. However, the article argues that unique factors like the state's specific refining requirements, high taxes, decreasing refining capacity due to a shift towards "zero emission" vehicles, and the reluctance of refiners to invest in upgrades are more likely causes. Legislative leaders are reportedly lukewarm to the idea of a windfall tax, questioning the evidence of oil company malfeasance and concerned that such a tax could be passed on to consumers or further constrict supply.

title: ETF 360: Rosenbluth and Minter Build the Case For Industrial Metals
summary: In this episode of ETF 360, Todd Rosenbluth and Robert Minter discuss the abrdn Bloomberg Industrial Metals Strategy K-1 Free ETF (BCIM). They highlight the resurgence in demand for commodity ETFs in 2022 due to their inflation-hedging benefits and strong performance compared to traditional assets. Minter emphasizes that industrial metals are crucial for the global energy transition, driven by major economies' push for renewable energy, and points out the tax benefits of BCIM as a K-1-free product.

title: Jefferies's Bowden Takes Over Global Industrial, Energy Banking
summary: Jefferies Financial Group Inc. has appointed Pete Bowden as its global head of industrial, energy, and infrastructure banking. Bowden, who has been with Jefferies since 2012, previously served as global head of energy since 2018. This move signifies an expansion of his role to cover a broader range of crucial sectors for the investment bank.

title: Two US companies commit to tax transparency. When will others make the move?
summary: Hess Corporation and Newmont Corporation have become the first US companies to publicly disclose key financial information through country-by-country reporting, aligning with the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) tax standard. This move marks a significant step towards greater tax transparency in the US, an area where American companies have historically lagged behind their international peers. The article highlights the benefits of such disclosures for investors and civil society, and encourages other US companies to follow suit, potentially influenced by proposed regulatory actions from the SEC and Congress.

title: Profits over politics: the case for anti-ESG ETFs
summary: Strive Asset Management has launched "anti-ESG" ETFs, Strive 500 ETF (STRV) and U.S. Energy ETF (DRLL), to counter "woke capitalism" and advocate for companies to focus solely on profits. Strive's executive chair, Vivek Ramaswamy, argues that corporations should prioritize financial success over political, social, or environmental agendas. While Strive aims to offer active engagement through proxy voting and shareholder engagement, existing ESG-focused funds continue to see significant inflows, indicating diverse investor choices.

title: Broken promises: Insurance giants Sun Life and Manulife are deep into coal, oil and gas
summary: Despite net-zero pledges, Canadian insurance giants Sun Life and Manulife have significantly increased their investments in fossil fuels, particularly coal, with holdings reaching US$15.9 billion and $9.9 billion respectively. This deep entanglement in coal, oil, and gas contradicts their climate commitments and positions them as major contributors to greenhouse gas emissions, raising concerns about the tension between their mission and financial goals. Shareholder advocacy groups are calling for stronger accountability and clear decarbonization strategies from these companies.

title: 33 Undervalued Stocks for 2022
summary: Morningstar has released its list of 33 top analyst picks for undervalued stocks heading into the fourth quarter of 2022. The U.S. stock market was down significantly for the year, with the median stock in Morningstar's North American coverage trading at more than a 20% discount to fair value. The article highlights undervalued sectors and provides a detailed list of stock picks across various industries, along with Morningstar's economic moat ratings, price-to-fair value ratios, uncertainty ratings, and star ratings for each.

title: Tesla's a 'key stock in everyone’s ESG portfolio.' So why is that so controversial?
summary: This article examines the controversy surrounding Tesla's inclusion in ESG portfolios despite its environmental contributions. While Tesla is a leader in EV technology and carbon emission reduction, concerns about its corporate governance, transparency on emissions, and controversies like racial discrimination and Autopilot safety issues have led to scrutiny and even removal from certain ESG indices. This highlights a fundamental debate within the ESG investing world regarding what constitutes true social responsibility and impact.

title: As permafrost thaws, a Biden-supported drilling plan is on unstable ground
summary: This article examines how thawing permafrost in Alaska's Arctic poses significant threats to oil and gas drilling projects, particularly ConocoPhillips' Willow project. It details a recent gas leak at ConocoPhillips' Alpine Field, where permafrost thaw exacerbated the incident, raising concerns about the stability and safety of new developments. The piece highlights the complex interplay between climate change, geological challenges, state oversight, and the economic and environmental impacts on local indigenous communities like Nuiqsut.

title: Hydrocracker upgrade boosts Wood River
summary: The Wood River Refinery, a 50-50 joint venture between Phillips 66 and Cenovus, has completed a major upgrade to its hydrocracker unit. This enhancement, including two new 3-million-pound reactors, allows the refinery to produce a higher percentage of in-demand fuels like diesel and jet fuel by optimizing low-value feedstocks and increasing clean-product yield. The project was completed safely, on schedule, and under budget, significantly strengthening the refinery's operations and positioning Phillips 66 to meet future liquid fuel needs.

title: NS Recognizes 48 Safe Shippers
summary: Norfolk Southern (NS) honored 48 customers with its 2021 Thoroughbred Chemical Safety Award for safely transporting hazardous materials without incident. This award, now in its 25th year, recognizes 43 corporate chemical manufacturers and five plants for their commitment to safety, aligning with Rail Safety Week. NS emphasizes strong working relationships with customers and its participation in the American Chemistry Council’s Responsible Care® Partner Program to ensure safe chemical transport.

title: Exxon Mobil shuts Fos-Sur-Mer refinery in France due to strike
summary: ExxonMobil is gradually shutting down its 235,000 barrel per day (bpd) Fos-Sur-Mer refinery in France due to ongoing strike action. This follows the shutdown of its Port Jerome-Gravenchon refinery and petrochemical site. The strikes were called by French unions CGT and Force Ouvriere over wage negotiations related to rising inflation.

title: Exclusive: Exxon boosts Guyana oil output, undecided on future auction bid
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is uncertain about bidding for new offshore areas in Guyana, as it ramps up production faster than expected and Guyana grapples with new oil lease terms. The Exxon-led consortium has significantly increased output to a record 390,000 barrels per day (boepd) on August 10, exceeding its initial 2022 target. Guyana is considering whether to hold an auction or partner with a national oil company for new properties, while also crafting a new Production Sharing Agreement to provide more economic benefits to the nation.

title: Crude oil tanker floats new dividend policy
summary: Bermudian-based DHT Holdings Inc, a crude oil tanker company, has announced a new dividend policy to return 100 per cent of net income to shareholders quarterly, effective from Q3. Meanwhile, Bermuda-based offshore drilling services company Valaris Limited received a $40 million partial early repayment from its joint venture ARO Drilling and authorized a $100 million share repurchase program. Additionally, executives at Bermudian-based LNG shipping company Flex LNG Ltd exercised and sold share options.

title: JX Nippon to buy NRG's stake in Petra Nova carbon capture plant near Houston
summary: JX Nippon, a co-developer of the Petra Nova carbon capture unit, is set to assume full ownership of the facility. The Petra Nova plant near Houston is described as the largest carbon capture unit of its kind globally, with an estimated development cost of $1 billion, partially funded by a $195 million grant from the Department of Energy.

title: Look to SPLV for Stability in Your Portfolio
summary: Investors are increasingly turning to the Invesco S&P 500 Low Volatility ETF (SPLV) for portfolio stability, with the fund attracting significant inflows in recent months. SPLV invests in the 100 least volatile securities from the S&P 500, focusing on established "blue-chip" companies known for their stability and dividends rather than high growth. The ETF is positioned as a defensive option that may outperform during bear markets and underperform in bull markets.

title: Opinion: Are Oklahoma 401(k) Plans Helping to Destroy State’s Energy Business?
summary: This opinion piece argues that Oklahoma 401(k) plan participants might unknowingly be investing in funds that work against the state's vital energy industry. The author, Terry Morgan of Ok401k, highlights the trend of large mutual fund companies adopting ESG investing criteria, which he claims can force corporations to comply with "woke" agendas and potentially harm the profitability of energy companies. He urges Oklahomans to be aware of how their investments are being used and suggests alternative funds like those from STRIVE Asset Management.

title: ExxonMobil Expands Fleet Reach With New Partnership
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has partnered with FLEETCOR Technologies Inc. to allow Fuelman and Comdata cards to be accepted at over 12,000 Exxon and Mobil stations across the U.S., expanding fleet reach and offering benefits like Synergy Diesel Efficient fuel and the Exxon Mobil Rewards+ loyalty program. Fuelman cardholders can immediately use their cards, while Comdata trucking cards will gain access starting in 2023. This collaboration aims to enhance the fueling experience for fleet customers by providing convenience, control, and savings.

title: Oil ETFs: What You Should Know Before You Invest
summary: This article explains what oil ETFs are, differentiating between those investing in oil industry equities and those in oil futures. It provides an overview of various types of oil ETFs, their performance, and investment opportunities and risks, emphasizing the current overweight recommendation for the energy sector. The author also offers specific ETF recommendations like XLE and VDE, and discusses considerations for investing in crude oil and gas futures via ETFs.

title: 5 Ways You Can Get Income From Your Investments Right Now |…
summary: This article outlines five easy ways investors can generate income from their investments, offering yields of up to 9%. It covers dividend-paying stocks and ETFs, bonds, REITs, Master Limited Partnerships (MLPs), and preferred shares. The author emphasizes the importance of diversifying an income portfolio to suit individual risk tolerance.

title: FLEETCOR® Signs ExxonMobil Relationship
summary: FLEETCOR Technologies, Inc. has signed network agreements with Exxon Mobil Corporation, enhancing the market position and product versatility of FLEETCOR’s North American commercial fleet card business, including its Comdata and Fuelman brands. The agreements provide brand-wide acceptance of Fuelman cards at over 12,000 Exxon and Mobil stations and will add acceptance of Comdata trucking cards at commercial fueling locations in 2023. This expansion offers cardholders benefits such as Exxon Mobil's Synergy Diesel Efficient™ fuel and the Exxon Mobil Rewards+™ loyalty program.

title: Will Friday’s weak gain in crude oil prices grow this week?
summary: Crude oil prices saw a weak gain on Friday amidst investor nervousness about China's COVID-19 shutdowns and the global economy, ahead of an OPEC+ meeting. West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude futures rose marginally, while natural gas prices fell. Various Oklahoma and other energy stocks experienced gains, with some utility stocks declining.

title: Exxon Beaumont, Texas, chemical plant upset triggered flaring -sources
summary: A malfunction at Exxon Mobil Corp's Beaumont, Texas, chemical plant led to flaring on Friday, according to sources familiar with the plant's operations. The chemical plant utilized portions of the adjoining refinery's safety flare system, though the refinery's operations remained normal. Exxon issued community notices regarding the flaring, which is a safety measure used by plants when they cannot process hydrocarbons normally.

title: Blackstone and Carlyle take different sides on oil and gas investment
summary: Private equity giants Blackstone and Carlyle Group are taking differing approaches to oil and gas investments amidst pressure to divest from fossil fuels and invest in cleaner energy. Blackstone is largely pulling back from new oil and gas exploration and production investments, while Carlyle Group and Brookfield Asset Management Inc. advocate for transforming existing traditional energy producers into more climate-friendly businesses, emphasizing "invest, not divest" strategies. This divergence reflects the challenges of volatile returns, a fraught political climate, and difficulties in financing and exiting fossil fuel assets, contrasting with the growing investment in renewable energy.

title: Direxion Plans Energy-Focused Single-Stock ETFs
summary: Direxion has filed for eight new single-stock ETFs focused on major energy companies like Chevron, ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, and EOG Resources. These funds will offer leveraged and inverse exposure, allowing investors to bet on both the upside and downside of these key energy stocks. The move comes as the energy sector, while having strong year-to-date performance, has recently faced significant outflows from the largest energy ETF (XLE).

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Exxon Escalates Dispute With Russia Over Barred Exit From Giant Oil Project
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has notified Russian officials of its intent to sue the government if it is not allowed to exit the Sakhalin-1 oil-and-gas project. A Russian decree enacted in early August has prevented Exxon from transferring operatorship and selling its 30% stake in the venture, despite the company's prior plans to divest following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

title: Dow temporarily cutting PE production by 15 percent
summary: Dow Inc., one of the world's largest polyethylene resin makers, is temporarily reducing its global PE production capacity by approximately 15 percent due to global logistics constraints, including port and rail congestions. This move aims to balance elevated inventories and improve logistics resiliency, particularly ahead of the hurricane season in the U.S. Industry analysts suggest the cuts are a temporary solution to PE overcapacity and declining prices but may not be widely followed by competitors.

title: Exxon, Shell, Chevron end lawsuits against Nigeria's state-owned oil company
summary: Four major oil companies, including Exxon, Shell, and Chevron, have agreed to end U.S. lawsuits seeking to enforce multi-billion dollar arbitration awards against Nigeria's state-owned oil company, NNPC. This decision follows new deepwater oil production sharing agreements between the companies and NNPC, with the lawsuits expected to be terminated after the agreements take effect. The disputes stemmed from accusations that NNPC drew more oil than permitted under previous contracts, with awards totaling nearly $4 billion.

title: Chart Industries CEO Expects LNG Plants to Go Up Faster as Projects Utilize New Designs
summary: Chart Industries CEO Jillian Evanko anticipates a rapid acceleration in LNG plant construction due to a shift towards smaller, modular designs that reduce costs and construction times. This modular approach, first adopted in the US and now gaining international traction, is helping to meet the escalating global demand for LNG, especially in light of recent geopolitical events. Evanko also highlighted hydrogen and carbon capture as key long-term growth areas for the company.

title: Exxon plans January coker, crude unit work at Louisiana refinery -sources
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp plans to shut down a coker and crude distillation units at its 520,000 barrel-per-day Baton Rouge, Louisiana, refinery for maintenance in January. The maintenance will begin with the 50,000-bpd Far East Coker, which will be shut for 68 days to replace all four of its coke drums. Subsequently, work will be performed on the refinery's four crude distillation units.

title: Peaking: Why Peaks Matter
summary: This report from RMI examines why demand peaks are critical for financial markets, particularly concerning the fossil fuel industry. It argues that a peak in demand signals a turning point from growth to decline, leading to falling volumes, prices, and profits, ultimately resulting in stranded assets and company bankruptcies. The report highlights the fossil fuel sector's vulnerability to these peaks due to low growth, high capital intensity, and the presence of cheaper renewable alternatives.

title: As inflation batters, TRS eyes natural gas
summary: The Teacher Retirement System of Texas (TRS), a $200 billion pension fund, is turning its attention to natural gas investments as a hedge against inflation. While inflation negatively impacts most of its portfolio, TRS's 6% allocation to Energy, Natural Resources and Infrastructure (ENRI) has performed well. The fund is specifically eying opportunities in natural gas infrastructure and export facilities, particularly on the US east coast, to capitalize on increased global demand and record prices.

title: ONGC signs agreement with ExxonMobil for deepwater exploration in India
summary: Indian oil explorer ONGC signed a Heads of Agreement with ExxonMobil for deepwater exploration in India's East and West coasts. This collaboration aims to monetize India's oil and gas resources and reduce its reliance on costly imports, with ExxonMobil's expertise expected to facilitate efficient fast-track development.

title: Tucker Carlson Gives the New Anti-ESG DRLL ETF a Big Boost
summary: The newly launched Strive U.S. Energy ETF (DRLL), an anti-ESG fund, has raised $100 million since August 10, with its founder Vivek Ramaswamy promoting conservative energy politics. The fund, backed by Peter Thiel and Bill Ackman, holds stakes primarily in large integrated oil companies like Exxon Mobil, Chevron, and ConocoPhillips. Its success hinges on the value of these assets, offering investors a way to express a political stance against ESG standards while playing the U.S. energy sector.

title: The Inflation Reduction Act Includes a Bonanza for the Carbon Capture Industry
summary: The Inflation Reduction Act significantly boosts the carbon capture industry by increasing tax credits for capturing CO2 from polluting sources to $85 per metric ton and for removing CO2 directly from the atmosphere to $180 per ton. This legislation, along with prior infrastructure investments, is expected to drive substantial growth in the sector, despite skepticism from environmentalists regarding the technology's effectiveness and its implications for fossil fuel companies. The new incentives are also likely to fuel local controversies, particularly concerning the construction of CO2 pipelines.

title: Meet the energy and climate bigwigs with White House access
summary: This article details the increased in-person meetings between Biden administration officials and energy executives, environmental leaders, and other stakeholders. Visitor logs reveal discussions between top White House advisers like Brian Deese and Gina McCarthy with CEOs from Chevron and Exxon Mobil, as well as various utility and environmental group representatives. These meetings provide insight into the efforts to shape the administration's energy and climate policies.

title: Strive Launches U.S. Energy Index Fund (DRLL) to Deliver a New Shareholder Mandate to U.S. Energy Companies
authors: Strive Asset Management via Business Wire
summary: Strive Asset Management has launched its U.S. Energy ETF (DRLL), aiming to refocus American energy companies on long-term profitability and increased oil and gas production, rather than ESG-driven political agendas. The firm plans to use its shareholder engagement to push for maximizing shareholder value by capitalizing on global energy demand. Strive anticipates significant appreciation in U.S. energy stocks due to factors like easing lockdown policies and supply shortages.

title: Yum! Brands (YUM) has what it takes to satisfy investor appetite
summary: Yum! Brands (YUM) showed positive revenue performance in Q2, primarily driven by Taco Bell, despite weakness in KFC and Pizza Hut and challenges in Russia and China. Despite recent earnings misses and market volatility, observers suggest buying and holding the stock due to its competitive dividend, global scale, and digital capabilities. The company's Q2 revenue increased 2% to $1.63 billion, with adjusted earnings down 9% annually to $1.05 per share.

title: Corporations Join the Nuclear Fusion Craze
summary: Major corporations like Google, Chevron, and Sumitomo are investing in nuclear fusion technology, indicating a growing belief in its potential as a viable source of clean energy. This corporate interest coincides with a broader resurgence of nuclear energy, as Europe considers green bonds for the power source and Germany rethinks its nuclear facility shutdown plans amidst an energy crisis. Silicon Valley, in particular, is embracing nuclear fusion as a future source of abundant, cheap, and clean energy.

title: Producing zero-emission hydrogen with natural gas
summary: Williams recently invested in Aurora Hydrogen, a company focused on technology that converts natural gas to hydrogen without carbon dioxide emissions. This investment supports Williams' strategy to leverage natural gas for decarbonization and will help scale Aurora Hydrogen's production to a demonstration plant by 2023. The technology promises to reduce global CO2 emissions significantly while using less electricity and not requiring water.

title: Mexican-American Advisor Managing $1.9 Billion Helps Clients At Morgan Stanley Diversify Away From Energy
summary: Arturo Karakowsky, a Mexican-American Managing Director at Morgan Stanley Wealth Management overseeing $1.9 billion in AUM, focuses on diversifying his Houston-based clients away from a heavy concentration in the energy sector. He emphasizes the importance of diversity within his 12-person team and his own background as an asset. Karakowsky is bullish on a long-term outlook for fixed income, equities, and alternatives, despite expecting short-term market volatility.

title: Ohio-based Marathon Petroleum reports profits soar amid high fuel prices during second quarter
summary: Marathon Petroleum reported a significant increase in profits during the second quarter of 2022, with its per-barrel profit margin tripling amidst high fuel prices. The company's adjusted net income reached $5.7 billion, up from $437 million in the same period last year, and Marathon refined at 100% capacity to meet strong demand. CEO Michael Hennigan attributed high prices to outside factors and noted the company's efforts to drive down costs.

title: Executive Viewpoint: The solution to our energy crisis does exist
summary: Jeremy D. Thigpen of Transocean Ltd. argues that the solution to the current energy crisis, characterized by high prices and geopolitical risks, is to safely and responsibly produce more oil and gas. He highlights that years of underinvestment and pressure to transition away from hydrocarbons have led to supply exceeding demand, despite global consumption projections indicating continued reliance on these energy sources. Thigpen emphasizes the need for increased capital investment in traditional energy, regulatory support, and public advocacy to ensure energy security and meet global demand, while also urging the development of all energy sources to prevent future crises.

title: Hafnia tanker involved in bunker oil spill in Mississippi River
summary: A Hafnia tanker, Hafnia Rhine, discharged an estimated 9,500 litres of bunker oil into the Mississippi River near Kenner, Louisiana, during a fuelling operation with a fuel barge. The US Coast Guard is overseeing the clean-up efforts with National Response Corp and Environmental Safety and Health Consulting Services, which have deployed containment and sorbent booms. Hafnia immediately activated its Vessel Response Plan and is cooperating with federal and state agencies, with the cause of the discharge still under investigation.

title: Exxon, Chevron Post Blowout Earnings, Oil Majors Bet on Buybacks
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp and Chevron Corp reported record revenues and profits due to surging crude oil and natural gas prices, with Exxon posting an all-time high quarterly profit for an international oil major. The major oil companies, including Shell and TotalEnergies, returned $23 billion to shareholders through buybacks, capitalizing on high margins, while facing criticism from politicians and consumer advocates over soaring profits amid high consumer fuel prices. Companies argue prices reflect global supply issues and underinvestment rather than gouging, resisting increased capital expenditure in favor of shareholder returns.

title: Exxon, Chevron post blowout earnings, oil majors bet on buybacks
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp and Chevron Corp reported record revenues bolstered by surging crude oil and natural gas prices, following similar results from European majors. Exxon posted a $17.9 billion quarterly profit, the highest for any international oil major in history, leading the U.S. pair, along with Shell and TotalEnergies, to combine for nearly $51 billion in the recent quarter. The companies are increasingly betting on share buybacks, with Exxon more than doubling its projected buyback program to $30 billion through 2022 and 2023.

title: NextDecade to supply LNG to Exxon Mobil from Texas Rio Grande plant
summary: NextDecade Corp announced a 20-year agreement to supply 1 million tonnes per annum (MTPA) of liquefied natural gas (LNG) to a unit of Exxon Mobil Corp from its proposed Rio Grande LNG export project in Texas. Commercial operations for the first liquefaction train are expected to begin as early as 2026. This deal comes amid increased global demand for alternative gas supplies following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, prompting NextDecade to anticipate a positive final investment decision on up to three trains in the second half of 2022.

title: Exxon Accelerates Production in Guyana, Makes Two New Discoveries
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced two new oil discoveries offshore Guyana and that it has already exceeded its original year-end daily production target for the South American country. The U.S. major is now producing more than 340,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with partner Hess reporting current production at 360,000 boepd. These discoveries, Seabob and Kiru-Kiru, bring the total to over 30 and reinforce Guyana's growing role as a global oil power.

title: Equinor second quarter 2022
summary: Equinor reported strong second-quarter 2022 adjusted earnings of USD 17.6 billion and USD 5.00 billion after tax, driven by high production and elevated energy prices due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The company also announced a significant increase in capital distribution, including a higher extraordinary cash dividend and an expanded share buy-back programme. Equinor is progressing its energy transition strategy through investments in low-carbon initiatives and exited all joint ventures in Russia during the quarter.

title: ConocoPhillips considers exit from US Gulf of Mexico
summary: ConocoPhillips is reportedly considering selling its minority stake in the Shell-operated Ursa platform and the Princess well in the US Gulf of Mexico, a move that would mark its exit from US offshore operations. This potential sale, valued in the high hundreds of millions of dollars, is driven by ConocoPhillips's recent focus on expanding its footprint in US shale basins, particularly the Permian. The company may retain the assets if a suitable offer is not received.

title: ConocoPhillips eyes U.S. Gulf of Mexico exit -sources
summary: ConocoPhillips is reportedly exploring a sale of its stake in the Ursa platform and Princess subsea well in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico, signaling its exit from deepwater energy production in the region. This move aligns with the company's strategy to divest assets, targeting $4 billion to $5 billion by the end of 2023, as it shifts focus to the Permian Basin. The divestment, potentially valued in the high hundreds of millions of dollars, would further solidify Conoco's presence as a major Permian operator.

title: Sasol Outage Means All South African Oil Refineries Are Now Shut
summary: Sasol Ltd. has declared force majeure on petroleum product supplies due to crude delivery delays at its Natref refinery, co-owned with TotalEnergies SE. This outage effectively shuts down almost all of South Africa's oil refining capacity, following a series of similar closures across the country. The temporary closure significantly impacts the nation's fuel production.

title: Taiwan edge AI company Gorilla Technology IPO surges 123% on first day of Nasdaq trading
summary: Taiwanese edge AI company Gorilla Technology Group saw its IPO surge 123% on its first day of Nasdaq trading, closing at US$33.43 under the ticker "GRRR." The company plans to use the proceeds from its business combination with Global SPAC Partners for working capital and international expansion, aiming to form a "Smart City Diverse Industry Alliance" to expand global markets for edge AI analytics solutions. Gorilla Technology has developed its edge AI technology over 20 years, holding 31 patents, and provides comprehensive video-centric and content management solutions across various sectors with key partnerships including Softbank, Intel, and Dell.

title: Hedge funds bet on Brazil oil and gas output surging 122%
summary: Hedge funds and investors are increasingly backing "junior producers" in Brazil's oil and gas sector, seeking alternatives to the turmoil-prone state-owned Petroleo Brasileiro SA. These junior companies are acquiring fields divested by Petrobras and are projected to significantly boost Brazil's oil and gas output, with ANP forecasting a 122% increase by 2025 from these assets. Despite risks like market volatility and past bankruptcies, investors see substantial profit potential due to anticipated production growth and attractive share prices.

title: Hilcorp Energy, Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips release the most greenhouse gasses among U.S. oil and gas companies
summary: According to a new report based on U.S. government data, Hilcorp Energy, Exxon Mobil, and ConocoPhillips are the leading emitters of greenhouse gases among 303 U.S. oil and gas companies that report to the EPA. While these companies rank high in absolute emissions, they often emphasize emissions intensity, which measures emissions per unit of energy produced, as a more accurate reflection of their efforts to decarbonize. The report, commissioned by Clean Air Task Force and Ceres, highlights a significant divergence in emissions intensity among producers, underscoring the role of operational decisions in climate impact.

title: Pioneer, Devon and ConocoPhillips Join OGMP 2.0, Commit to Leading Methane Performance and Increased Transparency in Emissions Reporting
summary: Pioneer Natural Resources Company, Devon Energy Corp., and ConocoPhillips have joined the Oil and Gas Methane Partnership (OGMP) 2.0 Initiative, committing to enhanced transparency in methane emissions reporting and reduction. This move aims to establish a global standard for methane performance and demonstrate their dedication to climate mitigation and responsible energy production. The companies express their commitment to leveraging this framework to advance their emissions reduction goals and encourage industry-wide improvements.

title: CenterPoint's Lesar tops list of Houston's best-paid corporate executives in male-dominated lineup
summary: CenterPoint Energy CEO David Lesar was the highest-paid executive among Houston public companies in 2021, earning $37.8 million, largely due to a turnaround at the company. Eight of the top ten highest-paid executives were from the energy sector, reflecting the industry's rebound. The average compensation for these top executives rose 9.5 percent in 2021, and the list remained male-dominated.

title: E3 Lithium Receives TSXV Approval and Closes Agreement with Imperial Oil
summary: E3 Lithium announced it received TSX Venture Exchange (TSXV) approval and closed its agreement with Imperial Oil. The company issued over 3.4 million prepaid warrants to Imperial Oil Limited for CAD $6.35 million and also issued common shares and paid a finder's fee for the transaction. This agreement will help advance E3 Lithium's Clearwater Lithium Project development.

title: Reborn Coffee scales down IPO size. Here’s what you need to know
summary: Reborn Coffee has decided to scale down its IPO to $17 million, deviating from its original plan to offer units comprising one common share and one warrant. The company, headquartered in Brea, California, plans to list on the Nasdaq under the symbol REBN and intends to use the IPO proceeds primarily for expanding its store network and opening 20 company-operated outlets within a year. Despite experiencing significant growth in revenues in 2021, the company also incurred a higher loss, and its future prospects will depend on the evolving pandemic situation.

title: Big Companies Offering Employees Mid-Year Raises to Cope with Inflation
summary: Many large U.S. corporations, including Exxon Mobil Corp., PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, Microsoft Corp., and T. Rowe Price Group Inc., are implementing mid-year raises or special bonuses for their employees to combat inflation and retain talent in a tight labor market. These moves are a response to increased living expenses and a desire to remain competitive employers, even as some executives express concerns about a potential economic slowdown. Companies are proactively adjusting compensation, with some even granting raises to new hires to address attrition and inflation pressures.

title: Exxon Mobil to Sell Canadian Shale Gas Assets for About $1.5 Billion
summary: Exxon Mobil and its subsidiary Imperial Oil are selling their Canadian shale gas business, XTO Energy Canada, to Whitecap Resources for approximately $1.5 billion in an all-cash deal. This sale marks Exxon's exit from certain Canadian natural gas regions and reflects a broader industry trend of consolidating oil-field investments in Western Canada. The transaction, involving over 600,000 net acres, is anticipated to close in the third quarter.

title: Exxon CEO says carbon removal is climate cure with oil perks
summary: Exxon Mobil CEO Darren Woods views direct air capture (DAC) technology as "the holy grail" for addressing climate change, allowing oil companies to remain profitable. This stance is likely to increase skepticism among environmentalists who fear such technologies could slow the transition away from fossil fuels, while Exxon continues to invest in both oil and gas production and emissions-cutting innovations. Environmental justice advocates also raise concerns about "technofixes" like DAC disproportionately affecting communities of color.

title: A ‘carbon bomb’ or desperately needed energy? Alaskan village holds key to Biden’s climate policy.
summary: The article discusses the difficult decision facing the Biden administration regarding ConocoPhillips's Willow project in Alaska's North Slope. This project presents a conflict between energy needs and environmental concerns, particularly for the Alaskan village of Nuiqsut, which has already experienced the impact of oil development. The outcome will be a key indicator of Biden's climate policy direction.

title: Is XLE ETF A Good Buy Now?
summary: The article analyzes the Energy Select Sector SPDR® Fund ETF (XLE), questioning its efficacy as an inflation hedge and its competitive dividend yield compared to individual oil stocks. It highlights that XLE holds a small number of large-cap oil and gas stocks, and its performance has been inconsistent over the last decade, often underperforming an equal-weighted holding of its top two stocks, XOM and CVX. The author suggests broader commodity strategies might be more preferable.

title: Chevron CEO urges Biden to stop criticizing Big Oil, take new approach
summary: Chevron CEO Michael Wirth urged President Biden to stop criticizing the oil industry and adopt a new approach to address high energy costs. Wirth's letter comes amid ongoing blame over rising fuel prices, with Biden accusing oil companies of profiting excessively while not increasing production. The CEO highlighted the industry's need for consistent policy regarding leases, permits, and infrastructure to meet energy demands.

title: Former UGI vice president shares supply lessons learned
summary: Steve Kossuth, former vice president of global LPG supply for UGI, shared insights on energy independence and diversity after nearly 15 years in the propane industry. He highlighted that the conflict in Europe underscores the importance of diverse energy sources and advocated for LPG's role in a carbon-reduced world. Kossuth also reflected on lessons learned from past events like the 2013-14 polar vortex, emphasizing the value of optionality and supply security in preparing for natural disasters and geopolitical events.

title: Eni SpA becomes second foreign firm to win $29 billion Qatari gas project stake
summary: Eni SpA has secured a 3.1% stake in Qatar's $29 billion North Field East expansion project, becoming the second foreign firm to join, following TotalEnergies SE. This expansion will increase Qatar's LNG production capacity significantly by 2026, amidst escalating energy crises in Europe and high demand for LNG. Other major players like China's Sinopec, China National Petroleum Corp., Exxon Mobil Corp., ConocoPhillips, and Shell Plc are also expected to invest in the project.

title: Setting a high target
summary: Advanced Drainage Systems Inc. (ADS) aims to significantly expand its recycling operations, targeting the use of 1 billion pounds of recycled resin annually by 2031. The company has already become one of North America's largest plastics recyclers, reprocessing about 650 million pounds of HDPE and PP annually, and plans to achieve its goal through in-house expansion and potential acquisitions. ADS emphasizes the long-term environmental benefits of using recycled materials in its durable water-management products.

title: Biden blasts oil refiners for record profits on pain at the pump
summary: U.S. President Joe Biden has demanded that oil refining companies explain why they are not increasing fuel production, despite making significant profits, as consumers face sky-high gasoline prices. He criticized these companies for reducing refining capacity to boost profits, attributing it to driving up gas prices and hindering efforts to counter the impact of the Ukraine war. Biden's administration is calling on refiners to act patriotically and increase supplies to ease consumer costs, with an emergency meeting planned with refinery executives.

title: Ohio-based Marathon Petroleum criticized by President Biden in letter about excess profits, lower fuel produc
summary: President Joe Biden has criticized Marathon Petroleum and six other oil refiners for generating excess profits while fuel production remains low, contributing to high gas prices. Marathon Petroleum reported significantly higher net income and profit margins in the first quarter of 2022, prompting Biden to call for concrete solutions to increase refining capacity. The American Petroleum Institute countered by blaming the administration's policies and advocating for measures to boost domestic oil and natural gas production.

title: FedEx's Activist-Backed Changes Help Lift Transportation ETFs
summary: FedEx Corp. (NYSE: FDX) saw its stock climb and boosted transportation sector ETFs after it raised its dividend and added new board members under pressure from activist investor D.E. Shaw Group. The company's quarterly dividend will increase by 53% to $1.15 per share, and executive-compensation plans will be modified to link cash bonuses to shareholder return, changes that were welcomed by analysts and investors.

title: Enterprise Products proposes $5B petrochemical expansion in Beaumont, Mont Belvieu (updated)
summary: Enterprise Products Partners LP is considering a major $5 billion to $5.25 billion petrochemical expansion in the Beaumont area, aiming to build an ethane cracker with a capacity of 2 million tons of ethylene per year. This proposed facility would be one of the largest globally, joining a new wave of cracker projects. The news comes as other major players like Exxon Mobil and CP Chem are also advancing significant petrochemical investments.

title: Caterpillar relocates headquarters from Chicago area to Irving
summary: Industrial giant Caterpillar Inc. is moving its global headquarters from suburban Chicago to Irving, Texas. The company, which already has 120 employees in Irving, cited strategic interests, talent attraction, and the business-friendly environment of North Texas as key reasons for the relocation. This move will make Caterpillar the fifth-largest public company headquartered in North Texas and adds to the region's growing list of Fortune 500 company headquarters.

title: Oil producer Sabinal Energy divvying up Permian assets for possible sale
summary: Sabinal Energy, an oil producer backed by Kayne Anderson, is preparing its Permian assets for a potential sale that could exceed $1 billion, possibly reaching $1.5 billion. The company is marketing approximately 132,000 net acres with a daily production of 13,000 barrels of oil equivalent, expected to generate over $400 million in EBITDA in the next year. This move aligns with a broader trend of consolidation in the Permian Basin and accelerated dealmaking in the shale patch as oil prices rise.

title: Mean Markets? Commodities May Be a Nice Alternative.
summary: The article discusses the poor performance of traditional asset classes in 2022, highlighting commodities as a potential bright spot due to their historically low correlation to other assets and their ability to act as an inflation hedge. It suggests that commodities could be a wise alternative for investors facing inflationary pressures and slower growth. Direxion offers specific ETFs (BRKY and COM) designed to capitalize on rising commodity prices and diversify portfolios.

title: Southern Company knew about climate change before it funded denial
summary: This report details a nearly 60-year history of Southern Company's awareness of climate change risks and its subsequent funding of climate disinformation campaigns. Despite early warnings dating back to 1964, the utility company engaged in a multi-million-dollar effort to discredit climate science, oppose emissions limits, and promote "clean coal" as a false solution. The report highlights financial contributions to various groups involved in climate denial and Southern Company's role in influencing public perception and policy.

title: International Seaways Sells Stake in Al Shaheen Oil Field FSOs to Euronav
summary: International Seaways has sold its 50% stake in two FSO vessels, FSO Asia and FSO Africa, to its joint venture partner Euronav NV for approximately $140 million in cash. The transaction, approved by North Oil Company, values the vessels at $300 million and secures their operation at the Al Shaheen oil field until Q3 2032 under a new ten-year contract. This move aims to strengthen International Seaways' balance sheet and support its long-term value creation strategy.

title: Chevron streamlines top operations management as U.S. oil role grows
summary: Chevron Corp is consolidating its exploration, production, and refining units under a single executive to sharpen its focus on U.S. oil and gas production and cost efficiency. This restructuring comes as the company increases its U.S. output, particularly in the Permian Basin, in response to global sanctions against Russian oil. The reorganization aims to align strategy and business development to deliver lower carbon energy.

title: Crude Oil Price Update – Strong Upside Breakout Puts $116.43 on Radar, Followed by $121.17
summary: Crude oil futures are trading higher due to optimism about a potential EU ban on Russian energy, increased U.S. refining activity, and low gasoline stockpiles ahead of summer driving season. Technical analysis indicates a strong uptrend, with July WTI crude oil targeting $116.43 and potentially $121.17 if current buying momentum continues.

title: Exxon shareholders back board, vote against faster carbon emission cuts
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp shareholders voted to back the company's board and its energy transition strategy, rejecting proposals to accelerate cuts to carbon emissions, particularly customer emissions (Scope 3). This marks a significant shift from the previous year, as concerns over energy security and fuel prices outweighed environmental resolutions. While investors supported better climate data analysis, they ultimately favored the company's stance on boosting fossil fuel production to address the global energy shortage.

title: Mitsui Enters into Participation Agreement for Carbon Sequestration Project in the U.S. with Sempra Infrastructure, TotalEnergies, and Mitsubishi Corporation | 2022 | Topics
summary: Mitsui & Co., Ltd. has entered into a participation agreement with Sempra Infrastructure, TotalEnergies, and Mitsubishi Corporation for the Hackberry Carbon Sequestration (HCS) project in southwest Louisiana, U.S. This project aims to capture and sequestrate up to 2 million tons per annum of CO2, primarily from Cameron LNG. Mitsui views its involvement in the HCS project as a contribution to global CCUS efforts and the realization of a sustainable society, aligning with its corporate mission and materiality goals.

title: Exxon must face Massachusetts climate change lawsuit, court rules
summary: Massachusetts' high court unanimously rejected Exxon Mobil Corp's bid to dismiss a lawsuit accusing the oil company of misleading consumers and investors about climate change. The court ruled that the state's anti-SLAPP law does not apply to government enforcement actions, allowing Attorney General Maura Healey's case to proceed. Exxon is evaluating its next steps, maintaining its innocence and arguing the case is politically motivated.

title: Marathon is renewing its El Paso refinery's air permit. Here's how you can weigh in.
summary: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) is holding a public meeting regarding Marathon Refinery's application to renew its air permit in El Paso. The meeting on May 24th will allow the public to comment on the permit, which outlines allowed air pollutant emissions for the refinery. Concerns have been raised about the TCEQ's new language access plan, as Spanish translations of key documents are not available, despite the refinery being located in a predominantly Hispanic, Spanish-speaking area.

title: Tesla dumped by S&P ESG index as Musk calls label a ‘scam’
summary: Tesla has been removed from the S&P 500 ESG Index due to concerns regarding working conditions, its handling of investigations into driver-assistance system deaths, and a lack of low-carbon strategy and business conduct codes. While S&P Dow Jones Indices noted Tesla's ESG score remained "fairly stable," it slipped against improving global peers. CEO Elon Musk subsequently criticized ESG as a "scam" and "fundamentally flawed," stating it has been "weaponized by phony social justice warriors."

title: Q&A: The Activist Investor Who Shook Up the Board at ExxonMobil, on How—or if—it Changed the Company
summary: This article features a Q&A with Charlie Penner, formerly of Engine No. 1, discussing the activist hedge fund's successful campaign against ExxonMobil. Penner reflects on the motivations behind the campaign to push Exxon towards better long-term capital allocation and climate planning, and assesses the company's changes a year later. He emphasizes that significant transformation will take time and highlights the interplay between investor activism, regulation, and a transition to a cleaner energy future.

title: Chevron and Exxonmobil to explore lower carbon opportunities in Indonesia
summary: U.S. energy giants Chevron and ExxonMobil have inked separate deals with Indonesian state energy company PT Pertamina to investigate various lower carbon business opportunities in Indonesia. These agreements focus on areas such as new geothermal technology, carbon offsets, carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS), as well as lower carbon hydrogen development, aligning with Indonesia's net-zero ambitions. The collaborations aim to leverage each company's strengths to advance sustainable energy solutions and support Indonesia's energy independence.

title: Cancer-causing gas emission spikes continue at refineries
summary: A new report by the Environmental Integrity Project reveals that benzene emissions at many refineries, including Marathon Petroleum's Galveston Bay refinery, increased significantly from 2018 to 2021, exceeding EPA action levels. This highlights the persistent challenge for the EPA in controlling this dangerous pollutant linked to leukemia and other health issues. While some companies cite "atypical events" for the spikes, the EPA is investigating and environmental advocates are calling for stronger action.

title: Global 2000: Berkshire Hathaway Takes Down JPMorgan As America’s Largest Company
summary: Berkshire Hathaway has surpassed JPMorgan Chase to become America's largest public company in the Forbes Global 2000 list, driven by nearly $90 billion in profits. Despite global volatility, U.S. companies like Amazon and ExxonMobil showed significant growth, with Amazon rising to third in the U.S. and ExxonMobil rebounding strongly due to surging energy prices. The article highlights the resilience of top U.S. companies amid inflation and geopolitical challenges.

title: ICE launches nature-based carbon credit futures contract
summary: Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) has launched a nature-based solutions (NBS) carbon credit futures contract to bring price signals to the voluntary carbon market. This new contract, which traded at $11.25 per tonne for its December 2022 expiry, is designed to measure the carbon sequestration capabilities of nature. Companies like Shell have welcomed the initiative as a step towards greater transparency and scale in the voluntary carbon market, using such credits to compensate for emissions they cannot otherwise reduce.

title: C2G Pipeline capitalizes on growing NGL demand
summary: Phillips 66 has completed and commissioned the C2G pipeline, a 155-mile bidirectional ethane pipeline connecting its Clemens Caverns to ExxonMobil and SABIC’s Gulf Coast Growth Ventures facility in Gregory, Texas. This project, which includes a contract for Phillips 66 to store and supply ethane, signifies the company's strong position in the growing natural gas liquids market. The C2G pipeline enhances flexibility, opens new markets south of the Sweeny Hub, and aligns with Phillips 66's growth strategy in the NGL sector, anticipating robust future demand from the global chemicals industry.

title: Imperial Oil nearly triples quarterly profit on surging crude prices
authors: Reuters Nia Williams and Ruhi Soni
summary: Imperial Oil nearly tripled its first-quarter profit due to surging global oil prices and announced a substantial issuer bid (SIB) to buy back up to $2.5 billion of its common shares. The company's earnings were the highest first-quarter earnings in over 30 years, despite a decrease in gross upstream production primarily due to extreme cold weather impacting its Kearl oil sands mine. This financial success mirrors that of rivals benefiting from high crude prices driven by concerns over tight supplies.

title: Exxon, Chevron post big revenues, but Wall Street shrugs
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp and Chevron Corp reported substantial first-quarter revenues, earning $5.5 billion and $6.3 billion respectively, yet disappointed Wall Street analysts who expected more given soaring oil prices. Both companies faced unexpected cash flow levels, derivative-related losses, and increased inflationary pressures, leading to a drop in their stock prices. Despite these setbacks and criticism from lawmakers, Exxon stated it does not plan to change its drilling strategy based on short-term demand.

title: Is Mexico’s resurgence losing steam?
summary: Mexico's economic resurgence, strong in 2021, appears to be losing momentum in 2022 due to domestic policy concerns and potential slowing US growth. While other Latin American markets benefited from commodity price surges, Mexico, an export-oriented economy focused on manufactured goods, has lagged behind its peers. The article also highlights concerns about inflation, interest rate hikes, and recent energy sector policy changes that could negatively impact its long-term economic outlook.

title: People on the Move: ExxonMobil, Global Partners, Parker's & NYACS
summary: This article details recent executive changes and personnel moves across several companies in the convenience store industry, including ExxonMobil, Global Partners, Dawn Foods, GreenPrint, PIM Brands Inc., Talking Rain Beverage Co., and Turning Points Brands. It also highlights awards and new appointments within industry associations like NYACS, the National Confectioners Association, the National Confectionery Sales Association, and the Pennsylvania Food Merchants Association, along with new hires at Parker's and TruAge. The changes reflect strategic shifts in leadership, marketing, and operations within these organizations.

title: Documents show Spire scrambling for survival of St. Louis pipeline after court ruling
summary: This article details how Spire Inc. engaged in assertive marketing and political lobbying to ensure the survival of its 65-mile STL Pipeline after a court ruling questioned its necessity. The company warned of heat outages for 400,000 customers, obtained a temporary operating permit, and simultaneously worked to undermine the transition to renewable energy. The article also highlights Spire's legal battles with property owners and its broader fight against electrification, which it sees as an "existential threat" to its profits from residential gas sales.

title: PEP Earnings: Key quarterly highlights from PepsiCo’s Q1 2022 financial results
summary: PepsiCo (NASDAQ: PEP) reported strong first-quarter 2022 earnings, with net revenues growing 9.3% to $16.2 billion and organic revenue up 13.7%. Net income attributable to PepsiCo more than doubled to $4.2 billion, or $3.06 per share, compared to the prior-year period. The company exceeded both top and bottom-line estimates and provided an optimistic outlook for fiscal year 2022, projecting 8% organic revenue growth and a 6% increase in core EPS to $6.63.

title: Republic Services landfill near Pearland houses one of nation's largest renewable natural gas plants
summary: Republic Services' Blue Ridge Landfill near Pearland is home to one of the nation's largest renewable natural gas (RNG) operations. This plant, developed with Morrow Energy, leverages landfill gas to produce renewable natural gas. The facility is a significant contributor to clean energy efforts, according to EPA data.

title: Global X launches Europe’s first uranium industry ETF
summary: Global X has launched Europe's first ETF providing exposure to the uranium industry, the Global X Uranium UCITS ETF, listed on the London Stock Exchange and Deutsche Börse Xetra. This launch comes as uranium prices have surged due to global climate initiatives and the ongoing war in Ukraine, which has highlighted nuclear power's role as a bridging fuel and created potential supply chain strains. The ETF tracks the Solactive Global Uranium & Nuclear Components v2 Index, investing in companies involved in uranium mining, exploration, and related technologies, reflecting strong interest in the sector seen in Global X's US-listed uranium ETF.

title: Gasoducto Néstor Kirchner: beneficios e impactos de largo plazo de la obra que transportará el gas de Vaca Muerta
summary: The article details the benefits and long-term impacts of the Néstor Kirchner Gas Pipeline, a crucial project for Argentina's energy development. This pipeline will transport gas from Vaca Muerta, aiming to improve domestic supply, reduce reliance on imported fuels, and enable gas exports to neighboring countries. The project is divided into three stages, designed to progressively increase transport capacity to 39 million cubic meters per day.

title: Exxon sees carbon capture market at $4 trillion by 2050
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. projects the carbon capture and storage (CCS) market to reach $4 trillion by 2050, representing about 60% of its estimated oil and gas market for the same period. The company is investing in this technology as a key emissions reduction strategy amid public pressure, with Occidental Petroleum also seeing CCS as a significant future industry.

title: In wild west of sustainable investing, which funds are the most responsible?
summary: The article discusses the growth and challenges of sustainable investing, noting that 2021 tested the optimism of the previous year. It highlights the increased scrutiny on ESG funds due to greenwashing concerns and the emerging standards for transparency and disclosure. Corporate Knights conducted research on over 1,000 ETFs and mutual funds to identify top performers in financial and sustainability metrics.

title: Oklahoma Shale Driller Chaparral Rebrands as Canvas Energy
summary: Chaparral Energy Inc. has rebranded as Canvas Energy Inc., completing a strategic transformation focused on ESG principles, efficient low-cost field operations, and sustainable free cash flow generation. The Oklahoma-based company, which emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy last October, aims to use its fresh assets and strong balance sheet to self-fund its new strategy. The rebranding includes a new name, logo, website, and updated corporate presentation.

title: BNY Mellon (BK) Infographic: Key financials and quarterly highlights
summary: The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation (NYSE: BK) reported its first-quarter 2022 earnings results. Total revenue increased by 2% to $3.9 billion, while net income applicable to common shareholders fell 19% to $699 million, and EPS dropped 11% to $0.86. Assets under management increased 2% to $2.3 trillion.

title: Sempra exec speaks of plans to expand LNG facility
summary: Sempra Infrastructure President Dan Brouillette announced plans to expand the Cameron LNG facility in Louisiana, proposing another train to export 6.75 million tons of LNG annually. The expansion is driven by global demand for natural gas and is expected to create 1,500 construction jobs and 69 permanent positions. Brouillette also highlighted the strategic importance of this expansion for European energy security and discussed a carbon storage facility in development.

title: Exxon to invest $10 billion in massive Guyana offshore oil project
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced a $10 billion investment in its fourth oil production project, Yellowtail, off the coast of Guyana. This project is part of Exxon's strategy to produce up to 1.2 million barrels per day of oil and gas by 2027 from Guyana, with contributions from partners Hess Corp and CNOOC Ltd. Yellowtail is expected to produce about 250,000 barrels of oil per day starting in 2025 and will include six drill centers and up to 26 production and 25 injection wells.

title: ‘The Future is Bleak, and the Future is Bright.’ What It’s Like to Be a Clean Energy CEO as Gas Prices Skyrocket
summary: This article interviews Jason Few, CEO of FuelCell Energy, about the challenges and opportunities for clean energy amidst rising gas prices. Few discusses the slow adoption of fuel-cell technology, the importance of government policies and cost reduction, and the role of carbon capture in achieving global climate goals. He also shares his personal clean energy commitments and thoughts on the broader energy transition.

title: Exxon Mobil gets Guyana's approval for fourth offshore oil project
summary: Exxon Mobil has received approval from Guyana's Environmental Protection Agency to begin work on its fourth offshore oil project, Yellowtail, in the South American country. This approval allows for construction and operation, with production expected to start in 2025 and pump up to 250,000 barrels of oil and gas per day. The permit includes strict environmental conditions, such as prohibiting routine gas flaring and requiring insurance for environmental damages.

title: Huge HPE Campus Acquired by Mexcor
summary: Mexcor International has acquired a 2 million-square-foot former Hewlett Packard Enterprise corporate campus in Northwest Houston, marking one of the largest transactions in the area in years. This acquisition significantly expands Mexcor's footprint, adding 66 acres and over 2 million square feet to its existing 28-acre facility, positioning the liquor and beverage distributor for continued growth and diversification into technology ventures. Meanwhile, Hewlett Packard Enterprise has relocated its global headquarters to a new facility at City Place, where Exxon Mobil is also establishing its headquarters.

title: Here's Where I'd Pump a Trade in Exxon
summary: The author suggests a trade opportunity in Exxon Mobil (XOM) due to the ongoing energy rally. The article recommends buying April 22, $85 calls for XOM, expecting the stock to approach $90 again in the next month. This trade is based on the belief that the energy market is still in the early stages of its rally.

title: Permian Basin land sought after by oil and gas companies Russia conflict grows fuel demand
summary: Oil and gas companies are actively acquiring land in the Permian Basin to increase production amid rising fuel demand spurred by the conflict in Russia. Orion Diversified Holdings recently purchased 320 acres in Ward County, Texas, to expand its oil and gas operations and wastewater disposal capabilities. The region is also seeing advancements in produced water recycling, driven by partnerships like Texas Pacific Land Corporation and Aris Water Solutions, to address environmental concerns and support increased drilling activity.

title: TGS ampliará el gasoducto Vaca Muerta Norte
summary: Transportadora Gas del Sur (TGS) will invest $60 million to expand the Vaca Muerta Norte gas pipeline, increasing its capacity by 17 million cubic meters daily. This project will connect Los Toldos and El Trapial to the Tratayén plant, addressing a key bottleneck in transporting gas from the Vaca Muerta formation. The expansion is crucial for supporting the growing natural gas production in the region, with operations expected to begin by June of the following year.

title: Exxon Mobil Powering Bitcoin Mining Pilot Using Excess Natural Gas: Report
summary: Exxon Mobil is reportedly using its pilot program to turn unspent natural gas into profit by powering a Bitcoin mining operation. This initiative, in agreement with Crusoe Energy Systems, utilizes gas from an oil well in the Bakken Formation to run mobile generators for crypto-mining servers.
