The oil giant is considering expanding similar projects to other locations globally to reduce waste from gas flaring.

title: Powerful clouds of methane spotted in Alabama coal country
summary: Satellite observations have revealed powerful clouds of methane near a coal-mining basin in Alabama, highlighting a significant, often overlooked, climate impact of coal. These plumes were detected near mines operated by Warrior Met Coal Inc., RJR Mining Co., and Southland Resources, with methane being a greenhouse gas far more potent than carbon dioxide in the short term. The discovery underscores the ongoing challenge of methane emissions from coal mining, which can persist even after mines are closed.

title: Strategy, Sustainability & Climate Presentation: TotalEnergies reports on the progress made in 2021 and expands its ambition towards Carbon Neutrality
summary: TotalEnergies presents its 2022 Progress Report on Sustainability & Climate, detailing advancements in its transformation strategy and an updated climate ambition, aligning with its commitment to reach net zero by 2050. The company made significant progress in 2021, including increased investments in renewables and a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. TotalEnergies is expanding its ambition with new targets for reducing emissions from petroleum product sales and methane, supported by a disciplined investment policy focused on decarbonized energies and maintaining existing infrastructure.

title: Global High-Density Polyethylene (HDPE) Market to Boost in Coming Years – Projected to Reach 78.0 Million Tons by 2028 | BlueWeave Consulting
authors: BlueWeave Consulting and Research Pvt Ltd
summary: The global High-Density Polyethylene (HDPE) market is projected to grow from 54.7 million tons in 2021 to 78.0 million tons by 2028, at a CAGR of 5.6%. This growth is driven by HDPE's diverse applications, including packaging, and the increasing demand for lightweight materials and developing construction sectors. The Asia-Pacific region is expected to dominate this market due to significant industrial and infrastructure development.

title: From electric AVs to oil: Ex-GM exec Ammann signs on at Exxon Mobil
summary: Former GM executive Dan Ammann, who previously led GM's autonomous vehicle unit Cruise, has been appointed president of Exxon Mobil Corp.'s Low Carbon Solutions business, effective May 1. Ammann's departure from Cruise in late 2021 was reportedly due to differing visions for the company's future with GM leadership. In his new role, Ammann will focus on commercializing ExxonMobil's low-emission portfolio to create shareholder value and support global emission-reduction efforts.

title: Once the biggest importer of Russian oil, Valero looks to Latin America and elsewhere to replace it
summary: Valero, formerly the largest U.S. importer of Russian oil, is seeking new crude supplies from Latin America and other regions after voluntarily discontinuing Russian purchases due to the invasion of Ukraine. The company is actively pursuing supply contracts with countries like Ecuador to fill the void, despite market uncertainties and rising oil prices. Analysts offer mixed prospects for Valero, with some seeing potential benefits from market shifts, while others foresee a negative impact on profitability despite the company's efforts to adapt.

title: Steelworkers Walk Off Job at Chevron Richmond Refinery
summary: Over 500 workers at Chevron Corp.'s Richmond refinery went on strike due to safety concerns and demands for higher wages to combat inflation and high Bay Area living costs. The United Steelworkers union stated that the strike began after workers rejected Chevron's contract offer, which offered a 2.5% pay increase while the union sought 5%. The strike raises concerns about potential impacts on California's already high gasoline prices, though Chevron anticipates no issues in maintaining product supply with replacement workers.

title: Workers go on strike at California refinery owned by Chevron
summary: Over 500 workers at Chevron Corp.'s refinery in Richmond, California, initiated a strike after rejecting a contract offer the United Steelworkers union deemed unreasonable. Chevron stated that refinery operations would continue and that it does not anticipate supply chain issues, despite concerns that a prolonged strike could impact California's high gasoline prices. The dispute arose as local bargaining units negotiated specific issues beyond a national agreement for oil workers.

title: Baker Hughes joins Halliburton and Schlumberger in pausing Russian operations
summary: Baker Hughes announced it is suspending new investments for its Russia operations, following similar moves by rivals Halliburton Co. and Schlumberger, in response to U.S. sanctions over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. This decision means these major oil field services companies are winding down or suspending activities in Russia, joining over 400 other multinational firms. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has urged remaining U.S. businesses to leave Russia, stating the market is "flooded with our blood."

title: US oil giant Halliburton suspends operations in Russia
summary: Halliburton and Schlumberger, two major US oil field services companies, have announced the suspension of their operations in Russia due to sanctions imposed over the invasion of Ukraine. Halliburton halted future business, shipments of sanctioned parts, and has no active joint ventures, while Schlumberger ceased investment and technology deployment. This move follows similar actions by over 400 other multinational firms pressured to exit the Russian market.

title: Feeling Short on Energy? Give This Inverse ETF a Look
summary: The energy sector has seen a recent decline, with the S&P GSCI Energy index falling over 20% since March 8, creating an opportunity for bearish traders. An inverse ETF, the Direxion Daily Energy Bear 2X Shares (ERY), is presented as a way to capitalize on further weakness in the energy sector. The article notes that despite recent drops, energy has been a stellar performer and a hedge against inflation for much of the year, but ongoing negotiations regarding the Russia-Ukraine conflict could temper oil prices.

title: News Content Hub - Rigs report: contracting activity jumps, Valaris drillship sustains minor damage
summary: Global offshore drilling activity significantly increased, with seven new contracts pushing the total to 351 contracted jack-ups and floaters. Maersk Drilling secured a 150-day contract for its Maersk Resolve rig, valued at US$16.9M. Concurrently, the Valaris DS-16 drillship and bulk carrier Akti sustained minor damage in a collision due to gale-force winds in Pascagoula, Mississippi, though Valaris expects no delays to its contract commencement.

title: Energy ETFs Retreat as Crude Oil Dips Below $100
summary: Energy ETFs plunged as crude oil prices fell below $100, driven by waning supply fears and concerns over demand due to a spike in COVID-19 cases in China. The decline was also influenced by potential progress in the Iran nuclear deal, which could reintroduce Iranian oil to global markets, and ongoing Russia-Ukraine ceasefire talks. Additionally, China's decreased oil processing rates and the Federal Reserve's anticipated interest rate hike further weighed on the oil market.

title: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights Chevron, Exxon Mobil, Tesla, Target Corp, and Marriott International
summary: This Zacks Analyst Blog highlights five U.S. corporate giants—Chevron, Exxon Mobil, Tesla, Target Corp, and Marriott International—as strong buy recommendations despite current market volatility, inflation, and geopolitical tensions. These companies are identified for their strong fundamentals, positive earnings estimate revisions, and solid growth potential. The article provides a detailed analysis of why each company is a compelling investment, citing their business models, market positioning, and financial outlook amidst challenging economic conditions.

title: Fact check: Is the U.S. polluting the air more than ever?
summary: This article fact-checks a claim by U.S. Rep. Glenn Grothman that the U.S. has made significant strides in reducing carbon emissions compared to other countries. PolitiFact rated his claim as "True," citing data showing an 8.2 percent decrease in U.S. greenhouse gas emissions from 2010 to 2019, while countries like China and India saw increases. The article also touches on Grothman's concern that stricter U.S. environmental laws could push manufacturing jobs to countries with lower standards.

title: San Antonio’s Valero Energy was a big buyer of Russian oil; with new ban, it’s looking elsewhere
summary: San Antonio-based Valero Energy Corp., a major buyer of Russian crude oil, faces a new ban on imports from Russia imposed by President Biden in response to the invasion of Ukraine. The company, which purchased over 15 million barrels of Russian oil last year, will now have to seek alternative sources, likely contributing to higher gasoline prices. Analysts note the difficulty of replacing Russian crude quickly and the potential for a significant oil supply shortage.

title: ConocoPhillips CEO says a decision to drill more today won't see oil flowing for up to a year
summary: ConocoPhillips CEO Ryan Lance stated that even if drilling for new oil started immediately today, it would take 8 to 12 months for the oil to begin flowing, offering no immediate relief to elevated prices. His comments followed the U.S. ban on Russian oil imports and highlighted challenges like inflation and supply chain issues impacting the oil industry's ability to ramp up production quickly. Lance also suggested that tapping into strategic petroleum reserves could provide short-term relief, but a longer-term strategy is needed for energy security given the potential for sustained high oil prices.

title: ConocoPhillips CEO: Not much conversation between oil industry and Biden Administration
summary: ConocoPhillips CEO Ryan Lance stated that there was not much conversation between the oil industry and the Biden Administration before Russia invaded Ukraine, but that has since ramped up due to national and energy security concerns. Lance also cautioned that the Russia-Ukraine situation may not resolve quickly, requiring longer-term planning for energy security. While initially commenting on a potential ban on energy exports as "stupidest", the CEO and ConocoPhillips fully support President Biden's ban on Russian oil imports.

title: John Hess Built His Net Worth in the Oil and Gas Industry
summary: John Hess, CEO of Hess Corporation, has amassed a net worth of at least $440 million through his family's long-standing involvement in the oil and gas industry, founded by his father Leon Hess. He recently urged the U.S. and IEA to take more aggressive action to stabilize oil prices amidst the Russia-Ukraine war and rising petroleum costs, advocating for larger releases from strategic reserves. Hess believes these actions are crucial to prevent an economic recession.

title: Hess CEO says oil is in the 'intensive care unit' — U.S., other nations need to act
summary: Hess Corporation CEO John Hess asserted that the oil market is in the "intensive care unit" and urged the U.S. and other nations to take immediate action to stabilize prices amidst the Russia-Ukraine war. He called on the International Energy Agency to release 240 million barrels from strategic petroleum reserves, arguing that last week's 60 million barrel release was insufficient to avert an economic recession.

title: ANTHONY CAVANNA Obituary (2022) - Washington, DC - The Washington Post
summary: Anthony J. Cavanna, a key executive instrumental in taking Trex Company Inc. public in 1999, passed away on February 10, 2022, at the age of 82. He had a distinguished 35-year career at ExxonMobil before co-founding Trex and overseeing its financial success. Cavanna was also a dedicated alumnus of Villanova School of Engineering and was knighted for his contributions to the Belgian economy.

title: Dow slides nearly 800 points as oil hits $120 a barrel while Russia conflict rattles investors
summary: Global stocks, including the Nasdaq, dropped significantly as oil prices surged to $120 a barrel. This market reaction was driven by investor concerns over potential sanctions on Russian crude oil and the broader economic implications of the conflict in Ukraine. The national average for gasoline also rose to $4 per gallon.

title: Exxon Mobil CEO says oil companies were in tough position before Ukraine-Russia war
summary: Exxon Mobil CEO Darren Woods stated that oil companies were challenged to ramp up production to meet demand even before the Ukraine crisis due to underinvestment during the COVID-19 pandemic and reduced government support. Woods also highlighted the global energy security needs exposed by the conflict and Exxon's efforts to increase production despite also halting operations in Russia. The article touches on rising oil prices, the U.S. government's deliberation on banning Russian oil imports, and the interconnectedness of the energy industry.

title: Commodity funds post hefty gains over the past week
summary: Commodity mutual funds and ETFs experienced significant gains over the last week due to rising crude oil and metal prices, intensified by the conflict between Russia and Ukraine. Key performers included ProShares Ultra Bloomberg Crude Oil, United States Oil Fund LP, and iShares S&P GSCI Commodity-Indexed Trust, with oil prices reaching 2008 highs and other commodity futures also soaring. This surge led to a net inflow of $7.9 billion into commodity funds in February, marking the largest influx since August 2020.

title: Exxon sues U.S. over taxes related to gas project in Qatar
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp has filed a lawsuit against the U.S. government seeking a partial refund of $2.1 billion in taxes and penalties. The taxes are related to a gas project in Qatar, with Exxon alleging overpayment of income taxes and misclassification of agreements. The company claims the U.S. erroneously collected taxes for tax years 2010 and 2011 and has not respected the partnership's decision to finance its venture with debt.

title: First U.S. refiner suspends purchases of Russian crude for Hawaii refinery
summary: Par Pacific Holdings Inc. has announced it will suspend purchases of Russian crude oil for its Hawaii refinery, becoming the first U.S. refiner to publicly do so after sanctions imposed due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The company plans to source crude from North and South America and was the fifth largest U.S. importer of Russian crude in 2021. This move comes as other Western companies halt Russian operations and the U.S. considers further sanctions on Russia's oil sector.

title: Canadian Natural Resources reports Q4 profit up, raises quarterly dividend
summary: Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. reported a significant increase in its fourth-quarter profit and raised its quarterly dividend by 28%, despite the volatile oil market exacerbated by global geopolitical events. The company emphasized a prudent, longer-term perspective on oil prices, highlighting its focus on sustainable dividend increases and strong debt reduction, with net debt decreasing by $1.9 billion. CNRL's revenue soared to $9.21 billion in Q4, and its full-year earnings reached $7.66 billion.

title: Halliburton opens first-of-its-kind chemical plant in Saudi Arabia
summary: Halliburton has opened a new chemical plant in Jubail, Saudi Arabia, marking a significant investment in the country. This facility is part of the $1 billion Halliburton has invested in Saudi Arabia over the last decade. Executives from Aramco and Halliburton CEO Jeff Miller were present at the inauguration.

title: Oil Prices Drop as Iran Deal is Renegotiated
summary: Oil prices dropped to $110 per barrel after the prospect of Iranian crude returning to the market emerged amidst renegotiations of the 2015 Iran nuclear deal. The U.S. and other nations are in talks to restore the agreement, which could bring Iranian oil back, potentially offsetting Russian supply. This development has implications for funds like the Invesco DB Oil Fund (DBO), which tracks crude oil market value without direct commodity exposure.

title: Exxon Mobil plans to exit Russian operations following Ukraine invasion
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced its plan to exit operations in Russia, including its stake and operator position in the Sakhalin-1 oil field, and reverse future investments in the country. This decision comes in response to the Ukraine invasion, with the company's Russian assets valued at over $4 billion.

title: Chevron CEO points to 'difficult decisions' by competitors to leave Russia
summary: Chevron CEO Michael Wirth expressed concern over the situation in Ukraine, acknowledging the difficult decisions competitors made regarding operations in Russia. He highlighted Chevron's limited exposure to Russia and emphasized the importance of the Caspian Pipeline Consortium for world oil supply. Wirth also discussed increasing cybersecurity spending and plans for Chevron to boost oil output in the Permian shale basin and Kazakhstan.

title: Exxon to Shut Down Oil Production in Russia After Ukraine Attack
authors: Christopher M. Matthews and Jenny Strasburg
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced it is halting operations at a multibillion-dollar oil and gas project in Russia and will cease further investments in the country due to its invasion of Ukraine. The U.S. oil giant is preparing to shut down production from the Sakhalin Island development, where it holds a 30% stake alongside Russian, Japanese, and Indian partners, and plans to exit the consortium. This decision follows similar moves by other major energy companies like BP and Shell.

title: Exxon Mobil to exit major Russian venture, will not invest in new developments
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced it is halting operations of its Sakhalin-1 oil and gas venture in Russia and taking steps to exit the project. This decision comes in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Exxon Mobil stated its support for the people of Ukraine, deplored Russia’s military action, and affirmed compliance with all sanctions.

title: The Energy Sector: 6 Things To Know
summary: This article discusses the energy sector, highlighting its evolving nature beyond traditional oil and gas to include clean energy sources. It emphasizes the sector's continued ties to oil prices, especially in light of geopolitical events like the Russia-Ukraine crisis, and explores various investment avenues, including individual stocks, ETFs, and both traditional and renewable energy options.

title: Exxon Texas refinery lockout to end on March 7
summary: Exxon Mobil announced that a 10-month lockout of union workers at its southeast Texas refinery will end on March 7, following the United Steelworkers union's acceptance of a return-to-work agreement. The agreement allows nearly 600 locked-out workers to return, after a new six-year contract was ratified that gives Exxon control over job assignments. The union's long-term presence at the refinery remains subject to a pending NLRB investigation regarding the lockout and a vote to remove the union.

title: bp to exit Rosneft shareholding | News and insights | Home
summary: BP announced its decision to exit its 19.75% shareholding in Rosneft due to Russia's aggression against Ukraine. Both BP-nominated directors, Bernard Looney and Bob Dudley, will resign from Rosneft's board, leading to a material non-cash charge in BP's Q1 2022 results. BP's financial framework and distribution guidance remain unchanged, but it will no longer report Rosneft's results.

title: Oil companies, union reach deal on U.S. refinery workers pact
summary: Oil companies, led by Marathon Petroleum, and the United Steelworkers union have reached a new national contract for 30,000 U.S. refinery, chemical plant, and pipeline workers. The four-year agreement includes a 12% pay increase and provisions for union health and safety representatives at each facility. Negotiations stalled earlier but resumed after union protests, leading to the new agreement.

title: Exxon, union reach tentative return-to-work deal for locked-out refinery workers -sources
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp and the United Steelworkers union (USW) have reached a tentative agreement for nearly 600 workers locked out of a Beaumont, Texas, refinery to return to work starting in March. The USW Local 13-243 is scheduled to vote on the agreement, which would end the lockout that began in May 2021. The agreement outlines the return of workers while an investigation by the U.S. National Labor Relations Board into alleged unfair labor practices continues.

title: Where are Houston’s Fortune 500 companies? Downtown still reigns.
summary: Downtown Houston remains the primary location for Fortune 500 companies, housing ten of the 25 located in the greater Houston area. North Houston has recently gained two major Fortune 500 headquarters with Exxon Mobil and Hewlett Packard Enterprise relocating there, while other concentrations of these companies are found in West Houston, Energy Corridor, Memorial City, Katy, and the Galleria area. The article details the specific companies and their locations, highlighting the diverse geographical distribution of Houston's top businesses.

title: Over the Hedge: The Best Commodities To Invest in
summary: This article explores the best commodities to invest in, including energy, metals, and agriculture, as a hedge against inflation and stock market volatility. It delves into the pros and cons of commodity investing, specific opportunities within each category like oil & gas, lithium, gold, copper, silver, palladium, hemp, and coffee, and various methods for gaining exposure to these markets. The author emphasizes diversification and understanding market factors, geopolitical risks, and extraneous events like weather.

title: Exxon's workforce falls by 9,000 in 2021 amid cost cuts
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced a reduction of 9,000 global employees in 2021 as a result of a comprehensive cost-cutting program initiated after the COVID-19 pandemic. This workforce reduction contributed to the company's best annual profit in seven years in 2021, following a historic loss in 2020. The company plans further restructuring, including combining refining and chemicals businesses and cutting $6 billion from operating costs by next year.

title: Iraq to develop oil and gas in the Western Desert in collaboration with Halliburton Co., Saudi Aramco
summary: Iraq plans to collaborate with Halliburton Co. and Saudi Aramco to develop oil and gas reserves in its Western Desert, specifically in the Anbar province and the Akkas natural gas field. This initiative aims to reduce Iraq's dependence on oil for electricity and achieve gas self-sufficiency by 2025. The Iraqi government will cover development costs, with potential investment from Saudi Aramco.

title: Opinion: As the stock market struggles, look at these ‘hard-asset’ commodity funds
summary: Amidst stock market struggles and escalating geopolitical tensions, "hard-asset" commodity funds are presented as a potential haven for investors. These assets, including metals, fossil fuels, and agricultural goods, are benefiting from inflationary pressures and offer a degree of stability compared to more volatile investments like small-cap growth stocks or cryptocurrencies. The article suggests that these funds could be a strategic investment during periods of market uncertainty.

title: Newpark Resources settles conflict with activist investor, expands board
summary: Newpark Resources has settled a conflict with activist investor Brad Radoff, who had advocated for the company to sell off its fluid systems business. As part of the agreement, Newpark Resources will expand its board. Radoff's main concern was that the fluid systems business, which primarily serves the upstream oil and gas industry, did not turn a profit in 2021.

title: Texas oil refinery workers ratify Exxon labor contract offer
summary: Unionized workers at Exxon Mobil's Beaumont, Texas, refinery voted to accept a new labor contract, ending a nearly 10-month lockout. The new agreement grants Exxon the right to determine plant assignments, a key company demand, and adds Martin Luther King Jr. Day as a paid holiday. Despite the contract's approval, the United Steelworkers union plans to continue pursuing an unfair labor practices complaint against Exxon.

title: Marathon Petroleum Corp: What are oil workers fighting against?
summary: This article details the struggles of US oil refinery workers against Marathon Petroleum Corp. and the United Steelworkers union. It highlights Marathon's substantial profits, the impact of federal bailouts and layoffs on workers, and the demand for a nationwide refinery strike amidst stagnant wage offers and ongoing exploitation.

title: The Top Carbon ETF’s of 2022: Investing Ideas for Canadians
summary: This article identifies the top carbon ETFs for Canadian investors in 2022, highlighting newly available options on Canadian exchanges like Horizons Carbon Credits ETF (CARB) and Ninepoint Carbon Credit ETF (CBON). It also discusses the U.S.-based KraneShares Global Carbon Strategy ETF (KRBN) and Carbon Streaming Corporation (NETZ) as significant investments in the carbon market. The piece emphasizes the growing accessibility of carbon-related investments due to global decarbonization efforts.

title: Roy Fuller Obituary - Dallas, TX
summary: Roy Lee Fuller, born March 25, 1927, passed away peacefully on February 20, 2022, at the age of 94. He had a notable career trajectory from Geophysical Services Inc. (GSI) to Texas Instruments, followed by an energetic retirement involving hardware store ownership, chamber of commerce leadership, and rural land investments. Fuller, a veteran of WWII and a gifted musician, is survived by his wife Pat, children, stepchildren, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren.

title: Skadden, Kirkland lead DuPont’s $11 bln sale of unit to Celanese
summary: DuPont has engaged Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom for its $11 billion sale of its mobility and materials business to Celanese Corp. Celanese, in turn, is being advised by Kirkland & Ellis and Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher for the acquisition and its financing. This deal marks DuPont's largest transaction since its separation from DowDuPont, as it continues to streamline its portfolio.

title: Hubba Hubba: Appalachia Sees Continued Investment in Carbon Capture and Storage
summary: Appalachia is seeing continued investment in carbon capture and storage (CCS) with a new hydrogen and carbon capture hub planned for Ohio, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia by a coalition of major energy, petrochemical, and steel companies. This initiative aims to reduce emissions across various industries, create jobs, and drive innovation, modeling an integrated low-emission energy and production system. The region's abundant natural gas resources are key to producing blue hydrogen, a process that separates hydrogen from natural gas with the resulting carbon dioxide stored underground, showcasing Appalachia's role in a lower carbon future.

title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise set to move into its new global headquarters in Spring
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is opening its new global headquarters in Spring, north of Houston, as construction on its 440,000 square-foot campus wraps up. Employees have begun voluntarily moving into the space, which is expected to serve as a collaborative cultural center for its 2,200 Houston-area employees. This move from California, announced in December 2020, solidifies City Place as a growing corporate hub with significant ongoing residential and commercial development.

title: ConocoPhillips considers sale of $1bn worth of Permian basin assets in US
summary: ConocoPhillips is reportedly considering selling over $1 billion worth of its assets in the Permian Basin, specifically in the Delaware region of West Texas and New Mexico. This move follows its $9.5 billion acquisition of Shell's Permian operations in late 2021 and is part of a strategy to high-grade its portfolio and raise between $4 billion and $5 billion through asset sales by 2023. The divestment comes as global oil and gas companies seek to reduce debt and capitalize on surging oil prices.

title: Exxon Mobil expands oil futures, products trading in Europe
summary: Exxon Mobil is reinvesting in its European oil trading division after previous budget cuts and an exodus of staff, with new hires and an expansion into speculative oil futures trading beyond hedging its own production. This move follows the company's biggest profit in seven years during the fourth quarter of 2021.

title: ConocoPhillips to weigh $1 billion Permian assets sale
summary: ConocoPhillips is considering selling over $1 billion in Permian Basin assets, working with an adviser to run an auction process. This potential sale follows its $9.5 billion acquisition of Shell's Permian operations and aligns with its strategy to high-grade its asset base and return cash to shareholders, encouraged by surging oil prices. The company had previously raised its asset sale target to between $4 billion and $5 billion by 2023, with proceeds expected primarily from the Permian Basin.

title: Singapore Airlines to buy ExxonMobil's sustainable fuel in push to cut emissions
summary: Singapore Airlines, with support from Singapore's civil aviation authority and Temasek, will purchase sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from Exxon Mobil Corp for a year-long pilot program. This initiative aims to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by approximately 2,500 tonnes, using 1.25 million litres of neat SAF supplied by Neste Oyj and blended at Exxon Mobil's facilities in Singapore. The move reflects efforts to make air travel more environmentally friendly by leveraging SAF, which produces significantly less carbon than traditional fossil fuels.

title: Civitas Grabs Bigger DJ Foothold with Takeover of Bison Oil
summary: Civitas Resources Inc., the largest oil and natural gas producer in the Denver-Julesburg Basin, has acquired Bison Oil & Gas II LLC in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $346 million. This acquisition will add 102 gross locations and increase Civitas' production by 9,000 boe/d, further solidifying its dominant position in the DJ Basin. The transaction involves Bison's private equity sponsor, Carnelian Energy Capital, receiving 2.3 million shares of Civitas and $45 million cash, with Civitas assuming $176 million of Bison's debt.

title: Exxon Mobil, LyondellBasell, others partner with city of Houston to boost plastic recycling
summary: Exxon Mobil, LyondellBasell, and other partners are collaborating with the city of Houston to enhance plastic recycling efforts. This initiative aims to increase the supply of plastic feedstock for ExxonMobil's Baytown facility, diverting plastic from landfills and into recycling streams. Dave Andrew of ExxonMobil Chemical Co. highlights that the main challenge is access to plastic feed, not investment.

title: Shell (SHEL) Stock Price, News & Analysis
summary: This article provides a detailed analysis of Shell (NYSE: SHEL) stock, covering its current price, key statistics, company overview, analyst ratings, earnings, valuation, dividend information, and recent news. It highlights Shell's position as a global integrated energy company focusing on both traditional hydrocarbons and developing lower-carbon solutions, emphasizing its "Moderate Buy" consensus rating and a 4.06% dividend yield. The report also includes FAQs about share performance, earnings, buybacks, subsidiaries, major shareholders, and how to buy shares.

title: Oil tops $90, 7-year high
summary: U.S. crude oil surged past $90 per barrel, reaching a 7-year high, with Brent crude hitting $91 per barrel. This rise comes as OPEC declined requests to increase production and national average gas prices hit $3.41 per gallon, leading some experts to predict a potential rise to $4. Geopolitical tensions between Russia and Ukraine are also contributing to the price pressure.

title: Oil companies, union to continue talks on worker contract
summary: Negotiators for major oil companies and the United Steelworkers union met but failed to reach an agreement on a new labor contract covering 30,000 U.S. workers. Both sides agreed to continue talks at a later date, with the union having rejected a 9% pay raise offer over three years. This comes after the union and Marathon Petroleum averted a potential strike by agreeing to a 24-hour extension of the existing contract.

title: Exxon Mobil restructures into three divisions and packs up for Houston
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. is relocating its corporate headquarters from suburban Dallas to the Houston area by mid-2023 and reorganizing into three main business lines: upstream, product solutions, and low-carbon. This major shake-up aims to reduce costs, with the company on track for $6 billion in savings by 2023. This reorganization will bring top executives to the company's Houston-area campus, fostering closer collaboration and a streamlined business model.

title: Exxon moves headquarters, reorganizes company
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced a reorganization and plans to move its headquarters to Spring, Texas, near Houston, to streamline operations and cut costs. The revamp includes making its low-carbon division one of its three main business lines and aims to save the company $6 billion compared to 2019. This move follows pressure from a hedge fund to focus on new forms of energy.

title: Exxon to move HQ to Houston, merge refining and chemicals
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced it will relocate its corporate headquarters from suburban Dallas to the Houston area by mid-2023, combining its chemical and refining divisions. This move is part of a broader shake-up aimed at reducing costs, reorganizing the company into three main business lines, and accelerating its cost-cutting drive to achieve $6 billion in savings by 2023. The reorganization seeks to enhance collaboration and shareholder value through the energy transition.

title: Darling Ingredients VP Melissa Gaither to Retire and Suann Guthrie to Succeed
summary: Darling Ingredients Inc. announced that Melissa Gaither, Vice President of Investor Relations, Sustainability, and Global Communications, will retire on April 29 after 33 years of service. Suann Guthrie has been named as her successor, effective January 31, bringing over 20 years of experience in strategy development, media, investor relations, and corporate communications from the tech and energy sectors.

title: Exxon Mobil to move headquarters out of Irving
summary: Exxon Mobil is moving its corporate headquarters from Irving to Houston, a decision announced as part of the company's plan to streamline its business structure by combining its chemical and downstream operations. This move means that North Texas will lose its second-largest public company upon completion next year.

title: ExxonMobil Exiting Irving HQ for Houston Megacampus
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced it will be moving its corporate headquarters from Irving, Texas, to its megacampus in the Houston area as part of a larger business restructuring. The relocation is anticipated to be finished by mid-2023. The Houston campus spans 385 acres and previously housed over 10,000 Exxon employees.

title: Chevron kicks off oil industry's Q4 results with a miss
summary: Chevron (CVX.N) reported fourth-quarter profits that missed Wall Street estimates and provided a weak outlook for this year's oil and gas production, causing its shares to drop. The company's earnings of $2.65 per share were below the $3.12 per share forecast, largely due to weaker output, downstream margins, and a hit from timing of bookings in its LNG business. Despite this, Chevron achieved its best annual earnings since 2014, driven by spending cuts, and announced increased shareholder returns including a share buyback and a dividend hike.

title: Chevron shares touch record high ahead of Q4 results
summary: Shares of U.S. oil major Chevron Corp touched an all-time high intraday on Wednesday, boosted by a strong stock market rally and rising oil prices, ahead of its fourth-quarter financial results. Oil prices reached $90 a barrel for the first time in seven years, leading to a surge in major producers' stocks. Analysts anticipate Chevron to report earnings per share of $3.12 for the fourth quarter.

title: Why the Sustainable Investment Craze Is Flawed - WSJ
summary: This article questions the effectiveness of sustainable investments (ESG funds) in truly making the world a better place, despite claims from the financial industry and the large sums of money flowing into them. The author argues that selling off "dirty" assets often just shifts ownership without reducing environmental impact, and that the rise of private capital without public reporting exacerbates this issue. This is the first in a series of columns exploring the flaws and potential solutions within ESG investing.

title: $10B Exxon-SABIC JV petrochemical plant near Corpus Christi starts operations
summary: Exxon Mobil and SABIC announced the start-up of their $10 billion Gulf Coast Growth Ventures petrochemical plant near Corpus Christi, Texas, in December. The plant features the world's largest ethane steam cracker, capable of producing 1.8 million metric tons of ethylene annually. This joint venture represents a significant new addition to the South Texas petrochemical industry.

title: Imperial Oil to reduce 30 per cent oil sands emission intensity by 2030
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd (IMO-T) plans to cut greenhouse gas emissions intensity from its oil sands operations by 30% by 2030, compared to 2016 levels, through new technologies, efficiency improvements, and carbon capture. The Calgary-based company also affirmed its goal of achieving net-zero Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions in its oil sands operations by 2050, aligning with other Canadian oil sands producers and majority owner Exxon Mobil's similar pledges.

title: Transocean's Offshore Drilling Rig to Drill Carbon Injection Well in Norway
summary: Transocean's drilling rig, the Transocean Enabler, will be used by Equinor to drill a carbon injection well in Norway for the Northern Lights Carbon Capture Storage Project. This project is a joint venture by Equinor, Shell, and TotalEnergies, aiming to establish Europe's first cross-border CO2 transport and storage network to mitigate emissions. Transocean highlighted its participation as an example of leveraging its core competencies for renewable and alternative energy projects.

title: Beyond Local: Imperial Oil continues to innovate bitumen extraction while reducing environmental impact
summary: Imperial Oil is advancing its bitumen extraction methods at its Cold Lake Operations to improve environmental performance. The company is implementing technologies like LASER and SA-SAGD to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and water usage, with the first phase of the SA-SAGD expansion project expected to produce 15,000 barrels per day by 2023. These innovations aim to increase efficiency and reduce the environmental impact of heavy oil recovery.

title: Exxon plans to shut Baytown, Texas, crude unit by late next week -sources
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp plans to shut down the 135,000-bpd Pipestill-7 crude distillation unit (CDU) at its Baytown, Texas refinery by late next week for a planned overhaul. This comes as the refinery, Exxon's largest in the U.S., continues to operate at reduced levels following a December 23 explosion.

title: DI People: JCPenney, 7-Eleven, Recode Therapeutics, Hawkeye, PCCI, and Others Make Moves
summary: This article details numerous executive appointments and promotions across various companies in North Texas, including JCPenney, 7-Eleven, Recode Therapeutics, Hawkeye, and PwC. Key moves include new CEOs for Hawkeye, Harver, and Recode Therapeutics, and significant leadership changes in e-commerce, technology, and operations at other notable firms, reflecting a dynamic period of innovation and growth in the region.

title: W&T Offshore expands in Gulf of Mexico with $47M acquisition
summary: W&T Offshore is expanding its operations in the Gulf of Mexico through a new $47 million acquisition. CEO Tracy Krohn stated that the current environment for acquisitions in the Gulf remains favorable. This move highlights the company's continued investment and growth strategy in the region.

title: AT&T Shares Deserve a Return Call
summary: AT&T is considered significantly undervalued despite an expected dividend cut, offering an attractive yield after refocusing on its core communications business. The planned spin-off of WarnerMedia into Warner Bros. Discovery provides shareholders with shares in a new media company while allowing AT&T to invest heavily in its wireless and fixed-line networks. Investors relying on the current dividend may be disappointed, but the strategic shifts position the company for future growth and a competitive dividend yield even post-cut.

title: Exxon, Imperial Oil to market up to $1 billion in Canadian assets
summary: Exxon Mobil and its affiliate Imperial Oil Ltd are planning to sell shale oil and gas properties in Western Canada, which could fetch between $500 million and $1 billion. This divestiture would make oil sands their largest Canadian onshore production business and is part of a broader effort by Exxon to sell smaller operations to pay down debt. XTO Energy Canada, jointly owned by Exxon and Imperial Oil, currently pumps about 9,000 barrels of liquids and 140 million cubic feet of natural gas per day in Canada.

title: EXCLUSIVE Exxon Mobil launches sale of U.S. shale gas properties -marketing document
summary: Exxon Mobil is selling shale gas properties spanning 27,000 acres in Ohio's Appalachian basin, including 61 wells that produced approximately 81 million cubic feet per day of natural gas last year. This divestment is part of an ongoing effort to sell U.S. assets and could value the properties at around $200 million. The company is focusing its development on brighter prospects in Guyana, offshore Brazil, and Texas's Permian Basin.

title: Commodities Notched Their Best Year Since 2009, Despite Precious Metals Weakness
summary: Commodities experienced their best year since 2009, with the Bloomberg Commodity Spot Index gaining 27% in 2021, driven largely by energy prices. Precious metals, however, were the worst-performing category, with gold down 3.6% blamed on expectations of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates. The article highlights the resurgence of fossil fuels due to increased demand and discusses various market trends across emerging markets, energy, and digital currencies.

title: Insight: Harmful soot unchecked as Big Oil battles EPA over testing
summary: A deadly form of soot pollution from U.S. refineries, known as condensable fine particulate matter, has gone unregulated for decades due to a dispute between the U.S. oil industry and federal environmental officials over measurement methods. This delay has led to significant unchecked emissions, with regional regulators in California attempting to crack down, sparking litigation from oil refiners like Chevron Corp and PBF Energy Inc. The EPA acknowledges issues with its current testing method but continues research, while environmental scientists warn against further delays in regulation.

title: 3 ConocoPhillips Trades As Energy Prices Rise And Stock Sees Multi-Year Highs
summary: ConocoPhillips (NYSE: COP) shares have surged by more than 90% since early 2021, fueled by rising energy prices and optimistic OPEC+ announcements. The article details potential investment strategies for COP, including buying dips, considering energy ETFs, or utilizing cash-secured put options for those anticipating continued highs. Analysts generally rate COP as "outperform" with a significant upside, despite potential short-term volatility around upcoming earnings and OPEC+ meetings.

title: Iraq to acquire Exxon Mobil's stake in West Qurna oilfield -minister
summary: The Iraqi government has approved the Iraqi National Oil Company's acquisition of Exxon Mobil Corp's stake in the West Qurna 1 oilfield. This decision follows Exxon's reported intention to sell its 32.7% stake for $350 million. The West Qurna 1 field is a significant asset in southern Iraq, boasting over 20 billion barrels of recoverable reserves.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Exxon Escalates Dispute With Russia Over Barred Exit From Giant Oil Project
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has notified Russian officials of its intent to sue the government unless it is allowed to exit the Sakhalin-1 oil-and-gas project. A Kremlin decree from early August has barred Exxon from transferring operatorship and selling its 30% stake, despite the company's prior efforts to transition operations following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Exxon considers Russia's actions a violation of its rights and an impediment to a safe exit from the project.

title: Four injured in fire at Exxon's Baytown, Texas, oil refinery
summary: A fire at Exxon Mobil Corp's Baytown, Texas, refinery complex injured four contract workers, two of whom remain hospitalized in stable condition. The blaze, which erupted in a hydrotreater unit, has been extinguished, and its cause is under investigation. The Baytown facility is one of the largest refining and petrochemical facilities in the United States.

title: Nigeria Overhauls Its Oil and Gas Laws with Petroleum Industry Act – Publications
summary: Nigeria has passed the Petroleum Industry Act (PIA) to overhaul its oil and gas laws, aiming to foster a business-friendly environment and make its economy gas-powered by 2030. The PIA introduces significant reforms in governance, upstream operations, gas exploitation, fiscal regimes, and host community protection. These changes are designed to adapt to global energy transitions while addressing the economic prospects of oil-producing regions.

title: Iraq says Halliburton, Exxon in talks for stake in oil field
summary: Iraq's energy minister stated that Halliburton Co. and Exxon Mobil Corp. are discussing Exxon's sale of its stake in the West Qurna-1 oil field. Iraq prefers a U.S. partner for Exxon's stake but would buy it through Basra Oil Co. if talks with Halliburton fail. The article also mentions current OPEC+ production plans and Chevron's potential investment in southern Iraq.

title: Halliburton Denies It’s Vying for Exxon’s Stake in Iraq Field
authors: Khalid Al Ansary and David Wethe
summary: Halliburton Co. denied claims by Iraq’s oil minister that it is in talks to acquire Exxon Mobil Corp.’s stake in the West Qurna-1 oil field. A Halliburton spokeswoman stated that the company is not buying oil fields and that previous discussions about providing services to a potential buyer have ceased. This comes amidst ongoing uncertainty regarding the future ownership of the significant oil asset.

title: ICE says new Midland WTI futures contract to go live in late January
summary: Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) announced its new Midland WTI American Gulf Coast futures contract will go live in late January, aiming to create a new U.S. light sweet index reflecting crude exports. This contract is a restructuring of the ICE Permian WTI crude oil futures, designed to offer greater liquidity and stability following the historic collapse of WTI futures in 2020. It includes oil from Enterprise's ECHO terminal and Magellan Houston terminal, significantly increasing the underpinning supply capacity.

title: DC’s United Bank completes 33rd acquisition
summary: United Bankshares, Inc. has completed its 33rd acquisition, purchasing Richmond, Virginia-based Community Bankers Trust for $303 million, including its subsidiary Essex Bank. This acquisition expands United Bank's footprint into new markets like Baltimore and Annapolis and increases its assets to $29 billion with nearly 250 offices. The deal makes United Bank the 41st largest banking company in the U.S. by market capitalization.

title: Expect Midstream Industry to Continue Growth in 2022
summary: North American midstream companies are projected to continue growing in 2022 due to economic recovery, increased activity, and constructive commodity prices, according to Fitch Ratings. The industry has seen strong free cash flow, enabling debt reduction and balance sheet improvement. Investors can gain exposure to this growth through the Alerian Energy Infrastructure ETF (ENFR), which tracks midstream energy companies involved in storage, pipeline transportation, and processing.

title: ConocoPhillips buys Shell’s Permian business for $9.5bn
summary: ConocoPhillips has acquired Shell's Permian Basin assets in the US for $9.5 billion, encompassing 225,000 net acres and producing properties. This acquisition is expected to improve ConocoPhillips' business drivers, enhance cash flow, and lower its GHG intensity. Shell plans to use the proceeds primarily for shareholder distributions and balance sheet strengthening.

title: New York Utilities Polarize Over Push to Ban Natural Gas
summary: A proposed ban on natural gas hook-ups in new New York City buildings has created a divide among utilities, with Con Edison supporting the ban while others, like National Grid and Buffalo-based National Fuel, resist it. ConEd's support stems from seeing electrification as an opportunity for combined gas and electric utilities, though it still has ties to gas infrastructure. The article highlights the broader national struggle between cities pushing for decarbonization and gas companies lobbying against such measures, particularly in states like Pennsylvania.

title: Halliburton says not buying Exxon stake in Iraqi oilfield
summary: Halliburton has denied claims by a senior official from Iraq's Basra Oil Co. that it proposed buying Exxon Mobil's stake in the West Qurna 1 oilfield. Halliburton spokesperson Emily Mir explicitly stated the company is not acquiring or partnering to acquire any oil fields. Meanwhile, Iraq plans to upgrade its oil export infrastructure to boost capacity to six million barrels per day by 2025.

title: John Richard Hall Obituary
summary: John Richard Hall, retired Chairman and CEO of Ashland Inc., passed away on November 25, 2021, at the age of 88. He was recognized for his integrity, strong leadership during crises, and his significant contributions to education and various corporate and philanthropic boards. His career at Ashland spanned 40 years, where he implemented the company's first Code of Business Conduct and successfully guided it through profitability and a hostile takeover attempt.

title: Chevron shuts Australian Gorgon LNG Train 1 after minor gas leak
summary: Chevron has idled Train 1 at its Gorgon liquefied natural gas (LNG) plant in Western Australia following the discovery of a minor gas leak. The leak, located on piping associated with the dehydration unit, prompted a precautionary shutdown, though the company continues to deliver LNG from Trains 2 and 3 and gas to Western Australia. It is currently unclear how long the unit will remain down for investigation and repairs.

title: Phillips 66 Converting Louisiana Refinery
summary: Phillips 66 announced plans to convert its Alliance Refinery in Belle Chasse, Louisiana, to a terminal facility in 2022. This decision was made after evaluating repair costs following Hurricane Ida and considering the site's value as a midstream asset. The conversion will impact approximately 900 employees and contractors, and Phillips 66 plans to support them through the transition while maintaining its role as a major refiner.

title: ExxonMobil 'Back on Track' to Meet Target to Double Earnings -CEO
summary: ExxonMobil CEO Darren Woods stated that the company is confident it will achieve its 2018 target to double earnings and cash flow by 2025 (initially pushed to 2027), attributing this to recent cost-cutting and higher energy prices. Woods also emphasized that the pace of the energy transition to cleaner fuels is a decision for consumers and governments, not oil producers.

title: EOG Eyeing ‘Incredible Value’ for LNG Exports from Permian, Eagle Ford and Dorado
summary: EOG Resources Inc. plans to focus on returning value to shareholders rather than boosting production volumes, despite higher commodity prices. The company sees "incredible value" in exporting natural gas as LNG from its Permian, Eagle Ford Shale, and Dorado assets, and is also piloting a carbon capture and storage venture to reduce emissions. EOG reported sharply higher profits and production in 3Q2021, increased its dividend, and approved share repurchases.

title: NextEra Energy Stock Forecast: Sunny and Windy
summary: This article provides an in-depth forecast for NextEra Energy (NEE), positioning it as a leading renewable energy stock that offers both growth and dividend income. It highlights NextEra Energy's dual business model as the world's largest utility company (FPL) and largest generator of renewable energy (NextEra Energy Resources), and discusses how it stands to benefit from the $1.2 Trillion Infrastructure Bill and global shifts towards nuclear and wind energy. The article also benchmarks NEE's performance against various indices, concluding that its future looks bright given current market and political landscapes.

title: Oil prices are up, but do not expect a gas-like crunch
summary: Oil prices are hovering above $80 per barrel due to OPEC+'s supply tightening, but a full-blown energy crisis is unlikely as economic growth is not strong enough to sustain high prices long-term. Despite the current tightening market and recovery in demand, the article argues that the primary driver of high oil prices is OPEC+'s political decision to restrict production rather than robust, sustained economic expansion. The abundance of OPEC spare capacity suggests that a "gas-like crunch" is not imminent, as long-term price developments hinge on true economic growth rather than temporary stimulus-driven recovery.

title: Speakers see opportunities in energy transition
summary: Speakers at the Executive Oil Conference in Midland, Texas, assert that oil and gas will be essential for decades, despite calls for a low-carbon future. ConocoPhillips and Devon Energy executives highlighted the Permian Basin's crucial role in U.S. energy production, emphasizing the need for technology and innovation to reduce emissions while meeting growing global energy demand, especially for populations experiencing energy poverty. They see opportunities in the energy transition for the industry and adjacent businesses.

title: Exxon warns some assets may be at risk for impairment due to climate change
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced that some of its oil and gas assets could face impairment due to climate change, a first such acknowledgment in a securities filing. The company's board, recently overhauled after a proxy battle, will now test assets for climate-related impairments as part of its annual review. This shift comes as Exxon plans to increase spending on carbon emission reduction technologies and faces pressure to address its climate strategy.

title: Phillips 66 to begin repairs next week on two units at shut Louisiana refinery -sources
summary: Phillips 66 plans to start repairs next week on a catalytic reformer and a hydrotreater at its storm-damaged Alliance, Louisiana, refinery, which has been shut since Hurricane Ida. Repairs for other major units, including the crude distillation unit and fluidic catalytic cracking unit, are slated for January. The company is also evaluating options for the refinery's future, including a potential sale or closure.

title: Howard Hughes, The Woodlands officials search for tenants to replace Exxon in Hughes Landing
summary: As ExxonMobil plans to vacate its offices in the Hughes Landing mixed-use district in The Woodlands, Howard Hughes and The Woodlands officials are actively seeking new tenants to fill the void. This move by Exxon will see its workers relocate to its main Houston-area campus, prompting a search for new companies to occupy the significant office space. The departure impacts The Woodlands' office market, necessitating efforts to attract different businesses to the area.

title: Oklahoma’s Harold Hamm among world’s richest oil men
summary: Harold Hamm of Continental Resources is ranked as the third richest oilman globally with a net worth of $14.8 billion, a significant increase of 191% in the past year. This increase is largely due to his company's shares soaring by 199.4%. Other notable Oklahomans on the billionaires list include Lynn Schusterman, known for her philanthropic efforts and energy investments, and Carl Icahn, an activist shareholder with investments in several energy companies.

title: These are the Fortune 500 companies that call Irving home
summary: Irving, Texas, is home to eight Fortune 500 company headquarters, with a total of 53 Fortune 500 companies maintaining offices in the city. The article highlights the reasons for Irving's appeal to corporations, such as its central location, amenities, and business-friendly policies. It then lists detailed information for each of the eight Fortune 500 companies headquartered in Irving, including their ranking, industry, number of employees, and revenue.

title: Argentina bets on natural gas despite climate commitments
summary: Argentina is prioritizing the expansion of natural gas production and its pipeline network from the Vaca Muerta fields, despite its climate commitments to reduce emissions. President Alberto Fernández's government views natural gas as a key fuel for energy transition and export, aiming to save money on imports and boost the economy. Environmental organizations, however, argue that these plans contradict emission reduction targets and could lead to stranded assets, while highlighting environmental and social risks for local communities.

title: ExxonMobil states non-union employees get higher pay at Beaumont refinery
summary: ExxonMobil informed locked-out union workers at its Beaumont, Texas, refinery that non-union employees at comparable sites receive 5% to 7% higher pay and similar benefits. This message comes ahead of a decertification vote for the United Steelworkers union Local 13-243, which represents 585 workers locked out since May 1. Exxon has stated the lockout will end if the union either accepts its proposed contract or is decertified, with the company aiming for changes to enhance competitiveness.

title: Robert Darnall Obituary (2021) - Englewood, FL - Chicago Tribune
summary: Robert J. Darnall, former Chairman and CEO of Inland Steel Industries, passed away at age 83. He had a distinguished career in the steel industry and served on numerous corporate and philanthropic boards, including the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. He is survived by his wife, Marletta, and their two children and grandchildren.

title: Oil and gas rally boosts Chevron's quarterly profit to 8-year high
summary: Chevron Corp reported its highest quarterly profit in eight years, reaching $6.11 billion, driven by surging oil and gas prices, increased output, and recovering motor fuel demand. The strong financial performance resulted in a significant increase in cash flow and boosted the company's shares. Chevron plans to continue its focus on oil production, adding drilling rigs and aiming for annual output increases through 2025.

title: Exxon posts strongest results since 2017, vows to resume share buybacks
summary: Exxon Mobil reported its strongest quarterly results since 2017, with net income of $6.75 billion, driven by surging fossil fuel demand and higher refining profits. The company announced plans to resume its share repurchase program in 2022, intending to spend up to $10 billion through 2023, while also increasing spending on carbon reduction initiatives. These developments follow a period of shareholder dissatisfaction and a successful proxy battle that led to new board members.

title: Eastman Chemical Co. stock outperforms market on strong trading day
summary: Eastman Chemical Co. stock (EMN) rose 4.25% to $110.04, outperforming the broader market indexes like the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average on a strong trading day. This rise ended a two-day losing streak for the company's shares. Eastman Chemical Co. also outperformed competitors such as Exxon Mobil Corp., 3M Co., and FMC Corp., with its trading volume exceeding its 50-day average.

title: Suncor doubles dividend as oil price surge powers profit
summary: Suncor Energy Inc doubled its dividend after posting a third-quarter profit, benefiting from a rebound in crude prices. The Canadian oil and gas producer generated strong free cash flow due to soaring energy prices and growing global fuel demand, reinstating its dividend to pre-pandemic levels. The company's production and refinery throughput also saw significant increases compared to the previous year.

title: Houston-based Hilcorp to operate Alaska gas field, taking over for Exxon Mobil
summary: Houston-based Hilcorp Energy Co. will take over operational responsibility for the Point Thomson field in Alaska, succeeding Exxon Mobil Corp. This move signifies another step in Hilcorp's expansion within Alaska.

title: Exxon Mobil keen to build carbon storage hubs in SE Asia, similar to Houston project
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp plans to establish carbon capture storage (CCS) hubs in Southeast Asia, mirroring its Houston project, and has initiated discussions with countries offering potential CO2 storage sites. The company identifies Singapore as a hub given its refining-petrochemical center, intending to transport captured CO2 to storage locations in countries like Indonesia and Malaysia, where significant CO2 storage capacity exists. For these projects to be viable, ExxonMobil emphasizes the necessity of a transparent carbon price across countries to attract investment and reduce emissions effectively.

title: Exxon Mobil reportedly to close 2 office towers in The Woodlands
summary: Exxon Mobil is reportedly closing two office towers in The Woodlands, moving approximately 1,400 employees to its main Houston-area campus. This move could impact the tax incentives Exxon Mobil was previously supposed to maintain by employing a certain number of workers in the Hughes Landing district. The relocation follows reports from Bloomberg.

title: Tsakos: A life in shipping
summary: Dr. Nikolas Tsakos, founder, CEO, and president of Tsakos Energy Navigation (TEN), discusses his life in shipping, the legacy of his family, and his vision for the future of the tanker industry. Despite a challenging year for tankers, Tsakos is optimistic about a comeback and emphasizes the importance of owner communication and sustainable practices, advocating for improved existing fuel infrastructure over radical new solutions for decarbonization. The article highlights his early career, the founding of TEN, and his views on industry challenges like decarbonization and the fragmentation of the tanker sector.

title: Marathon is committed to meet current, future needs
summary: Marathon Petroleum Corp. details its commitment to meeting today's energy demands while simultaneously investing in a sustainable and energy-diverse future, particularly at its Detroit refinery. The company highlights its efforts in emissions and water-use reduction, community engagement through grants and volunteer work, and investment in emerging technologies. This piece emphasizes the dual focus of providing current essential petroleum products and developing sustainable practices for the future.

title: Exxon board debates dropping several major oil and gas projects
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp's board is reportedly debating whether to proceed with several major oil and gas projects, including a $30 billion liquefied natural gas development in Mozambique and a multibillion-dollar gas project in Vietnam. This deliberation comes amid investor pressure for fossil fuel companies to prioritize cost-consciousness and green energy. The discussions are part of a review of Exxon's five-year spending plan, with a board vote expected at the end of the month.

title: TechnipFMC Third Quarter 2021 Earnings Call Presentation
summary: TechnipFMC announced the availability of its Third Quarter 2021 Earnings Call Presentation in connection with its teleconference scheduled for October 21, 2021. The presentation is accessible on the company's website. TechnipFMC, a leading technology provider in energy industries, also uses its website as a channel for distributing material company information.

title: Chad ExxonMobil Unit Shuts In Production Site Over Labor Dispute
summary: An Exxon Mobil Corp. unit in Chad temporarily ceased production due to an attack on its facilities stemming from a labor dispute. Workers are negotiating their remuneration package with Esso Exploration and Production Chad Inc. ahead of a planned sale of the business to Savannah Energy.

title: Exxon tells Texas refinery workers lockout will end if contract approved or union removed
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp informed workers at its Beaumont, Texas, refinery that their six-month lockout would end if they either ratified the company's contract offer or voted to remove the United Steelworkers union (USW) as their representative. Workers are scheduled to vote on the contract offer, while the U.S. National Labor Relations Board is reviewing a petition for a vote to decertify the USW Local 13-243. The USW has urged workers to reject the contract and has filed a complaint alleging the lockout's purpose is to remove the union.

title: P&G dogged by controversy on forests, human rights at annual meeting for third year in a row
summary: Environmental advocacy groups protested Procter & Gamble's annual general meeting for the third consecutive year, raising concerns about the company's supply chain issues, particularly its sourcing of pulp from Canadian boreal forests and palm oil from Indonesian and Malaysian tropical forests. Activists called for greater accountability regarding forest destruction, human rights, and climate change, with shareholders voting to keep board member Angela Braly despite pushback. The groups emphasize that pressure on P&G will continue until substantial improvements are made in its sourcing practices and policy.

title: Exxon says union removal vote to go forward at Texas refinery hit by lockout
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced that a vote to remove the United Steelworkers union (USW) from its Beaumont, Texas, refinery will proceed regardless of an upcoming contract ratification vote by locked-out workers. The USW sees the contract vote and the decertification vote as separate issues, while Exxon maintains the decertification process will continue as per NLRB guidelines. The union has filed a complaint against Exxon with the NLRB regarding the decertification materials.

title: First Fully Automated Land Rig Drills First Well
summary: Nabors Industries Ltd. announced that the world's first fully automated land drilling rig, PACE®-R801, successfully drilled its first well for ExxonMobil in the Permian basin, reaching a total measured depth of 19,917 feet. This rig combines Nabors' Smart Suite software with Canrig® robotics, aiming for enhanced safety, efficiency, and environmental performance with a crew primarily focused on supervision, service, and maintenance. ExxonMobil lauded the collaboration as a step towards optimizing drilling through advanced technologies.

title: Chevron commits to net zero operational emissions by 2050
summary: Chevron Corp (CVX.N) has announced a target to achieve net zero operational emissions by 2050, aligning with increasing pressure from investors and governments on energy companies to combat climate change. This commitment focuses on upstream and indirect emissions from its own operations. Unlike some European peers, Chevron's goals do not include greenhouse gases from all fuel products sold, but it plans to pivot towards low-carbon businesses and triple investments to reduce its carbon footprint.

title: BW Energy Gets Hold of Two Offshore Blocks in Gabon
summary: BW Energy has been provisionally awarded operatorship of two offshore blocks, G12-13 and H12-13, in Gabon's 12th Offshore Licensing Round, pending finalization of production sharing contracts. These blocks are adjacent to BW Energy's existing Dussafu licence and will be operated by BW Energy (37.5%) in a consortium with VAALCO Energy (37.5%) and Panoro Energy (25%). The consortium plans to drill exploration wells and conduct 3D seismic acquisition, aiming to leverage existing infrastructure for potential rapid value creation.

title: Exclusive Analysis: In U.S. TV Ads, Chevron Motors Past Its Big Oil Competition in Boasting of Sustainability Accolades
summary: Chevron significantly outspent its major oil competitors (BP, Exxon Mobil, Shell) in U.S. television advertising between June 2020 and August 2021, airing nearly 30,000 ads focused heavily on sustainability. While other companies aired far fewer ads or focused on traditional oil and gas messaging, 80% of Chevron's airings featured sustainability-focused language, despite external skepticism about the industry's green transition claims. This advertising strategy contrasts with its competitors' more limited or product-focused ad campaigns during the same period.

title: Nabors Announces World's First Fully Automated Land Rig Has Successfully Drilled Its First Well
summary: Nabors Industries Ltd. announced that its PACE®-R801, the world's first fully automated land drilling rig, successfully drilled its first horizontal well for ExxonMobil in the Permian Basin. This rig combines proprietary automated drilling software with robotics to create an unmanned rig floor, enhancing safety, efficiency, and environmental performance. The technology showcased in PACE®-R801 aims to drive the next wave of performance gains in the energy industry, with insights gained informing future innovations.

title: How to Invest in Companies That Are Actually Helping the Environment
summary: ESG funds have gained popularity as investors seek to align their money with environmental concerns, but their effectiveness is debated due to broad definitions and limited regulation. This article explores how to identify truly sustainable investments, highlighting the vetting processes of fund managers and criteria for companies genuinely commitmed to environmental progress, urging investors to scrutinize reports and core business practices.

title: Exxon offers new proposal to locked-out Texas refinery workers
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp offered a new contract proposal to its locked-out refinery workers in Beaumont, Texas, including some seniority protection. However, leaders of the United Steelworkers union local 13-243 stated that the offer still falls short, arguing that key proposals detrimental to workers' safety, seniority, and security remain. If ratified by November 1st, workers would receive a $500 bonus.

title: Cheniere Energy's Sabine Pass Train 6 closer to service
summary: Cheniere Energy's Sabine Pass Train 6 is moving closer to operation after the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved the introduction of feed gas. The liquefied natural gas unit is now expected to come online in the first quarter of next year, earlier than initially anticipated. Cheniere also recently announced its first stock dividend of 33 cents per share, payable on November 17.

title: Exxon, Chevron conceal payments to some governments -watchdog
summary: U.S. oil majors Exxon Mobil Corp and Chevron Corp have reportedly failed to meet a core transparency standard set by the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI), a global anti-corruption body. EITI stated that these companies have declined to publicly disclose payments made to governments in countries that are not EITI members, despite having board seats on the organization. This lack of transparency contrasts with European-based oil companies like BP, Shell, and Total, which do disclose such payments.

title: As energy transition plays out, Shell exits Permian with $9.5 bln sale to ConocoPhillips
summary: Shell is selling its Permian Basin business for $9.5 billion in cash to ConocoPhillips as part of its strategy to shift towards renewable energy and meet its net-zero goals. ConocoPhillips will acquire 225k net acres with a current production of 175 thousand barrels equivalent per day, aiming to enhance its role in the energy transition with lower GHG intensity barrels and increasing its dividend. The deal, expected to close in Q4 2021, allows Shell to fund shareholder distributions and strengthen its balance sheet, while ConocoPhillips increases its divestment targets to help finance the acquisition.

title: Why We’re Bullish on Russia and Eastern Europe Right Now
summary: This article outlines why Russia and Eastern Europe, particularly the CEE region, present a bullish investment opportunity. It highlights Russia's positive real rates, strong oil and gas prices bolstering its economy, and its stock market's outperformance against the S&P 500, along with attractive valuations and dividend yields. The broader CEE region, including Poland, is also noted for its sustained growth and shared characteristics with other emerging markets.

title: Shell exits Permian with $9.5 bln Texas shale sale to ConocoPhillips
summary: Royal Dutch Shell announced the sale of its Permian Basin assets to ConocoPhillips for $9.5 billion in cash, marking its exit from the largest U.S. oilfield as it refocuses on clean energy transitions. ConocoPhillips' acquisition of 225,000 net acres strengthens its position in U.S. shale, while both companies made moves related to shareholder returns and greenhouse gas emission targets. The deal highlights a divergence between European and U.S. producers regarding future hydrocarbon investments.

title: BP gambles big on fast transition from oil to renewables
summary: BP is embarking on a rapid transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy, selling off lucrative oil and gas assets to fund investments in clean energy despite current losses in its renewable ventures. CEO Bernard Looney aims to significantly cut BP's oil production while boosting renewable electricity generation by 2030, a strategy that has raised concerns among some executives and analysts about asset valuation and shareholder value. The company plans to offset declining oil and gas revenue with growing revenues from gasoline stations and electric vehicle charging, which they expect to be more stable than the volatile oil business.

title: Royal Dutch Shell Sells Permian Basin Oil Holdings for $9.5 Billion (Published 2021)
summary: Royal Dutch Shell sold its Permian Basin oil holdings to ConocoPhillips for $9.5 billion in cash, marking a significant step for Shell toward cleaner energy production amidst investor and public pressure to reduce carbon emissions. This deal consolidates ConocoPhillips' position as a major player in the Permian Basin, which is seeing a recovery in American shale oil production and a wave of acquisitions. Shell's exit comes nine years after it acquired the field and developed it to produce about 200,000 barrels a day.

title: Suit claims BP trader sacked for raising Nigeria bribe concerns
summary: A former oil trader for British energy giant BP, Jonathan Zarembok, alleges he was fired for raising concerns about bribes being paid in Nigeria to secure local contracts. Zarembok claims BP paid "abnormally large" fees to a local agent and that the company's proposed reasons for these payments were a "sham." BP denies the allegations, stating that the payments were legitimate and thoroughly vetted, and that Zarembok's dismissal was due to an "irretrievably broken down" working relationship.

title: Landmark Legal Cases to Secure Clean Water and Clean Air as a Right For All
summary: Earthjustice highlights fifty years of landmark legal cases focused on securing clean water and clean air as a fundamental right. The article details significant victories, including those related to the Clean Air Act, Mercury & Air Toxics Standards, and the Clean Water Act, demonstrating how legal action holds polluters accountable and strengthens environmental protections across the nation and internationally. These cases range from local community protection to nationwide policy changes and international collaborations.

title: Chevron triples low-carbon investment, but avoids 2050 net-zero goals
summary: Chevron Corp pledged to triple its low-carbon investments to $10 billion through 2028, focusing on reducing its carbon emissions footprint. However, the company is not yet committing to a 2050 net-zero emissions target, citing concerns about realism and deliverability, a stance that diverges from European oil producers. The investment will be allocated across areas such as carbon capture, greenhouse gas reductions, renewable fuels, and hydrogen energy.

title: Oil-soaked birds found near oil spill at refinery in wake of Hurricane Ida
summary: Louisiana wildlife officials have documented over 100 oil-soaked birds near the Phillips 66 Alliance Refinery in Belle Chasse following an oil spill caused by Hurricane Ida's flooding. Efforts are underway to rescue and rehabilitate affected wildlife, including black-bellied whistling ducks, blue-winged teal, and egrets. The incident is part of a larger picture of numerous oil and chemical spills reported to the EPA and Coast Guard in the aftermath of the hurricane.

title: GOOD NEWS: MC students receive scholarships
summary: Midland College (MC) announced a new partnership with Ovintiv USA, Inc., which includes $8,000 in scholarships for Energy Technology students. The scholarships recognize students with GPAs over 3.0 who are also employed, highlighting Ovintiv's commitment to Permian Basin workforce development. Ovintiv, a North American oil and natural gas producer, is supporting MC's program that prepares students for careers in the oil and gas industry.

title: Offshore oil and gas producer Beacon makes major final investment decision in Gulf of Mexico
summary: Beacon Offshore Energy has made its first final investment decision (FID) on the deepwater Shenandoah discovery project in the Gulf of Mexico. This decision could elevate Beacon Offshore Energy to become one of the top 10 offshore producers in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico. The project marks a significant milestone for the Houston-based oil and gas producer.

title: Venture Global, Cheniere Move Closer to Starting Up Louisiana LNG Projects
summary: Venture Global and Cheniere Energy are advancing their Louisiana LNG projects, with both Calcasieu Pass and Sabine Pass signaling potential startup by year-end. Venture Global's Calcasieu Pass is authorized to introduce feed gas, while Cheniere's Sabine Pass sixth train is expected to be fully operational in early 2022. These developments are poised to increase U.S. natural gas exports this winter to meet global LNG demand.

title: P&G’s Board Must Be Accountable for Forest Destruction
summary: Ten months after Procter & Gamble's shareholders called on the company to address its impacts on climate-critical forests and Indigenous rights, P&G has failed to take meaningful action.
