This article details P&G's continued role in driving deforestation and human rights violations through its tissue and palm oil supply chains, and calls for investors to hold the Board of Directors accountable by voting against Angela Braly and James McNerney.

title: Exxon sting surfaces in climate litigation
summary: A secret recording of an Exxon Mobil Corp. lobbyist admitting to the company's obstruction of climate action has surfaced in climate change litigation against the oil giant. The recording, in which lobbyist Keith McCoy details how Exxon relied on "shadow groups" to deny scientific consensus on global warming, is being cited in a "friend of the court" brief in Minnesota’s climate lawsuit. This development is seen as a significant new data point, revealing an Exxon insider's admission of the company's historical and ongoing efforts to misrepresent climate science.

title: Oil and gas firm Talos Energy picked to operate offshore carbon capture, storage project
summary: Talos Energy and partner Carbonvert have been awarded a lease by the Texas General Land Office to operate an offshore carbon capture and storage project in Jefferson County, Texas. This project aims to sequester 225-275 million metric tons of carbon dioxide and marks Talos's first step in building multiple CCS sites along the U.S. Gulf Coast. The agreement is currently in an exclusive negotiation phase with the GLO.

title: Imperial Oil outlines plan to produce plant-based renewable fuel
summary: Imperial Oil plans to build Canada's largest renewable diesel facility near Edmonton, converting vegetable oil into one billion litres of fuel annually. This initiative responds to increasing emissions-reduction goals and impending Canadian Clean Fuel Standard regulations. The project, expected to cost "hundreds of millions of dollars," hinges on government support and market conditions, with a final investment decision anticipated by mid-2022 and production by 2024.

title: Imperial to produce renewable diesel at refinery near Edmonton using locally grown crops
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. plans to build Canada's largest renewable diesel complex at its Strathcona refinery near Edmonton. The facility will use blue hydrogen and locally grown crops to produce up to 1 billion litres per year of low-carbon diesel fuel, potentially reducing annual CO2 emissions by 3 million tonnes from the Canadian transportation sector. The project's progression depends on market conditions and government support, with production possibly starting in 2024 to align with Canada's Clean Fuel Standard.

title: Imperial Oil to produce renewable diesel at Strathcona refinery using locally grown crops
summary: Imperial Oil plans to build Canada's largest renewable diesel complex at its Strathcona refinery near Edmonton, utilizing blue hydrogen and locally grown crops to produce over one billion litres of low-carbon biofuel annually. This project, expected to reduce emissions from the Canadian transportation sector by an equivalent of three million tonnes per year, aims to meet growing customer demand for cleaner burning fuels and align with Canada's Clean Fuel Standard. The company anticipates a final investment decision next year, with production potentially starting in 2024, contingent on market conditions and government support.

title: Most flares from Texas Permian oil drilling lack permits -study
summary: A report by Earthworks claims that major oil producers like Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell are flaring gas in the Permian Basin without the required Texas state permits. The study found that between 69% and 84% of observed flares were likely unpermitted, despite industry claims of compliance and efforts to reduce flaring. Texas regulators, however, contend that Earthworks' analysis is flawed and based on incomplete data, as some unpermitted flaring is allowed under specific conditions.

title: Enterprise AI for the Utilities Industry
summary: This article highlights how C3 AI addresses key issues across the utilities value chain using its powerful Enterprise AI platform and SaaS applications. It details how C3 AI solutions help prioritize asset maintenance, optimize AMI operations, reduce energy costs, and enhance customer service through AI/ML-driven CRM and energy management tools. The platform is designed for rapid integration and deployment, yielding significant business value for utilities.

title: Fossil Fuel Companies Are Quietly Scoring Big Money for Their Preferred Climate Solution: Carbon Capture and Storage
summary: Fossil fuel companies and other industrial sectors are quietly pushing for policies that allocate billions in federal funding for carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, despite environmental advocates arguing that these funds would be better spent on proven renewable energy solutions. The bipartisan infrastructure legislation includes over $12 billion for direct carbon capture support, with potential for billions more, and industry lobbyists are pushing to expand existing tax credits for the technology. While some scientists acknowledge CCS could be useful for specific industrial processes or future direct air capture, environmentalists warn that significant funding risks prolonging the operation of polluting facilities and creating new dependencies on fossil fuels.

title: Natural Gas ETFs Bounce on Supportive Short-Term Fundamentals
summary: Natural gas exchange-traded funds performed well on Monday as natural gas prices rebounded due to supportive short-term fundamentals like higher LNG demand and lower production. While peak summer demand may have passed, analysts suggest a potential downside near-term before storage trajectories provide support. Weather forecasts show continued above-normal heat for the coming week, influencing price movements.

title: Hedge Fund and Insider Trading News: Warren Buffett, Millennium Management, Engine No. 1, HollyFrontier Corp (HFC), DTE Energy Co (DTE), and More
summary: This article provides an update on significant hedge fund and insider trading activities, featuring Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway's substantial gain on DaVita stock and Millennium Management's summer hiring in London. It also highlights Engine No. 1's impact on ExxonMobil's board, pushing for climate action, and reports on overall hedge fund performance and capital movements in July and August 2021.

title: Refiner Boosts Battery Bet
summary: Phillips 66, a major U.S. oil refiner, is diversifying into battery technology by acquiring a 16% stake in Australian company Novonix Ltd. for $150 million. This investment supports the development of a domestic supply chain for EV and energy storage markets in the U.S., as Phillips 66 anticipates gasoline demand has already peaked. The company views battery materials as a significant growth opportunity and a hedge against declining demand for traditional fossil fuels.

title: Oil slips as COVID dampens outlook, again
summary: Oil prices dropped by 2 percent, extending previous losses, due to a rising US dollar and concerns over new COVID-19 restrictions in Asia, particularly China, which are dampening global fuel demand. Analysts point to the accelerating Delta variant and curbs in China, the world's second-largest oil consumer, as significant factors, despite expectations that the market can eventually absorb additional supply from OPEC+.

title: Exxon suspended from climate group after sting tape
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has been suspended from the Climate Leadership Council (CLC) after a secretly recorded video showed a company lobbyist discussing strategies to delay climate action. The tape raised suspicions about Exxon's true commitment to carbon pricing despite its historical support for the CLC. Exxon has disavowed the lobbyist's comments, calling the CLC's decision "disappointing and counterproductive."

title: HollyFrontier and Holly Energy Partners Add Sinclair Dinosaur for $1.8B
summary: Dallas-based HollyFrontier Corporation and Holly Energy Partners announced an agreement to acquire and combine with Sinclair Oil from the Sinclair Corporation in a deal valued at $1.8 billion. The newly formed company will be called HF Sinclair Corporation, headquartered in Dallas, and will replace HollyFrontier in public trading on the NYSE. The acquisition includes Sinclair's market branding, commercial activities, renewable diesel business, and two Rocky Mountain area refineries, consistent with the company's growth strategy.

title: Devon, Conoco Said to Study $10 Billion Shell Permian Assets
summary: Devon Energy Corp. and ConocoPhillips are reportedly evaluating Royal Dutch Shell Plc’s Permian Basin oil fields for a potential acquisition, which could be valued at up to $10 billion. Chevron Corp. is also among the companies considering bids for these assets, primarily located in West Texas. This move indicates Shell's strategy to reduce its acreage, aligning with other European majors.

title: Canada's Imperial Oil posts 7% fall in quarterly profit
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd reported a 7% fall in second-quarter profit due to turnaround activity and weaker margins in its downstream refining business. Despite this, the company saw strong output from its Kearl oil sands mine, leading to raised full-year production guidance. Imperial's CEO noted continued commodity price increases but slow demand recovery amidst ongoing pandemic concerns.

title: Chevron (CVX) Taps Permian Chief to Run New Low-Carbon Division
summary: Chevron Corp. is establishing a new business unit, Chevron New Energies, to focus on scaling up new technologies like carbon capture and hydrogen. Jeff Gustavson, currently head of North America exploration and production, will lead this division, signaling Big Oil's adaptation to the energy transition. Ryder Booth will take over Gustavson's current role.

title: Cenovus retires $1 billion in debt as oil price surge lifts Canadian energy sector
summary: Cenovus Energy Inc. retired nearly $1 billion in debt in the second quarter, anticipating it will meet its interim net debt target of $10 billion by year-end due to surging oil prices. The Calgary-based oil producer reported significant free cash flow and a swing to profit, signaling a robust recovery for the Canadian energy sector. This financial turnaround reflects the easing of COVID-19 restrictions and strong commodity prices after a volatile 2020.

title: Big investors are divesting from fossil fuels – should you?
summary: The article explores the dilemma for Australian investors regarding fossil fuels: whether to invest in undervalued energy names or join the growing trend of divestment. It presents arguments from both "bulls" who see continued demand from Asian markets and "bears" who warn of stranded assets due to renewable energy advancements and tightening regulations. The piece discusses the potential for energy companies to transition to green futures and the financial risks involved for investors.

title: Iraq wants American firm to replace Exxon, prime minister says
summary: Iraq's Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi stated that Iraq wants another American company to replace Exxon Mobil Corp as it exits the country. Exxon is selling its 32.7% stake in the West Qurna 1 oilfield, and while it has agreements with Petrochina and Pertamina, Iraq insists on another American firm as its replacement. Foreign investment is crucial for Iraq, as oil revenue accounts for at least 95% of its income.

title: Exxon Mobil adds first woman top-tier executive with external CFO hire
summary: Exxon Mobil has appointed Kathyrn Mikells as its new chief financial officer, making her the first woman and external hire to join the oil major's management committee. This move comes as Exxon faces investor pressure to diversify its leadership and shake up its executive suite after years of poor returns and as competitors invest more in energy transition. Mikells' appointment is seen as a significant step towards change in the company's historically rigid internal promotion structure.

title: Exxon lobbyists paid the 6 Democrats named in sting video nearly $333,000
summary: A new analysis by Oil Change U.S. reveals that six Democratic senators received nearly $333,000 from Exxon-affiliated lobbyists and PACs over the past decade. This comes after an Exxon lobbyist named these Democrats as key allies in a secretly recorded sting video. The findings highlight Exxon Mobil's significant financial influence in shaping legislative agendas.

title: Dems plan to question Exxon lobbyist about carbon tax video
summary: Congressional investigators are preparing to question an Exxon Mobil Corp. lobbyist, Keith McCoy, after a secretly recorded video showed him admitting the company's efforts to undermine climate action and downplaying its public support for a carbon tax. This inquiry by the House Oversight and Reform Committee is expected to precede a larger hearing with Exxon CEO Darren Woods and other oil and gas executives. The investigation comes as Exxon faces increasing pressure from shareholders regarding climate change concerns.

title: Engine No. 1’s big win over Exxon shows activist hedge funds joining fight against climate change
summary: Engine No. 1, a relatively new hedge fund, secured a significant victory against ExxonMobil, getting at least two of its nominated board members elected. This battle highlighted how a company's failure to address climate change can erode shareholder value, signaling a potential turning point for activist hedge funds to push for more sustainable business practices. The article suggests this win shows a shift in investor sentiment toward sustainability and away from short-term fossil fuel gains.

title: A Closer Look at the PR Feud Between Liberty Oilfield and the North Face
summary: Liberty Oilfield Services launched a marketing campaign against The North Face, accusing the outdoor brand of hypocrisy regarding its climate activism while relying on fossil fuels for its products. This feud highlights the complex and often contentious relationship between the outdoor industry and the oil and gas sector. The North Face, while acknowledging its reliance on fossil fuels, states it carefully considers co-branding partnerships and is working to reduce its environmental impact.

title: Shell hastens efforts to hit goal of net-zero emissions
summary: Pilipinas Shell Petroleum Corp. is accelerating its "Powering Progress" strategy to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 or sooner, aligning with Shell Global's commitment. Recent initiatives include solar installations at mobility sites, a voluntary carbon offset program for fleets which has already offset 4.63 tons of carbon dioxide, and the use of sustainable building materials like Shell Bitumen FreshAir and eco-bricks in new stations. The company emphasizes strategic collaboration with stakeholders to develop renewable energy sources and reduce its carbon footprint.

title: Move to Hydrogen Noted in Chart Industries Executive Interview
summary: Jill Evanko, President and CEO of Chart Industries, discusses the company's significant role in the hydrogen fuel cell sector, leveraging its cryogenic expertise for hydrogen production, distribution, and storage. She highlights Chart's collaboration with heavy-duty transportation companies to advance liquid hydrogen use and anticipates a significant increase in hydrogen fuel cell vehicle adoption within the next 12-18 months. Evanko also emphasizes the need for a hybrid approach to fueling infrastructure and continued industry innovation and collaboration.

title: An Exxon lobbyist thought he was in a job interview. Instead, it was a secretly recorded Zoom call.
summary: An ExxonMobil lobbyist, Keith McCoy, was secretly recorded during a Zoom call by Greenpeace UK, where he openly discussed efforts to obstruct the Biden administration's climate agenda. The leaked video has caused significant repercussions in Washington, leading a top Democratic lawmaker to call for Exxon's CEO to testify before Congress regarding the company's climate change communications. McCoy believed he was participating in a job interview when he made these admissions.

title: New Exxon sting video reveals more energy lobbying tactics
summary: A new sting video reveals an Exxon Mobil Corp. lobbyist discussing the company's tactics to block regulations on plastics and "forever chemicals," mirroring strategies used against climate change regulations. The lobbyist, Keith McCoy, detailed how Exxon uses trade associations to push back against regulation, maintaining plausible deniability. This revelation has sparked outrage among some members of Congress, who criticize the influence of corporate lobbyists.

title: Shell plans to exit California joint venture with Exxon Mobil
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc (RDSa.L) intends to exit Aera, its oil and gas-producing joint venture in California with Exxon Mobil Corp (XOM.N). The move is part of Shell's strategy to divest carbon-intensive assets and increase investments in renewables, aligning with investor pressure to reduce fossil-fuel holdings. Aera accounts for about 25% of California's oil and gas production, and Shell is also considering selling assets in the Permian Basin.

title: Reports of violence, vandalism surface as Warrior Met Coal miners' strike enters fourth month
summary: The strike against Warrior Met Coal Inc. by United Mine Workers of America members has entered its fourth month, marked by continued calls for a "reasonable contract" and reports of violence and vandalism. The union accuses Warrior Met Coal of violence, citing vehicular assaults on picket lines, while the company points to a court-ordered injunction against unlawful activity. A reward of up to $10,000 is being offered for information leading to the arrest and conviction of those who vandalized Warrior Met Coal property in May and June.

title: Exxon lobbyist duped by Greenpeace says climate policy was a ploy, CEO condemns statements
summary: An Exxon Mobil lobbyist, Keith McCoy, was duped by Greenpeace activists posing as headhunters into revealing that Exxon's public support for a carbon tax is a "talking point" because the company believes it will never gain political traction. Exxon CEO Darren Woods condemned McCoy's statements, calling them deeply apologetic and against the company's commitment to climate change solutions. The incident follows recent shareholder frustration over Exxon's climate record and a shake-up of its board.

title: Celanese to acquire Santoprene TPV elastomers business from ExxonMobil
summary: Celanese Corp. announced its definitive agreement to acquire Exxon Mobil Corp.'s Santoprene TPV elastomers business. This acquisition will expand Celanese's portfolio of engineered solutions, particularly in targeted growth areas like future mobility, medical, and sustainability, and is expected to drive future shareholder value.

title: Exxon to sell elastic polymers business to Celanese for $1.15 billion
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced it would sell its Santoprene elastic polymers business to Celanese Corp for $1.15 billion. The deal is part of Exxon's strategy to divest lower-margin operations to improve profit and reduce debt, and it is expected to close in Q4 2021. Celanese anticipates the acquisition will immediately contribute to its 2022 adjusted earnings per share and free cash flow.

title: Celanese buying Santoprene unit from ExxonMobil in $1.15B deal
summary: Celanese Corp. is acquiring ExxonMobil Corp.'s Santoprene-brand thermoplastic vulcanizate business for $1.15 billion. The acquisition, which includes product portfolios, intellectual property, production assets, and approximately 350 employees, is expected to expand Celanese's engineered solutions and be accretive to 2022 adjusted earnings per share. This strategic move aims to strengthen Celanese's elastomers portfolio and target growth areas like future mobility, medical, and sustainability.

title: Equinor to collaborate with U. S. Steel on hydrogen and carbon capture and storage development
summary: Equinor has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with U. S. Steel to explore the development of hydrogen and carbon capture and storage (CCS) in the Appalachian Basin. This collaboration aims to assess the technological and commercial viability of these solutions to help the US achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, focusing on supporting energy-intensive industries. The initial work includes feasibility studies, screening third-party partners, and advocating for supportive policies.

title: Exxon must face Massachusetts lawsuit alleging climate change deceit
summary: A Massachusetts state judge has ruled that Exxon Mobil Corp must face a lawsuit brought by Attorney General Maura Healey, which alleges the oil company misled consumers and investors about its role in climate change. The judge rejected Exxon's attempt to dismiss the case, stating that many of Exxon's statements referenced in the complaint are not protected. This decision follows an activist hedge fund winning board seats at Exxon, intensifying pressure on the energy giant regarding global warming concerns.

title: El Gobierno autorizó la compra de Edenor: sale Mindlin, entran Vila y Manzano
summary: The Argentine government has officially authorized the sale of Edenor, the country's largest electricity distributor, from Marcelo Mindlin's Pampa Energía to a group led by Daniel Vila and José Luis Manzano for $95 million. This transaction marks a significant shift in the energy sector, transferring control from an entrepreneur favored by the previous Macri government to a group with close ties to the current administration. The deal raises questions about the financial health of privatized energy companies and the ongoing state subsidies required for their operation, especially given Edenor's significant debt to the state.

title: Angst at Exxon as managers begin employee performance reviews
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is conducting its yearly performance review for U.S. staff, a process some workers fear may lead to stealth layoffs as 5% to 10% of the workforce are expected to be put on performance improvement plans. This comes after Exxon targeted 8% of U.S. employees as low performers last year, up from a historical 3%, and follows a significant $22.4 billion loss in 2020 and plans to reduce its global workforce by 14,000 by the end of 2021.

title: ExxonMobil, FuelCell Energy Partner on ‘Game Changing’ Technology
summary: ExxonMobil and FuelCell Energy are collaborating on developing carbon reduction technologies, with FuelCell Energy focusing on converting methane-rich fuels into electricity and capturing carbon to produce more electricity. ExxonMobil is also developing biofuels and algae for fuel production to address the dual challenge of meeting energy demand while lowering emissions. This partnership highlights the importance of collaboration between large and smaller companies in tackling climate change.

title: ETF issuers ‘systematically’ allocate to new carbon-intensive bonds, research finds
summary: New academic research indicates that ETF issuers consistently purchase new bonds from carbon-intensive companies, despite increasing focus on ESG investing. The study, titled "Breaking the Bond: Primary Markets and Carbon-Intensive Financing," found that 13.6% of new bonds acquired by 35 large US-listed corporate bond ETFs between 2015 and 2020 were from carbon-intensive sectors, exceeding the wider global corporate bond market's 10%. This trend raises concerns that ETFs could become "buyers of last resort" for these sectors, potentially hindering the transition to a low-carbon economy.

title: ICE Extends European Natural Gas Forward Curve Amid Record Interest
summary: Intercontinental Exchange Inc. (ICE) is extending its European natural gas forward curve for Dutch TTF futures until December 2031 due to record interest and strong trading activity. This extension, driven by customer requests, will allow market participants to better hedge global gas price risk and optimize LNG portfolios. The move aligns the futures contract with typical lengths of medium- to long-term LNG deals.

title: Turkey turns to U.S. firms as plans Black Sea gas extraction, official says
summary: Turkey has shared data on its Black Sea gas discovery with U.S. energy majors Chevron and Exxon Mobil, signaling a potential shift towards foreign cooperation in extracting the estimated 540 billion cubic meters field. This move comes as Turkey, previously intent on developing the field independently, considers the technical and financial reasons for a consortium and aims to reduce its energy dependence on other nations. The collaboration could also help ease tensions between NATO allies Turkey and the U.S.

title: ExxonMobil Claims More Stabroek Success in Guyana
summary: ExxonMobil announced a new discovery at Longtail-3 in the Stabroek Block offshore Guyana, encountering 230 feet of net pay. This discovery, along with the recent Uaru-2 find, has the potential to increase resource estimates for the block and supports a potential fifth FPSO vessel. ExxonMobil, along with partners Hess and CNOOC Petroleum, continues to develop the world-class resource in Guyana.

title: Exxon, union negotiators to meet over U.S. refinery lockout -official
summary: Negotiators for the United Steelworkers union (USW) and Exxon Mobil Corp (XOM.N) were set to meet for the first time since a May 1 lockout of Beaumont, Texas, refinery workers. A contract covering 650 union workers expired earlier this year, and Exxon locked out workers citing fear of a sudden walkout. The two sides will attempt to resolve open issues, including Exxon's proposal for separate contracts and control over senior posts, and USW's six-year contract proposal with no pay raise in the first year.

title: Exxon's board shakeup could force review of billions of dollars in spending
summary: The recent overhaul of Exxon Mobil Corp's board of directors is expected to lead to a review of billions of dollars in spending and strategy over several years, according to analysts and investors. With activist directors now holding a third of the board seats, there's pressure to re-evaluate projects and shift towards more cost-conscious approaches. This shakeup follows years of weak financial returns and investor dissatisfaction with Exxon's past strategies regarding energy transition and market shifts.

title: Coca-Cola Sued for False Advertising Over Sustainability Claims
summary: Earth Island Institute has filed a lawsuit against Coca-Cola, alleging false advertising and greenwashing due to the company's sustainability claims, despite being the world's leading plastic waste generator. The suit, filed in District of Columbia Superior Court, does not seek damages but aims to halt Coca-Cola's deceptive marketing practices and encourage transparency regarding its plastic use. This action highlights a broader issue of corporations, including those in the fossil fuel industry, facing legal challenges over misleading environmental representations.

title: Memphis pipeline rekindles eminent domain fight
summary: A planned oil pipeline in Memphis, the Byhalia Connection, has ignited a fierce eminent domain battle, particularly due to its proposed route through a low-income Black neighborhood. Critics argue that private companies wielding condemnation powers are exploiting vulnerable communities and that the project constitutes environmental racism. The pipeline companies, Plains All American Pipeline LP and Valero Energy Corp., defend the route as necessary for economic development and claim it avoids greater community impact, despite facing significant local, environmental, and political opposition.

title: Will Chevron Divest Canada Oil Sands Asset?
summary: Chevron Corp. is considering selling its 20% stake in a Canadian oil sands mine due to investor pressure to curb emissions. CEO Michael Wirth stated that while the asset generates good cash flow, it's not strategic, and the company would be open to a sale if fair value is met. This potential divestment aligns with other major oil companies that have shed oil sands holdings amidst increasing climate-related demands from shareholders and courts.

title: Investment firm Engine No. 1 prepares to launch Transform 500 ETF after Exxon win
summary: Following its recent success in securing board seats at Exxon Mobil Corp., investment firm Engine No. 1 is set to launch the Transform 500 ETF. This new exchange-traded fund will focus on socially conscious investing across various sectors and aims to encourage transformational change in public companies through proxy voting. The ETF will be managed by Molly Landes and represents the firm's broader strategy after its impactful investment in Exxon.

title: XOM Exits Oil Exploration Prospect in Ghana
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. is withdrawing from a deep-water oil exploration prospect in Ghana, two years after the initial agreement was ratified. The company relinquished its 80% stake in the Deepwater Cape Three Points block and resigned as operator after fulfilling contractual obligations during the early exploration phase. This move prompts Ghana National Petroleum Corp. and Ghana Oil Co. to seek a new operator for the block.

title: Chevron Increases Base Oil Prices Again, Prices for Several Base Oil Grades Touch Record Highs
summary: Chevron Corp. has announced its second base oil price increase in a month, effective May 28, 2021, with various grades seeing hikes of 20-30 cents/gallon. Other manufacturers like Excel Paralubes, Phillips 66, and ExxonMobil are also raising prices. These increases are attributed to tight supply, robust demand, and rising production costs, leading base oil prices to record highs.

title: New Exxon director’s resume bolsters ‘best’ boast
summary: Greg Goff, a new board director at Exxon Mobil Corp., was initially deemed "unqualified" by the company despite his extensive experience across all segments of the oil industry. His background, including a successful tenure as CEO of Tesoro Corp. and a 1,032% stock gain, bolsters activist investor Engine No. 1's proxy fight victory and suggests a focus on improving Exxon's financial performance and addressing climate change concerns. Goff's appointment comes after a significant shake-up at Exxon, signaling a new era for the oil giant and a challenging integration with current CEO Darren Woods.

title: What Exxon, Chevron climate shake-ups mean for oil
summary: Climate change activists achieved significant victories at Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp., securing a board shake-up at Exxon and expanded climate goals at Chevron through shareholder votes. These moves, following years of pressure and investor organizing, signify a potential shift in strategy for major U.S. oil producers regarding emissions and climate change. The impact will depend on the new board members at Exxon and how Chevron implements its broadened emissions targets.

title: Engine No. 1 wins 3 Exxon Mobil board seats amid climate criticism (updated)
summary: Activist investor Engine No. 1 secured three board seats at Exxon Mobil following a proxy fight. The hedge fund's success comes amid growing climate criticism and pressure on the energy giant. Greg Goff, former CEO of Andeavor, is among the new directors.

title: Activist Wins Exxon Board Seats After Questioning Oil Giant’s Climate Strategy
summary: An activist investor, Engine No. 1, won seats on Exxon Mobil Corp.'s board, marking a significant setback for the oil giant and CEO Darren Woods. This victory, achieved in one of the most expensive proxy fights, will likely force Exxon to address growing shareholder concerns about climate change more directly. Preliminary vote counts indicated shareholders supported two of Engine No. 1's nominees.

title: ExxonMobil Shareholders to Company: We Want a Different Approach to Climate Change
summary: ExxonMobil shareholders voted to elect two new corporate directors supported by an investment firm seeking to push the oil giant toward a more climate-friendly strategy. This move is seen as a significant blow to Exxon's current leadership and signals strong shareholder concern about the company's approach to the energy transition, potentially leading to a re-evaluation of its long-term strategy. The vote highlights growing investor pressure on major oil companies to address climate change more aggressively.

title: Engine No. 1’s big win over Exxon shows activist hedge funds joining fight against climate change
summary: A proxy battle led by Engine No. 1, a relatively small hedge fund, against Exxon Mobil resulted in at least two of Engine No. 1's board nominees being approved, signaling a significant shift in how activist hedge funds engage with climate change. This event highlights a new trend where investor pressure for sustainability aligns with long-term shareholder value, challenging traditional short-term profit motives of hedge funds. The article suggests this could be a turning point for corporate accountability on climate issues.

title: Exxon CEO is dealt a stinging setback at hands of activist
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. CEO Darren Woods suffered a major setback as activist investor Engine No. 1 successfully secured at least two board seats despite vocal opposition from Exxon. This unprecedented victory for a small activist firm against a major oil producer signals a growing willingness among institutional investors to push for corporate action on climate change and raises questions about Exxon's energy transition strategy.

title: EXCLUSIVE BlackRock backs 3 dissidents to shake up Exxon board -sources
summary: BlackRock, Exxon Mobil Corp's second-largest shareholder, is backing several candidates from Engine No. 1 to join Exxon's board, challenging the energy giant's strategy following years of weak financial performance and reluctance to invest in renewable energy. This support from a major institutional investor like BlackRock highlights growing shareholder frustration and the increasing importance of environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) factors in investment decisions, potentially influencing the outcome of Exxon's upcoming annual shareholder meeting.

title: Nordic American Tankers reports $25m loss
summary: Nordic American Tankers Ltd reported a net loss of $25 million in the first quarter of the year, an improvement from the previous quarter's $28.7 million loss. Despite the loss, the company remains optimistic about the future of the tanker market, citing easing Opec oil production cuts and strong global oil demand. Nordic American Tankers also announced a dividend payment of two cents per share, marking its 95th consecutive quarterly dividend.

title: Hess takes more interest in Exxon’s Guyana block
summary: Hess Corporation has increased its working interest in the ExxonMobil-operated Kaieteur Block offshore Guyana from 15% to 20% following the Tanager-1 oil discovery in November 2020. This move reflects confidence in the block's prospective resource potential and the wider Guyana-Suriname Basin's hydrocarbon resources. The Kaieteur JV now consists of ExxonMobil (operator, 35%), Ratio Guyana Limited (25%), Cataleya Energy Limited (20%), and Hess (20%).

title: BHP Sells Its Stake in the GoM Neptune Field to EnVen
summary: BHP announced it is divesting its 35% stake in the Neptune field in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico to Houston-based EnVen Energy Corp. The transaction will increase EnVen's interest in the deepwater field from 30% to 65%, while BHP will continue to operate the field under contract until regulatory approval. This divestment aligns with BHP's long-term strategy to reshape its portfolio, though the Gulf of Mexico remains a key region for the company.

title: Exxon says it will restart gas compressor at Guyana platform in June
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced on Friday that it plans to reinstall a gas compressor at its Liza Destiny platform off Guyana's coast in June. This comes after an equipment failure last month forced the company to reduce oil output significantly. The company is currently producing 100,000-110,000 barrels per day and is working to comply with Guyana's environmental regulations regarding gas flaring.

title: Strong Vote — Shareholders Condemn Sempra Energy’s Anti-Climate Lobbying
summary: Sempra Energy shareholders, representing 37% of investors, voted to support a climate lobbying resolution at the company's annual meeting. The resolution, filed by As You Sow, Calvert Research and Management, and the Office of the Illinois State Treasurer, demands a report on the alignment of Sempra's lobbying activities with the Paris Agreement's 1.5 degrees Celsius goal. This strong vote signals investor concern over Sempra's anti-climate lobbying, particularly in California, and emphasizes the need for transparency and alignment with climate goals.

title: Methanex will not accept short-term gas contract from NGC
summary: Methanex announced that it will not accept a short-term gas contract from NGC for its Titan plant at the Point Lisas Industrial Estate, stating that month-by-month contracts are not feasible for restarting the plant. The company prefers a medium to longer-term agreement to justify the significant investment needed for a restart and to ensure profitability through market cycles. Despite a competitor restarting operations on short-term agreements, Methanex is prioritizing certainty and a more economically viable long-term solution.

title: Full-year US chemical results show an industry hit by COVID-19
summary: The article details how the COVID-19 pandemic significantly impacted the top 50 US chemical producers in 2020, leading to a 10.1% drop in combined chemical sales and an even sharper decline of 15.6% in profits for those reporting operating income. Companies reacted by cutting capital spending, with some product demands like polyethylene seeing increases. The report also highlights changes in the ranking due to mergers, acquisitions, and new entrants.

title: How a Century of Moments Built MRC Global
summary: This article chronicles the 100-year history of MRC Global, a leading PVF distributor, tracing its evolution from Jerry McJunkin's initial company in 1921 to its current global presence. It highlights key moments like mergers, strategic acquisitions, and investments in technology like the Houston Operations Complex and the MRCGO e-commerce platform. The article emphasizes how the company has adapted to industry changes, customer needs, and economic cycles, positioning itself for future success under new leadership.

title: Exxon Outvotes Other Shareholders to Beat Back Net-Zero Resolution for Imperial Oil
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. shareholders, led by parent company ExxonMobil, voted to defeat a resolution for the company to adopt a net-zero carbon emissions target by 2050. While ExxonMobil owns 69.6% of Imperial, 58% of other shareholders voted in favor of the resolution, highlighting a rift. Imperial's CEO stated that such a long-term target is premature without clear, achievable steps, focusing instead on a 2023 emissions reduction goal.

title: Exxon expects $200 mln in charges this year for job cuts
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp expects up to $200 million in charges this year related to job cuts as part of its cost-saving efforts, with total cash outflows estimated to be between $400 million and $600 million. The company's workforce reductions are expected to be "substantially complete" by year-end, leading to anticipated annual cost savings of $1 billion to $2 billion compared to 2019 levels. Exxon, which reported its first annual loss last year due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on energy demand, has been slashing costs and delaying projects.

title: UAE Wealth Fund to Buy Share of Israeli Gas Field
summary: Mubadala, the UAE's sovereign wealth fund, plans to acquire a 22 percent stake in Israel's Tamar offshore natural gas field from Delek for $1.1 billion. This deal, the largest commercial agreement since the Abraham Accords, significantly advances the UAE's diplomatic and energy profile in the Mediterranean region. The acquisition faces geopolitical complexities, including Palestinian opposition and regional rivalries, while highlighting the broader growth of East Mediterranean energy production.

title: Timeline: Looking back at departing Chesapeake Energy CEO Doug Lawler's time with the company
summary: This article provides a timeline of major events during Doug Lawler's tenure as CEO of Chesapeake Energy, from his appointment in 2013 to his departure in 2021. It highlights the company's efforts to reduce debt, its oil expansion, the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing and subsequent emergence, and the renaming of Chesapeake Energy Arena. Lawler's time was marked by significant financial challenges and strategic shifts to keep the company afloat.

title: $380MM Brazil Drilling Contract Goes to Seadrill
summary: Seadrill Limited has secured a four-year firm contract, valued at approximately $380 million, for its West Saturn drillship to work on the Bacalhau field in Brazil for Equinor Brasil Energia Ltda. The contract's total value is contingent on the final investment decision by Equinor and its partners, Exxon Mobil Corp. and Petrogal Brasil. Seadrill plans to implement significant upgrades to the drillship, including a combined hydrogen and methanol injection system, to enhance efficiency and reduce fuel consumption by 10-15%.

title: CalPERS to back activist’s four director nominees in Exxon board fight
summary: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System (CalPERS) announced its support for Engine No. 1's four director nominees in their proxy fight against Exxon Mobil Corp. CalPERS, a major shareholder, cited ExxonMobil's long-term financial underperformance and the need for new expertise, particularly in clean energy, as reasons for its decision. This move adds significant weight to Engine No. 1's challenge ahead of Exxon's annual meeting.

title: NextEra Energy Is One of the 2021 TIME100 Most Influential Companies | TIME
summary: NextEra Energy has been named one of the 2021 TIME100 Most Influential Companies, following a period of significant growth and market outperformance. The utility company, which is the world's largest generator of wind and solar power, briefly surpassed ExxonMobil in market capitalization, demonstrating the profitability of renewable energy. NextEra is expected to invest tens of billions more in renewable energy by 2022, with 35% of its electricity already sourced from wind and solar.

title: Shareholders Are Pressing for Climate Risk Disclosures. That’s Good for Everyone.
summary: Shareholders are increasingly demanding that companies disclose their climate change-related risks. Major corporations like BP, Exxon Mobil, Occidental Petroleum, and PPL Corporation have seen shareholder proposals accepted on this matter, and a record number of such proposals are expected this year. This trend, despite proposals often receiving limited initial support, signifies a growing investor focus on the financial implications of climate change.

title: Does The Energy Sector and "ERX" Still Have Room to Run?
summary: The S&P 500 Energy index and the Direxion Daily Energy Bull 3X Shares (ERX) have shown significant strength in 2021, with ERX up 56%. Analysts suggest the sector still has room to run, supported by a bullish oil report from the International Energy Agency (IEA) and anticipated global demand growth despite potential fragility from rising COVID-19 cases. The IEA revised up global oil demand for 2021 and expects strong demand growth in the latter half of the year.

title: News - Braskem joins Cyclyx as Founding Member
summary: Braskem has joined Cyclyx International as a founding member, aiming to increase plastic recyclability from 10% to 90%. Geoffrey Inch, Braskem's Sustainability and Circular Economy Director, will also join the Cyclyx Executive Advisory Board. This partnership enhances Braskem's commitment to a Carbon Neutral Circular Economy and the development of certified circular polypropylene.

title: Diverse workforce brought HPE headquarters to Houston, CEO says
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise CEO Antonio Neri stated that the primary reason for moving the company's headquarters to Houston was to tap into the city's diverse talent pool. Neri, an immigrant himself, believes that diverse companies perform better and sees Houston's demographics, as well as its educational institutions, as key assets for HPE's long-term growth and leadership diversity. Additionally, HPE's involvement in COVID-19 vaccine research using its high-performance computing systems was highlighted.

title: Exxon proposes massive $100B CCS project
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has proposed a massive $100 billion carbon capture "innovation zone" near Houston to trap and store industrial emissions. The project aims to be a large-scale collaboration between government, industry, academia, and local communities, with a goal of capturing roughly 50 million metric tons of CO2 per year by 2030. This initiative aligning with the Biden administration's push for more carbon capture infrastructure, drawing parallels to the "Storing CO2 And Lowering Emissions (SCALE) Act."

title: Chemical Used in Many Oil Refineries Could Cause Mass Deaths If Leaked
summary: An investigation reveals that modified hydrofluoric acid (MHF), used in many oil refineries, poses a significant danger to nearby residents, with a potential leak causing mass casualties. Despite industry claims of safety, experts argue that MHF is nearly identical to deadly hydrofluoric acid (HF) and could form a flesh-eating vapor cloud. Community activists and local officials are pushing for a ban on these chemicals, highlighting past incidents and the inadequacy of current safety measures, particularly in earthquake-prone areas.

title: Exxon Mobil has agreed to reduce air pollution at refinery near Chicago - U.S. Justice Department
authors: Sarah N. Lynch and Jan Wolfe
summary: Exxon Mobil has reached an agreement with U.S. and Illinois regulators to significantly reduce air pollution at its refinery near Chicago. The consent decree requires operational changes to its sulfur recovery plant and a payment of over $1.5 million in penalties, plus an estimated $10 million in improvements to reduce emissions. This action signals the Biden administration's commitment to cracking down on major polluters.

title: Exxon Mobil Will Keep Paying Its Dividend, And May Be Worth 30% More
summary: Exxon Mobil is committed to maintaining its dividend, offering a strong 6.15% yield. Based on historical dividend yield, P/E, and P/Sales multiples, XOM stock is estimated to be undervalued by approximately 30-34%, suggesting a target price significantly higher than its current trading value. While most analysts have more conservative short-term targets, the article argues for a long-term potential for significant returns, including dividend income.

title: Tegna shareholder says company has pattern of racial bias, insensitivity
summary: A major Tegna shareholder, Standard General, is calling for an investigation into alleged patterns of racial bias and insensitive behavior within the company. This demand follows media reports and an anonymous letter from a former employee detailing numerous incidents of discrimination. Tegna has acknowledged it's not perfect but claims significant progress in diversity, equity, and inclusion, dismissing Standard General's claims as an attempt to advance a proxy fight.

title: COVID-19 surge complicates busy maintenance season for Canada's oil sands
summary: Canada's oil sands face challenges during their busy annual maintenance season due to a third wave of COVID-19, making workers reluctant to travel. Despite companies introducing rapid testing and travel assistance, finding skilled tradespeople is difficult with several oil sands sites fighting outbreaks. This could impact maintenance schedules crucial for regulatory compliance and safety, potentially affecting crude output.

title: MRC Global marks its centennial more with relief than revelry
summary: MRC Global, a leading distributor of pipe, valves, and fittings to the energy industry, is celebrating its centennial with a new CEO and a sense of optimism after a challenging year. The company recorded a significant loss in 2020 due to plunging oil prices and the pandemic but is now seeing improvements. They are also preparing for the industry's shift towards alternative energy sources.

title: Occidental CEO Hollub opposes a carbon tax despite rivals' support for idea
summary: Occidental Petroleum CEO Vicki Hollub has voiced her opposition to a carbon tax, despite the backing it has received from major rival oil companies and some trade groups. Hollub argues that a carbon tax would negatively impact a significant portion of the industry, consumers, and particularly economically disadvantaged individuals. Meanwhile, Occidental is pursuing ambitious climate targets and is trying to make its low-carbon unit profitable.

title: Exxon sues Energy Transfer over charges from pipeline dispute
summary: Exxon Mobil's XTO Energy shale unit has filed a breach of contract lawsuit against Energy Transfer LP over disputed payments related to the Dakota Access Pipeline. The suit claims Energy Transfer hit XTO with deficiency charges and revoked credits after Exxon shifted oil to other outlets following a U.S. court order to shut down DAPL. Exxon is seeking over $1 million in damages, return of revoked credits, and attorneys' fees.

title: Fossil Fuel Companies Took Billions in U.S. Coronavirus Relief Funds but Still Cut Nearly 60,000 Jobs
summary: A new analysis by BailoutWatch reveals that dozens of fossil fuel companies received $8.2 billion in tax benefits through the CARES Act in 2020 but still cut nearly 60,000 jobs. This contradicts the stated intent of Congress to maintain employment, as companies like Marathon Petroleum ($2.1 billion in benefits, nearly 2,000 jobs cut) and NOV ($591 million, nearly 8,000 jobs cut) prioritized cash flow and shareholder rewards. The article highlights that these tax changes, while not explicitly targeting the oil industry, uniquely benefited them due to their volatile earnings.

title: Court Affirms Dismissal of NYC Climate Suit
summary: The Second Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal of New York City's climate change lawsuit against major oil companies, ruling that the Clean Air Act governs domestic emissions and foreign policy concerns preclude judicial intervention in regulating foreign emissions. The court emphasized that federal common law displaces state law in this context, deeming global warming a "uniquely international problem of national concern" unsuitable for state nuisance law. This decision contrasts with other courts allowing state-level climate suits, highlighting ongoing litigation regarding climate change liability.

title: Can FuelCell Energy’s molten carbonate fuel cell help solve the CO₂ problem?
summary: FuelCell Energy (FCE) is developing a molten carbonate fuel cell (MCFC) that can capture CO2 from power plant flue gas while generating additional electricity. This technology offers an alternative to traditional, energy-intensive carbon capture methods, potentially reducing costs and allowing existing energy infrastructure to meet emissions demands. Despite challenges including financial losses and project setbacks, FCE is transitioning from an R&D company to a commercial provider, with investor interest growing due to its carbon capture and reversible hydrogen fuel cell solutions.

title: Drillers Burned Off Gas at a Staggering Rate as Winter Storm Hit Texas
summary: During the winter storm in Texas, drillers in the Permian Basin were forced to burn off an estimated 1.6 billion cubic feet of natural gas in a single day, a fivefold increase from pre-crisis rates. This flaring occurred because pipelines froze and power plants went offline, leaving nowhere for the gas to go. Satellite analysis confirms this as one of the highest spikes in flaring ever observed in the region.

title: Cold weather played role in crude oil price increase in February
summary: Extreme winter weather, particularly in Texas, significantly contributed to the rise in crude oil and natural gas prices in February, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA). The cold temperatures disrupted petroleum supply and increased demand for natural gas, leading to a notable price surge for both commodities. The EIA anticipates market rebalancing in the latter half of 2021 for crude oil and projects increases in U.S. electricity consumption and carbon dioxide emissions for 2021 and 2022.

title: Feeling Aggressive? This Leveraged Oil ETF May Be for You
summary: Oil prices continue to rise, fueling the Direxion Daily Energy Bull 2X Shares (ERX) ETF, which has seen over 90% year-to-date gains. This surge is attributed to OPEC+'s decision to maintain supply curbs despite global economic recovery and the ongoing worldwide vaccine rollout. Investors looking for aggressive exposure to the energy sector might find ERX appealing, though its relative strength index indicates it is currently in overbought territory.

title: Exxon’s CEO sees golden opportunities in carbon capture
summary: Exxon Mobil CEO Darren Woods views carbon offsets and carbon capture as significant money-making opportunities, especially through partnerships with venture funds. The company's new Low Carbon Solutions business aims to commercialize low-carbon technologies and would benefit from a government-set "transparent and explicit price on carbon." Exxon is looking to leverage external investments and its own capabilities to create a successful business while growing shareholder value in this space.

title: ExxonMobil Seeks Minimum 30% Returns on New Projects
summary: ExxonMobil has set a target of at least 30% returns on new projects following reductions in capital spending, aiming to rebuild investor confidence. The company expects projects in Guyana and the Permian Basin to generate 10% returns even at oil prices of $35 a barrel or less. This strategy is intended to boost earnings, cash flow, and ensure dividend growth, despite significant debt and past cash burn.

title: Michael Angelakis and Jeffrey Ubben join ExxonMobil board of directors
summary: Exxon Mobil Corporation announced that Michael Angelakis and Jeffrey Ubben have joined its board of directors, increasing the board to 13 members, 12 of whom are independent. Angelakis, chairman and CEO of Atairos, and Ubben, co-founder of Inclusive Capital Partners, bring expertise in capital allocation and strategy development. Their appointments are aimed at strengthening ExxonMobil's board as it navigates complex transitions, focuses on increasing shareholder value, and plays a role in the energy transition.

title: Exxon board adds activist after attacks on returns, climate
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. appointed climate-minded activist investor Jeff Ubben and former Comcast Corp. executive Michael Angelakis to its board following investor criticism over its environmental record and poor capital allocation. These appointments aim to appease shareholders amid a proxy battle with activist investor Engine No. 1 and follow moves by Exxon to address emissions targets and climate disclosure. The company's financial performance has dwindled, with a significant loss in 2020, intensifying pressure from investors for change.

title: ExxonMobil adds 'socially responsible' activist investor Jeffrey Ubben to board
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has appointed two new directors to its board, including activist investor Jeffrey Ubben and former Comcast CFO Michael Angelakis, amidst pressure from activist investors for board changes and a clearer energy transition strategy. While the move aims to refresh the board, one activist fund, Engine No. 1 LLC, still plans a proxy fight for additional board seats, pushing for more diverse expertise in the energy industry. The company also announced a new "low carbon solutions" business unit to invest in emission-lowering technologies like carbon capture and storage.

title: Sempra CEO Says ‘Goal’ to Help in Mexico’s Infrastructure Needs
summary: Sempra Energy CEO Jeffrey Martin affirmed the company's commitment to supporting Mexico's infrastructure needs despite regulatory changes, viewing their role as a partner in the government's goals. Martin highlighted the importance of natural gas infrastructure and storage, especially after a recent energy crisis, and confirmed Sempra's continued investment in gas export projects and the $2 billion ECA LNG export terminal. The company reported strong full-year 2020 earnings and has a significant capital plan focused on infrastructure and renewable energy.

title: Exxon Mobil's total reserves drop by a third after COVID-19 oil price drop
summary: Exxon Mobil's global oil and gas reserves decreased by a third in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on oil prices and demand. This reduction led to significant cuts in project spending, jobs, and a net annual loss of $22.4 billion for the company. The decline was primarily driven by oil sands in Canada and U.S. shale gas properties.

title: Exxon's Baytown refinery making slow progress restarting wastewater, sulfur units -sources
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is facing slow progress in restarting the wastewater and sulfur recovery units at its 560,500-barrel-per-day Baytown, Texas, refinery. These units are crucial for environmental compliance, treating water used in fuel production and extracting sulfur from hydrogen sulfide. While the company acknowledges making progress in restarting operations, it refrains from discussing individual unit operations as a matter of practice.

title: CFO at Jerry Jones' gas company on rising prices due to Texas freeze: 'Like hitting the jackpot'
summary: Roland Burns, CFO of Comstock Resources Inc., a natural gas company controlled by Jerry Jones, reportedly described the rising natural gas prices during the deadly Texas winter storm as "like hitting the jackpot." This statement drew criticism as millions in Texas faced power outages and frigid temperatures. The storm caused gas production to plummet, leading to a surge in prices, from which Comstock benefited by selling gas at "super premium prices."

title: New Mexico largest electric utility bankrolled dark money group in 2020 election
summary: New Mexico's largest electric utility, PNM Resources, Inc., was the sole funder of a dark money group called the “Council for a Competitive New Mexico” (CCNM) in the 2020 election, contributing almost half a million dollars. CCNM spent over $130,000 on mailers and robo-calls to support incumbents and attack opponents in five state senate Democratic primary races. This disclosure by the New Mexico State Ethics Commission highlights the utility's increasing involvement in state politics and raises suspicions about its potential funding of other dark money groups.

title: Celanese Corp. stock outperforms market on strong trading day
summary: Celanese Corp. (CE) stock rose 1.02% on Thursday, outperforming the mixed market performance of the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average. The stock closed $9.62 short of its 52-week high reached on January 6th. Trading volume for the day was below its 50-day average, and the company showed mixed performance against competitors like Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM), Eastman Chemical Co. (EMN), and Westlake Chemical Corp. (WLK).

title: The 2020 Polar Endeavour Shipyard Project
summary: This article details the challenges faced during the 2020 Polar Endeavour shipyard project in Singapore, which was significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The crew and shoreside staff demonstrated exceptional teamwork and dedication to complete the required maintenance under strict travel restrictions and quarantine measures. Despite hurdles like reduced crew and limited shore access, the project was successfully completed, setting a precedent for subsequent tanker dry dock schedules.

title: Exxon to close Australian refinery
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced the closure of its 72-year-old Altona refinery in Australia, converting it into a fuel import terminal due to low demand and economic unviability. This decision leaves Australia with only two operating refineries after BP Plc also decided to shut its Kwinana facility. The Australian energy minister expressed disappointment, noting that 300 jobs would be affected, but assured that fuel stockholdings would not be negatively impacted.

title: Billion-dollar baby: Amazon daily sales surpass new milestone
summary: Amazon.com Inc. achieved over $1 billion a day in revenue in 2020, reaching $386 billion for the full year, driven by the holiday shopping season and increased online shopping during the pandemic. The e-commerce giant's revenue surged by nearly 44% in the fourth quarter to over $100 billion, reflecting a significant shift towards online retail that analysts expect to continue. Despite CEO Jeff Bezos stepping down, strong analyst ratings and projected market dominance indicate continued growth for the company.

title: The Drilldown: Imperial Oil has alternative plans in case Line 5 closes
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. is preparing contingency plans to transport oil from Western Canada to Ontario refineries if Michigan succeeds in closing Enbridge Line 5. The company reported a significant loss for its fourth quarter due to a non-cash charge on natural gas assets and decreased fuel demand from lockdowns. Internationally, Lebanon will receive fuel oil from Iraq to address power shortages, while France and the UK face criticism for insufficient action against climate change.

title: Exxon Defends Dividend After First Annual Loss in Decades
summary: ExxonMobil (XOM) pledged to safeguard its dividend even after posting its first annual loss in 40 years, a stance that differentiates it from rivals who cut payouts. CEO Woods emphasized a willingness to sacrifice new projects to protect the dividend, highlighting the company's commitment to financial health even in a low oil price environment. The company's stock rose despite the news, indicating investor confidence in its dividend protection strategy.

title: Exxon Creates Carbon Capture Tech Branch
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp has launched a new division, Low Carbon Solutions, to commercialize its carbon emission reduction technology. This move is part of the company's efforts to address climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions amid increasing pressure from investors and activists. The new unit will initially focus on carbon capture and storage in locations like the U.S. Gulf Coast and depleted North Sea gas fields.

title: CEOs of oil giants Exxon, Chevron discussed mega merger: Reports
authors: Reuters and The Wall Street Journal
summary: The CEOs of ExxonMobil Corp and Chevron Corp held preliminary talks in early 2020 about a potential mega-merger, which would have been the largest ever. These discussions, no longer active, highlight the immense pressure on the energy sector due to plunging oil prices during the COVID-19 pandemic. The potential merger would have faced significant regulatory scrutiny, particularly under the Biden administration, and sought synergies through major cost cuts.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Exxon, Chevron CEOs Discussed Merger
summary: The CEOs of Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. discussed a potential merger last year after the pandemic significantly impacted oil and gas demand. While described as preliminary and not ongoing, such a combination could represent one of the largest corporate mergers in history. The discussions highlight the financial pressures faced by both companies due to crashing energy prices.

title: GM’s all-EV plan could shake the energy industry
summary: General Motors announced its plan to stop making gas-powered cars by 2035 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2040, a move expected to transform the electric vehicle market and energy industry. This significant commitment will necessitate dramatic changes to the electric grid and put GM in direct competition with Tesla. The shift also marks a major policy turnaround for GM, which previously sided with the Trump administration against stricter emissions standards.

title: Activist investor Engine No. 1 nominates four potential Exxon Mobil directors
summary: Activist investor Engine No. 1 has nominated four candidates to Exxon Mobil's board of directors, arguing that the company needs a significant change in its existing strategy. This move indicates increasing pressure on Exxon Mobil to reassess its strategic direction.

title: BlackRock’s shift to ‘net-zero’ investments is accelerating, CEO Larry Fink says
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink announced an acceleration in the firm's shift towards "net-zero" investments, urging companies in its portfolio to disclose their strategies for a carbon-neutral economy. This move reflects an intensifying reallocation of capital towards sustainable assets, with global investors pouring US$288-billion into sustainable funds from January to November last year. BlackRock emphasizes that companies failing to demonstrate progress in climate risk disclosure and transition plans could face divestment from its discretionary active portfolios.

title: Iditarod Sled-dog Race Losing Exxon Support Amid Animal-rights Pressure
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced its decision to end its sponsorship of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race after the 2021 event, citing economic concerns. This move is seen as a victory by animal-rights activists like PETA, who have long criticized the race as inhumane. The Iditarod organization, facing multiple sponsor withdrawals and a scaled-back race due to the pandemic, hopes to rebuild and reassess its partnerships.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Magellan and Enterprise to develop Joint Houston crude oil futures contract
summary: Magellan Midstream Partners and Enterprise Products Partners announced an agreement to jointly develop a Houston-based crude oil futures contract. This initiative aims to address market interest for greater scale, flow assurance, and price transparency for physical crude oil delivery in the Houston area. The contract will specify West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil from the Permian Basin, deliverable at Magellan’s East Houston terminal or Enterprise’s ECHO terminal.

title: There's Traditional Energy Funds. Then There's the MLPX ETF
summary: The Global X MLP & Energy Infrastructure ETF (MLPX) offers investors an alternative to traditional energy funds, providing exposure to midstream energy infrastructure MLPs and corporations. MLPX has demonstrated strong performance, being up over 30% in recent months and outperforming other energy indexes due to its midstream focus, tax efficiency, and high income potential. The fund benefits from recovering oil prices and the anticipated economic revival spurred by a COVID-19 vaccine.

title: Halliburton cut 15,000 jobs in 2020
summary: Halliburton, led by CEO Jeff Miller, announced 15,000 job cuts in 2020, a year described as "like no other." This significant reduction reflects broader trends of job losses within the energy sector during that period.

title: Durango’s Brennan Oil Co. switches gasoline supplier
summary: Brennan Oil Co., a 102-year-old family-owned business in Durango, has switched its gasoline supplier from Exxon Mobil Corp. to Marathon Petroleum Corp. The primary reason for the change was Marathon's more beneficial loyalty rewards program, which allows customers to earn points on both fuel and convenience store purchases. This move marks only the third change in suppliers for Brennan Oil Co., which previously used Texaco before its 22-year contract with Exxon Mobil.

title: Population growth will sustain demand for fossil fuels, says Chevron CEO Michael Wirth
summary: Chevron CEO Michael Wirth believes global population growth will sustain demand for fossil fuels for decades, despite efforts to transition to cleaner energy. He highlights Chevron's commitment to address climate change through reducing carbon output, integrating renewables, and investing in new technologies like carbon capture. Wirth also discussed the industry's need for consolidation and Chevron's intent to work constructively with the new U.S. administration.

title: Shell joins Equinor and YPF in Argentina block
summary: Shell has agreed to acquire a 30 percent non-operated interest in the CAN 100 block offshore Argentina from Equinor and YPF. This transaction, pending governmental approval, will result in Equinor and YPF each holding 35 percent equity in the block, with Shell holding the remaining 30 percent. The CAN 100 block, located in the North Argentinian Basin, covers an area of 15,000 km2.

title: Equinor, YPF partner with Shell offshore Argentina
summary: Equinor and YPF have partnered with Shell to farm down 30% non-operated interests in the CAN 100 block in the North Argentinian basin, offshore Argentina. After the transaction, which is pending governmental approval, Equinor and YPF will each hold 35% equity, with Shell holding the remaining 30% in the 15,000 sq km block. This agreement follows Equinor's farm-in to the CAN 100 block and agreement to take over operatorship in October 2019.

title: Investors flee Big Oil as portfolios get drilled
summary: The article details how Big Oil's financial might has been eroding for a decade, with a significant hit in 2020 due to collapsed fuel demand and oil prices. Investment firms and banks are increasingly wary of fossil fuels, with Goldman Sachs allocating more towards renewables, and major U.S. banks withdrawing funding for Arctic drilling. This shift is driven by both environmental concerns and the poor financial performance of the fossil fuel sector compared to growing competitive renewable energy.

title: Oil and Gas Industry Fights New Regulations in Ventura County
summary: The oil and gas industry is fiercely resisting Ventura County's new environmental safety measures through lawsuits and petition drives, arguing the regulations will impact jobs and tax revenue. Companies like Aera Energy and California Resources Corporation face financial difficulties as communities move away from fossil fuels, and are challenging buffer zone requirements, pipeline mandates, and environmental impact reviews for older permits. The industry's lobbying efforts and petition drives have been met with counter-organizing from environmental groups and accusations of misinformation.

title: Max Midstream agrees to pump $360 million into Calhoun Port's expansion plan
summary: Max Midstream is investing $360 million into a public/private partnership with the Calhoun Port Authority to deepen and widen the Matagorda Ship Channel by 2023. This expansion aims to provide an alternative export option for companies, enabling the port to accommodate larger vessels like Aframax and Suezmax. Max Midstream also secured a deal with Phillips 66 to connect the Gray Oak pipeline to the Calhoun Port, granting access to crude from the Permian and Eagle Ford basins.

title: For first time, oil giant Exxon reveals full scope of emissions
authors: Kevin Crowley and Akshat Rathi and Bloomberg
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has for the first time disclosed the full scope of emissions from customers' use of its products, revealing that its 2019 Scope 3 emissions were equivalent to 730 million metric tons of carbon dioxide, comparable to Canada's total emissions. This disclosure follows pressure from investors for greater transparency despite Exxon's previous focus on Scope 1 and 2 emissions. While Exxon announced new targets to reduce emissions per barrel of crude, it has not committed to reducing absolute pollution levels.

title: Exxon Reveals Petroleum Product Emissions Data for First Time
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has for the first time released Scope 3 emissions data, detailing the emissions from customers' use of its petroleum products, totaling 570 million metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent in 2019. While most major oil companies already publish this data, Exxon stated that it does not provide meaningful insight into the company's emission-reduction performance. The company prefers to focus on Scope 1 and 2 emissions, which are within its direct control, and reported a 3.2% reduction in its direct emissions in 2019 compared to 2018.

title: Activist Wins Exxon Board Seats After Questioning Oil Giant’s Climate Strategy
summary: An activist investor, Engine No. 1, won two seats on Exxon Mobil Corp.'s board, marking a significant defeat for the oil giant and its CEO Darren Woods. This victory signals increased pressure on Exxon to address shareholder concerns regarding climate change. The final composition of the board was still unclear as of the preliminary vote count.

title: Exxon Mobil warns investors it’s heading toward a fourth straight quarterly loss
summary: Exxon Mobil is anticipating its fourth consecutive quarterly loss as it struggles to maintain its $15 billion-a-year dividend program. The Irving-based oil giant confirmed a regulatory filing indicating a write-down of up to $20 billion on its upstream assets, alongside smaller non-cash impairments in its refining business. This financial challenge highlights the company's reliance on debt to cover dividends and capital expenditures from operational cash flow.

title: Eastman joins pellet spill reporting, NGO targets broader effort
summary: Eastman Chemical Co. has agreed to public reporting of resin pellet spills, becoming the sixth plastics manufacturer to do so following an agreement with activist group As You Sow. This move is part of As You Sow's broader effort to increase transparency and accountability in the plastics industry regarding microplastic pollution, advocating for widespread adoption of spill reporting, in-transit reporting, and third-party audits. The initiative aims to address the estimated 10 trillion pellets lost annually, pushing for stricter regulations and industry standards.

title: Former Exxon chief Lee Raymond to retire from board of JPMorgan Chase
summary: Lee Raymond, former CEO of ExxonMobil and a long-serving director at JPMorgan Chase, is retiring from the bank's board following pressure from environmental activists. While JPMorgan stated his retirement was unrelated to climate issues, activist groups view it as a win, urging the bank to now overhaul its fossil fuel financing. Raymond had been a director for 33 years and the lead independent director for 19 years.

title: JPMorgan Chase Longtime Board Member Lee Raymond to Leave
summary: Lee Raymond, a longtime lead independent director at JPMorgan Chase & Co. and former Exxon Mobil Corp. chief, is leaving the bank's board at the end of the year. His departure follows a campaign by environmental groups and institutional investors seeking his removal due to climate-change concerns. Mr. Raymond had served on the board for over 30 years.

title: JPMorgan Chase Board Member Lee Raymond to Leave
summary: JPMorgan Chase announced that Lee Raymond, its longtime lead independent director and former Exxon Mobil chief, will be leaving the board at the end of the year. Raymond has served on the board for over 30 years and recently faced a campaign to remove him due to climate-change concerns. He has been the lead independent director since 2001.

title: LNG Prices Rebound to 6-Year High
summary: LNG spot prices in Asia have rebounded to a six-year high, driven by colder weather, production outages, and shipping congestion. This surge, up 564% since April, is expected to persist into early 2021, boosting commodity traders but potentially leading some utilities to switch to cheaper fuels like coal. While the rally may not last past winter, it has significant short-term implications for global gas markets, drawing cargoes away from Europe and reducing the risk of U.S. cancellations.

title: Utility of the Year: NextEra Energy
summary: NextEra Energy was named Utility of the Year for its significant investments in green hydrogen, solar energy, and grid resilience, alongside expanding its renewables project pipeline. The company also showcased strong performance through its Florida Power & Light subsidiary amidst the pandemic and hurricane season, maintaining low residential bills and high reliability. Analysts highlight NextEra's leadership in renewable energy and its disciplined approach to M&A despite some unsuccessful bids.

title: Chevron’s CEO says “action over pledges” will deliver higher returns, lower carbon
summary: Chevron's CEO, Mike Wirth, announced a focus on "action over pledges" to deliver higher returns and lower carbon, distinguishing the company from rivals with long-term emissions targets. Chevron, which has overtaken Exxon Mobil in market value, aims for capital efficiency and will continue to invest in less risky, quicker-to-produce operations rather than following European peers into renewables like wind and solar. The company's carbon goals are tied to reducing methane leaks and emissions intensity, allowing flexibility for future crude output growth.

title: An underperforming Exxon Mobil faces a new climate threat: Activist hedge fund investors
summary: Exxon Mobil is facing a new climate threat from activist hedge fund investors and long-term impact investors focused on sustainability. A newly formed activist investor group, Engine No. 1, plans to seek four board seats at Exxon, supported by pension giant CalSTRS. The activists aim to overhaul Exxon's management and strategy due to its underperformance, significant decline in stock value, and perceived inaction on climate change, while also addressing concerns about the company's dividend.

title: Why We Named Lori Ryerkerk Our 2020 CEO of the Year
summary: D CEO named Lori Ryerkerk, CEO of Celanese Corp., as its 2020 CEO of the Year. Ryerkerk, an energy industry veteran, has made a significant impact since joining the $6.3 billion company in 2019, steering it through major business moves and expanding its diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives. She is recognized for her authentic leadership and commitment to making a difference.

title: Lori Ryerkerk is D CEO’s CEO of the Year
summary: Lori Ryerkerk, CEO of Celanese Corp., has been named D CEO's CEO of the Year for 2020. The article highlights her trailblazing career, commitment to social responsibility, and efforts to advance diversity, inclusion, and corporate citizenship at the $6.3 billion company. It also touches on her experiences as a woman in a male-dominated industry and how motherhood shaped her leadership style.

title: Suncor Energy: The Only Integrated Energy Loser This Week
summary: Suncor Energy (SU) was the sole integrated energy stock to decline this week, falling marginally by 0.43% to $34.52. Despite the minor dip, the stock has been on a strong uptrend since July 2017, rising approximately 23.0% and hitting a 52-week high of $35.18 last week. This week's movement appears to be a correction within its ongoing upward trend, with strong support at its 50-day moving average.

title: Chevron tightens belt again with billions in spending cuts
summary: Chevron Corp announced significant cuts to its long-term capital and exploratory budget, reducing it to $14 billion-$16 billion through 2025 from a prior forecast of up to $22 billion.
