This move reflects the company's expectation of lower energy prices for years and a focus on capital discipline, despite recent acquisitions and in contrast to rival Exxon Mobil's projected spending increase. The 2021 budget details include $11.5 billion for exploration and production and $2.1 billion for refining, with a notable reduction in Permian basin spending.

title: America’s Greenest Energy Giant Isn’t Trying to Save the Planet
summary: NextEra Energy Inc. (NEE), despite its conservative political leanings and past opposition to certain green initiatives, has become the world's largest investor-owned generator of wind and solar power. The company's strategic investments and lobbying efforts position it to significantly benefit from the Biden administration's focus on zero-emissions electricity. NextEra's approach is driven by business interests rather than purely environmental motives, making it a prominent player in the U.S. clean energy transition.

title: ConocoPhillips to lay off 500 Houston workers, company says
summary: ConocoPhillips announced it will lay off approximately 500 workers in Houston as part of a workforce reduction tied to its upcoming acquisition of Concho Resources. The company stated these targeted reductions are necessary to align organizational capacity with future activity levels and maintain competitiveness. Impacted employees will receive advance notice, severance, and outplacement assistance, with severance notifications beginning in February.

title: Exxon Writes Off Record Amount From Value of Assets Amid Energy Market Downturn
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced a record write-down of $17 billion to $20 billion in natural gas assets, primarily in the U.S., Canada, and Argentina, marking its largest-ever impairment. This move acknowledges past strategic errors and comes after a period where Exxon resisted such write-downs despite adjustments by rivals. The company continues to project long-term demand for oil, even as climate concerns mount.

title: How wind and solar toppled Exxon from its place as America’s top energy company
summary: NextEra Energy, a company built on wind and solar farms, briefly unseated Exxon as America's most valuable energy company in early October, demonstrating the growing market ascendance of renewable energy. This shift, partly due to the pandemic's impact on oil majors, highlights NextEra's success in leveraging energy regulation changes and its dual business model of regulated natural gas utility and a deregulated renewables provider. Despite a mixed environmental record, NextEra's strategy offers a glimpse into a future where clean energy titans lead.

title: Exxon Mobil steps back from plan to increase spending, preparing to slash assets book value
summary: Exxon Mobil is reversing its prior strategy to increase spending for oil and gas production, instead planning to cut its capital expenditures and preparing for a significant write-down of asset book value. The Texas oil giant, having experienced over $2.3 billion in losses this year, expects to slash its assets by up to $20 billion in the fourth quarter and has revised its spending outlook for the next five years. This shift comes as a course correction for CEO Darren Woods, following the negative impact of the coronavirus pandemic on fossil fuel demand.

title: Exclusive: Exxon and Total in talks over Mozambique LNG resource-sharing deal - sources
summary: ExxonMobil and Total are negotiating a resource-sharing deal for their massive LNG projects in Mozambique to increase gas extraction from a shared field and reduce costs. The talks, which also involve the Mozambican government, aim to optimize development plans amidst falling oil prices and a worsening security situation in the region. Success in these negotiations is particularly crucial for Exxon's delayed Rovuma LNG project.

title: Imperial Oil set to end Syncrude services contract as Suncor become operator
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. announced it will relinquish its 14-year contract to provide operational, technical, and business management services to Syncrude Canada Ltd. by the end of 2021. This decision comes as Suncor Energy Inc., holding a 58.74% stake in Syncrude, is set to take over as the operator of the oilsands mine and upgrader. The transition is expected to improve efficiency through bidirectional pipelines connecting Suncor’s Base Plant and Syncrude’s operations, with Suncor anticipating annual cost-saving synergies of approximately $300 million.

title: General Electric’s Mission, Vision, and Strategy
summary: General Electric (GE) is undergoing a strategic transformation to shift from a broad conglomerate to a focused industrial leader. This involves reshaping its portfolio by acquiring businesses like Alstom’s Power and Grid, spinning off entities like Synchrony Financial, and divesting non-strategic segments such as its appliance business. The goal is to achieve 75% of operating EPS from industrial businesses and return $50 billion to investors.

title: Graphical Representation of General Electric’s Business Model
summary: This article outlines General Electric's business model, highlighting its two main divisions: industrials and finance services, which contributed 91% and 9% respectively to its consolidated 2015 earnings. It details GE's industrial backlog, geographic reach, core strengths, and competitiveness, along with its 2016 operating EPS target. The company's strategic focus on technology, growth markets, and services is emphasized.

title: How Does Saudi Aramco’s Production Compare to Its Peers?
summary: This article examines Saudi Aramco's crude oil and natural gas production in 2015, comparing it to other major oil producers like ExxonMobil, Chevron, Royal Dutch Shell, and BP. Saudi Aramco's production accounted for a significant portion of OPEC's total output, highlighting its influence within the organization and its leading position globally. The article also touches upon Saudi Aramco's plans for future natural gas supply expansion.

title: Why climate change is getting the attention of world's wealthy investors
summary: Wealthy investors are increasingly focusing on climate change as a fundamental investment theme, driven by significant economic opportunities rather than political beliefs. Billionaires like Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk are leading the way, but this trend is also widespread among ultra-wealthy investors who see renewables becoming cheaper and creating vast capital investment opportunities. Despite concerns about short-term political uncertainties or the intermittency of renewable energy, experts believe the investment case for green technologies and addressing climate risk in portfolios remains strong, with potential for comparable performance to traditional investments.

title: Carbon Capture and Storage Market to See 48.39% Year-Over-Year Growth in 2020 Amid COVID-19 Spread | Technavio
summary: The global carbon capture and storage market is projected to grow by 39.94 million tons during 2020-2024, despite a decelerating CAGR of over 16% due to the impact of COVID-19. The report highlights market fragmentation with key players including Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Babcock & Wilcox Enterprises Inc., and Chevron Corp., and discusses the negative growth expected in 2020-2024 due to the pandemic's effect on energy demand and the utilities industry. It also provides a detailed analysis of the market's competitive landscape, growth drivers, challenges, and regional prospects.

title: 3 Oil ETFs to Buy That Are Gushing Higher: XOP XLE OIH
summary: This article recommends three oil ETFs (XLE, XOP, OIH) to buy, citing a recent rotation from growth to value stocks and positive vaccine news driving money back into the energy sector. It highlights the tumultuous year for oil prices and suggests that a recovery is underway, detailing the characteristics and appropriate trades for each ETF. The ETFs offer varying exposure to the energy market, from large-cap integrated oil companies to more volatile exploration and production firms and oil services companies.
banner_image: https://investorplace.com/2020/11/3-oil-etfs-to-buy-that-are-gushing-higher/Source: Shutterstock (Note: Actual image URL needs to be found from webpage inspection - this is a placeholder)

title: Sasol wraps up $12.8B petrochemical complex in Lake Charles
Woodside Stops Talks to Sell Offshore Project Stake to Chinese Firms over Diplomatic Row
summary: Woodside Energy halted discussions to sell stakes in a gas field and LNG project to Chinese companies due to the ongoing diplomatic tensions between Australia and China. CEO Peter Coleman expressed disappointment but hopes to revive talks once relations improve, noting that existing partnerships with Chinese companies in other regions remain unaffected. The diplomatic row has impacted various Australian exports but has not yet affected LNG shipments to China, according to research.

title: How One Firm Drove Influence Campaigns Nationwide for Big Oil (Published 2020)
summary: FTI Consulting, a global firm, designed and ran numerous influence campaigns nationwide for major oil and gas companies, often obscuring their involvement. These campaigns created seemingly grass-roots movements and websites like Texans for Natural Gas and the Arctic Energy Center to promote fossil fuels and counter climate activism. FTI also monitored environmental activists and created fake online personas, with former employees revealing that content from sites like Energy In Depth was directed by clients such as Exxon Mobil.

title: Eni and HitecVision form Nordic renewable energy venture
summary: Italian energy company Eni and Norwegian private equity group HitecVision have established a joint venture named Vaargroenn to develop renewable energy projects in the Nordic region. The venture, 69.6% owned by Eni, aims to install 1 gigawatt of electricity capacity by 2030, initially focusing on offshore wind in Norway. This initiative is part of Eni's broader decarbonization strategy, building on their existing cooperation in oil through the Vaar Energi joint venture.

title: Rising Market Cap Fuels Acquisition Ambitions For US Renewable Energy Firms
summary: The rising market capitalization of US renewable energy firms like NextEra Energy is fueling their acquisition ambitions, allowing them to use stock to purchase competitors. This trend highlights the growing momentum in the renewable energy sector compared to traditional energy giants. The article also touches upon the potential for similar developments in India, despite differences in capital market access for renewable developers.

title: Comstock Ramps Haynesville Activity in Anticipation of Higher Natural Gas Prices
summary: Comstock Resources Inc. is increasing its activity in the Haynesville Shale, adding two drilling rigs and accelerating well completions, in anticipation of higher natural gas prices. The company aims to capitalize on increased LNG exports and a recovery in natural gas prices following a warm winter and low production levels. Despite a challenging third quarter with a net loss due to hedging, Comstock expects to boost capital spending and production to take advantage of improved market conditions in early 2021.

title: Ralph Cunningham Obituary - Houston, TX
summary: Ralph S. Cunningham Sr. passed away on November 7, 2020, at the age of 80 in Houston, Texas. He was a distinguished chemical engineer with a long career in the energy industry, holding executive positions at companies like Exxon and Huntsman Corporation, and serving on several company boards. Cunningham was remembered for his brilliant mind, compassionate heart, deep faith, generosity, and strong devotion to his family and various organizations.

title: Kirby gets energized by alternative energy
summary: Kirby Corp, traditionally associated with fossil fuels, is shifting its business focus towards alternative and clean energy solutions due to "demand destruction" from COVID-19 and a growing emphasis on decarbonization and ESG factors. The company plans to expand its involvement in transporting alternative fuels, building electric-powered fracturing units, and supporting offshore wind projects to generate new revenues and maintain growth despite declines in traditional markets.

title: Enbridge Wins Natural Gas Pipeline Duel with TC Over Traffic to LNG Canada
summary: Enbridge Inc. has secured a victory in a pipeline dispute with TC Energy Corp. after the Canada Energy Regulator (CER) approved a C$25 million ($19 million) flow meter for Enbridge’s Westcoast network. This approval allows Enbridge to relay up to 1.2 Bcf/d into the supply artery for the Shell-led LNG Canada project, solidifying its position to serve the first Canadian liquefied natural gas export terminal on the Pacific coast. The CER's decision favored open competition in the Montney Shale region and dismissed TC's demand for an inquiry into the effects of Enbridge's gain on Western Canadian pipeline traffic and tolls.

title: Colombia Inches Closer to Becoming Second South American Nation to Use Fracking
summary: Colombia is moving forward with hydraulic fracturing (fracking) pilot projects, with contracts for four projects in the Middle Magdalena and Cesar Ranchería basins to be awarded by the end of November. This initiative aims to assess the technical, operational, and environmental aspects of fracking in the country, potentially making Colombia the second South American nation after Argentina to use the technique commercially. Companies like ExxonMobil, ConocoPhillips, and Ecopetrol SA have expressed interest, with drilling expected to begin by late 2021 to inform a definitive government policy.

title: Hundreds of coal mining jobs to end as TransAlta switches to natural gas
summary: TransAlta Corp. announced it will end operations at its Highvale thermal coal mine by the end of 2021, four years earlier than planned, as it transitions to natural gas for all its Canadian coal-fired plants. This decision will result in hundreds of job losses, though 40 to 50 people will remain for reclamation work expected to last about 20 years. The company cites the economics of producing power from coal with the carbon tax as a primary driver for the accelerated transition.

title: Underwater Pioneer Lad Handelman Dies at Santa Barbara Home
summary: Lad Handelman, a pioneer in deep-water diving and offshore oilfield construction, passed away at his Santa Barbara home on October 26. He began his career as an abalone diver and went on to found California Divers, which evolved into Oceaneering International. Handelman was also known for his philanthropic efforts, including marine preservation and support for those with spinal injuries, and despite a debilitating accident, continued to lead his company and contribute to various causes.

title: Exxon’s climate fix is algae. Experts say it won’t work
summary: Exxon Mobil has invested in algae-based biofuels for over a decade, promoting it as a solution for climate change and reduced emissions, particularly for commercial transportation. However, experts and critics largely dismiss this as "greenwashing," arguing the technology is too expensive and impractical for large-scale fuel production, especially compared to Exxon's continued massive investments in oil and gas extraction. The company's spending on algae research pales in comparison to its advertising budget, and other major oil companies are pursuing different renewable strategies.

title: Convert to Natural Gas
summary: This article from National Fuel Gas Company promotes converting to natural gas for WNY Residences. It highlights the benefits of natural gas, including its affordability, efficiency, reliability, environmental advantages (less pollution), and its ability to add value to homes. The company provides options for both new and existing customers to convert.

title: Dwindling Oil Demand: 14,000 ExxonMobil staff to lose jobs
summary: ExxonMobil is set to cut its global workforce by 15%, equating to about 14,000 employees and contractors, over the next two years. This decision comes as the COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted global crude oil demand and prices, leading major oil producers like Shell, Chevron, and BP to also announce significant job reductions. The cuts are part of CEO Darren Woods' efforts to curtail spending and address the company's recent quarterly losses.

title: ExxonMobil to cut 14,000 global jobs as Covid-19 pandemic hurts energy demand
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced plans to cut approximately 14,000 global jobs, including contractors, which accounts for about 15% of its workforce, due to the severe impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on energy demand and prices. The job cuts are part of a global reorganisation and come after the company reported significant losses in the first half of the year. This move follows similar workforce reductions by other major energy companies like Royal Dutch Shell, BP, and Chevron.

title: Job cut nation: Exxon Mobil to lay off 1,900 US employees
summary: Exxon Mobil announced it would lay off about 1,900 employees in the United States, primarily from its Houston, Texas office, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on energy demand and prices. The company has been cutting costs, promising to shed over $10 billion in project spending and reduce operating expenses by 15 percent, after significant losses earlier in the year. Despite the layoffs and financial challenges, Exxon confirmed it would maintain its quarterly shareholder dividend payments.

title: Exxon to cut 14,000 jobs as pandemic hits oil demand
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced plans to cut approximately 15% of its global workforce, amounting to about 14,000 jobs, due to the severe impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on energy demand and prices. This includes deep white-collar staff reductions in the United States, following more than $10 billion in budget cuts this year. Other major oil companies like Royal Dutch Shell, BP, and Chevron are also implementing significant workforce reductions.

title: Exxon Mobil to keep dividend flat for first time since 1982
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced it would keep its fourth-quarter dividend flat at 87 cents per share, marking the first time since 1982 that the U.S. oil producer has not raised its shareholder payout. The decision comes amidst sharp declines in energy prices and demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to projected full-year losses for the company. While the dividend is maintained for now, analysts express doubts about its long-term sustainability if demand doesn't fully recover.

title: How NextEra became America’s most valuable energy company
summary: NextEra has emerged as America's most valuable energy company, surpassing traditional oil giants, by strategically transitioning towards natural gas and renewables. This shift, driven by declining costs for wind and solar and government mandates, has proven highly prescient and profitable. The company's focus on utility operations and significant investments in renewable energy infrastructure have solidified its leading position in the evolving energy landscape.

title: Focus: Chevron bets on Middle East gas riches and reconciliation
summary: Chevron is strategically shifting its natural gas focus to the Middle East, betting on regional reconciliation to capitalize on growing demand for cleaner fuels. This move, highlighted by their acquisition of Noble Energy and its stake in Israel's Leviathan field, signifies a pivot away from U.S. shale and an investment in an area with significant gas reserves despite existing political risks. The company aims to supply gas to Europe and Asia, where demand for natural gas as a complement to renewables is projected to rise.

title: Exclusive: GM, Ford knew about climate change 50 years ago
summary: A monthslong investigation by E&E News reveals that scientists at General Motors and Ford Motor Co. knew as early as the 1960s that car emissions caused climate change. Despite this internal knowledge, both companies engaged in decades of political lobbying to undermine efforts to reduce emissions and invested heavily in gas-guzzling vehicles while financially supporting groups that cast doubt on climate science. The transportation sector, largely driven by cars and trucks, remains the leading source of planet-warming pollution in the United States today.

title: ExxonMobil Deploys QR Codes And NFC Tags for Streamlined Mobile Payment at the Pump
summary: ExxonMobil is implementing QR codes and NFC tags at over 11,500 U.S. stations to enable streamlined mobile payments with Apple Pay and Google Pay. This system leverages Apple App Clips for iPhone users without the ExxonMobil app and provides a web-based solution for Android users, enhancing contactless payment options at the pump. The initiative is part of ExxonMobil's ongoing efforts to innovate and offer secure, convenient payment methods, building on prior contactless payment solutions like "Alexa, Pay for Gas."

title: Stock Wars: ExxonMobil Vs. NextEra, A Battle Of Old Vs. New In Energy
summary: This article examines the shift in the energy sector with NextEra Energy Inc. surpassing ExxonMobil in market capitalization, highlighting a battle between old fossil fuel companies and new clean energy providers. It compares the financials and stock performance of both companies, noting ExxonMobil's declining value and NextEra's significant growth, especially in the context of increasing clean energy investments.

title: Exxon Mobil 'very close' to disclosing US job cuts
summary: Exxon Mobil CEO Darren Woods announced that the company is "very close" to completing workforce appraisals in the U.S. and Canada, with job cuts expected to be unveiled soon. These reductions are part of a plan to increase competitiveness and respond to a "devastating impact" on oil demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has significantly strained the company's finances and dividend obligations.

title: ExxonMobil plans to Layoff 1,600 staff
summary: ExxonMobil announced plans to lay off an unspecified number of employees globally, with a specific focus on 1,600 in Europe, as low oil prices force the company to delay major projects. CEO Darren Woods defended the company's focus on fossil fuels, despite a significant drop in stock value and industry-wide struggles. The company, which normally produces about 500,000 barrels of crude per day, is making efforts to increase efficiency while maintaining its long-term investment strategy in traditional energy sources.

title: U.S. oil giant Exxon set to announce layoffs in Canada
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is nearing the completion of workforce appraisals in the United States and Canada and plans to announce job cuts, as disclosed by its chief executive in an email to employees. The company has faced significant financial losses, including nearly $1.7 billion US in the first half of the fiscal year, and is implementing cuts to increase competitiveness amidst a COVID-19 induced decline in oil demand. Despite these measures, the CEO stated that further reductions are necessary due to ongoing significant headwinds.

title: Exxon Mobil to workers: Job cuts are coming
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced job cuts due to low oil prices and the impact of COVID-19 on global fuel demand, forcing delays in major projects. CEO Darren Woods stated these are difficult times requiring tough decisions to make the organization more efficient. This move follows similar struggles among other U.S. energy producers and comes after Exxon slashed its capital spending budget.

title: Chevron and Exxon boost campaign donations to Democrats
summary: Chevron Corp (CVX.N) and Exxon Mobil Corp (XOM.N), the two largest US energy firms, have increased their share of campaign donations to Democrats in 2020, according to recent filings. This represents a strategic shift for these oil giants, as Joe Biden leads in the polls, leading them to diversify political contributions beyond their traditional Republican support. Despite this, the majority of fossil fuel donations still overwhelmingly favor Republican and conservative groups.

title: ConocoPhillips Doubles Down On The Permian Basin And Fracking With Concho Acquisition
summary: ConocoPhillips announced its acquisition of Concho Resources for $9.7 billion in an all-stock transaction, marking the largest U.S. shale-focused deal of 2020. This acquisition significantly expands ConocoPhillips' Permian Basin holdings, aiming for annual cost savings and a strong asset base below $30 per barrel WTI. The move signals strong confidence in the future of U.S. shale despite industry headwinds and political uncertainties.

title: ConocoPhillips to buy Concho Resources for $9.7 billion in 2020's top shale deal
summary: ConocoPhillips announced its acquisition of Permian-focused driller Concho Resources for $9.7 billion, marking the largest shale deal of 2020. This all-stock, low-premium transaction reflects a trend of consolidation within the energy sector as companies grapple with weak crude prices and high debts amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The acquisition will significantly expand ConocoPhillips' presence in the Permian Basin and position it as the largest U.S. independent oil producer.

title: ConocoPhillips Adopts Paris-Aligned Climate Risk Framework to Meet Net-Zero Operational Emissions Ambition by 2050
summary: ConocoPhillips has adopted a comprehensive Paris-aligned climate risk framework to guide its management of climate-related risks and stakeholder expectations through the energy transition. The company has set an ambition to achieve net-zero operational emissions by 2050 and revised its greenhouse gas emissions intensity reduction target to 35-45% by 2030. This strategy also aims to meet global energy demand sustainably and deliver competitive returns by focusing on cost of supply and utilizing a scenario-based strategic planning process.

title: U.S. oil majors pitch more campaign cash to Democrats as frack battle looms
summary: U.S. oil majors Chevron Corp and Exxon Mobil Corp have increased their campaign donations to Democrats for the current election cycle, amidst a looming battle over fracking and concerns about renewable energy policies. This shift comes despite the vast majority of oil and gas donations still favoring Republican candidates and conservative causes. The article highlights the strategic donations by energy companies as Democratic challenger Joseph Biden gains ground with an agenda focused on renewable energy and an end to new fracking permits on federal lands.

title: Argentine gas companies plan to invest US$400mn in pipeline expansions
summary: Argentine gas companies Transportadora de Gas del Norte (TGN) and Transportadora de Gas del Sur (TGS) are planning to invest around US$400mn to expand pipeline capacity from the Vaca Muerta formation and southern provinces. The companies are in discussions with gas regulator Enargas regarding details like fee collection and loan repayment. The government plans to utilize equipment acquired in 2015 for previous expansion efforts to reduce investment costs.

title: Northern Lights is innovating for the future of carbon transport and storage
summary: The article details the Northern Lights project, a partnership between the Norwegian government, Equinor, Shell, and Total, focused on scaling carbon capture and storage (CCS) across Europe. Microsoft has joined the project as a technology partner to integrate its digital expertise and explore the use of the Northern Lights facility as part of its own carbon capture projects. The initiative aims to create a permanent storage solution for CO2 in the North Sea and develop a new business ecosystem around carbon management to achieve a net-zero carbon future.

title: Personnel Moves: ExxonMobil VP and General Counsel To Retire
summary: Randall Ebner, VP and General Counsel for Exxon Mobil Corp., is retiring, and Craig Morford will succeed him. This article also details several other significant personnel changes across various companies in the Dallas area, including new hires and promotions at Dallas Area Habitat for Humanity, DuWest Realty, Augustine Agency, OneDay, Imaginuity, Fermata Energy, HudsonLake, and Agents National Title Insurance.

title: ExxonMobil Loses $225 Billion In Market Cap Against Chevron
summary: ExxonMobil's market capitalization has significantly declined, losing $225 billion against Chevron, leading to its replacement by NextEra Energy as the largest U.S. energy company. While both companies faced a tough decade, Chevron's strategic decisions and fewer missteps allowed it to better maintain its value and dividend payments compared to ExxonMobil's costly acquisitions and struggles. Despite ExxonMobil's brief bounce back, its enterprise value remains comfortably ahead of Chevron and NextEra, indicating its total asset value.

title: Wind and solar producer tops Exxon as most valuable U.S. energy company
summary: NextEra Energy, a wind and solar power producer, eclipsed ExxonMobil to become the most valuable U.S. energy company with a value of $143.8 billion. This milestone highlights the significant shift towards clean energy, contrasting with Exxon's declining value and stock performance. NextEra's growth is driven by high profit margins and investor confidence in renewable energy, despite government policies favoring fossil fuels.

title: Exxon to cut 1,600 jobs across Europe as oil rout weighs
summary: U.S. oil giant Exxon Mobil announced plans to reduce its European workforce by up to 1,600 employees across its affiliates by the end of 2021 as part of a global review. This decision comes as the COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted demand for its products and caused crude prices to tank, forcing oil majors to cut jobs and spending. Exxon previously announced voluntary layoffs in Australia, indicating global job cuts would continue into 2021.

title: How NextEra Overtook ExxonMobil As The Largest U.S. Energy Company
summary: NextEra Energy surpassed ExxonMobil in market capitalization, highlighting a significant shift in the U.S. energy sector. This divergence is attributed to NextEra's aggressive investment in renewable energy and strong financial performance, contrasted with ExxonMobil's struggles due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on energy demand. The article details how NextEra's strategy, particularly its focus on wind and solar power, has led to exceptional returns, positioning it as a leading energy company.

title: Noble Energy shareholders approve $4.1 billion sale to Chevron
summary: Noble Energy shareholders have approved the company's $4.1 billion sale to Chevron Corp, making Chevron the second-largest U.S. shale oil producer and expanding its international natural gas reserves. The all-stock deal also includes $8 billion in debt assumed by Chevron and represents the first major energy deal since the global fuel demand was impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. Despite the deal's approval, only 60% of shareholders voted in favor of merger-related executive payouts, following recommendations against "excessive" executive payments.

title: Oil loses 4% after Trump gets coronavirus and economies wobble
summary: Oil prices fell more than 4% on Friday, marking a second weekly decline, after U.S. President Donald Trump tested positive for COVID-19, causing market jitters. The drop was also attributed to a weak U.S. unemployment report and rising global crude output threatening the market's recovery. Both Brent and U.S. crude benchmarks saw significant weekly losses as increased supply from OPEC members and U.S. energy firms further weighed on prices.

title: U.S. oil refiner Marathon Petroleum cuts 12% of staff because of pandemic
summary: Marathon Petroleum Corp, the largest U.S. oil refiner, is reducing its workforce by 12%, or 2,050 jobs, due to a continued decline in fuel consumption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The company expects to incur a charge of up to $175 million to third-quarter earnings as a result of these job cuts and refinery closures. This move is part of a broader trend of cost-cutting and layoffs across the oil industry amid weak prices and a global glut of fuel.

title: BlackRock, Vanguard, Transamerica roll out latest ESG funds
summary: BlackRock, Vanguard, and Transamerica have launched new ESG funds to meet the growing investor demand for sustainable investing options. These funds apply ESG screens to traditional indexes, resulting in slightly higher costs and altered stock compositions compared to their non-ESG counterparts. For example, BlackRock's iShares ESG Screened S&P 500 ETF (XVV) removes companies like Exxon and Chevron from the standard S&P 500 index.

title: BlackRock, Vanguard, Transamerica roll out latest ESG funds
summary: BlackRock, Vanguard, and Transamerica have launched new funds that incorporate environmental, social, and governance (ESG) screens, catering to the increasing investor demand for sustainable investing options. These new ESG-focused funds, while slightly more expensive than traditional index funds, aim to provide targeted exposure to ESG objectives. By applying these screens, they alter the composition of standard indexes, leading to differences in holdings and potentially performance compared to their non-ESG counterparts.

title: Petra Nova is closed: What it means for carbon capture
summary: The Petra Nova carbon capture project, one of the world's largest, is offline due to low oil prices, prompting reevaluation of carbon capture project revenue streams. While its economics are cautionary, carbon capture remains important for decarbonization strategies, especially with federal tax credits like 45Q. Developers are exploring dedicated storage options and CO2 pipeline networks to de-risk future projects from oil price volatility.

title: R&D Council of NJ Announces 2020 Thomas Edison Patent Award Winners
summary: The Research & Development Council of New Jersey announced the 2020 Thomas Edison Patent Award winners and special individual honorees. Awards will be presented on November 12, 2020, to 14 companies and institutions, recognizing innovations from biomaterials to water-efficient toilets. Special awards will be given to Dr. Roger Perlmutter of Merck for the Chairman's Award, Dr. Joachim Messing (posthumously) for the Science and Technology Medal, and Dr. Dawood Farahi for the Educator of the Year Award.

title: Exclusive: -EQT bids for Chevron U.S. shale-gas assets in Appalachia - sources
summary: EQT Corp., the largest U.S. natural gas producer, has reportedly placed a $750 million bid for Chevron Corp.'s Appalachia shale gas properties and a pipeline stake. Chevron is currently evaluating bids for these assets, which it had previously taken an $8.17 billion charge to write down their value. This potential acquisition comes as EQT views Appalachia shale as a "buyer's market" and an opportunity for consolidation.

title: Top Comcast exec to become lead independent director at JPMorgan Chase
summary: Comcast Corp. executive Steve Burke has been appointed as the lead independent director of JPMorgan Chase & Co. Burke will be succeeding former ExxonMobil CEO Lee R. Raymond in this role. This move brings a prominent media executive into a key leadership position at one of the largest financial institutions.

title: Imperial Oil Restarts Oilsands Output from Kearl After Pipeline Leak
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. has restarted production at its 220,000 b/d Kearl oilsands mine after Inter Pipeline Ltd. repaired a leak that had halted operations. The leak, which occurred in a 238,000 b/d Inter Pipeline conduit called Polaris, spilled an estimated 550 barrels of bitumen and disrupted the supply of condensate essential for bitumen processing. The full production impact of the outage is still being assessed by Imperial Oil, a company 70% owned by ExxonMobil.

title: Imperial ramps up Kearl oil sands mine output after diluent pipeline restored
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. is resuming normal production at its Kearl oil sands mine after its main diluent supply pipeline was restored following a leak. The company had halted operations at the 240,000 barrels per day facility after a leak was detected in the Polaris pipeline in late August. Analysts estimate that the two-week production loss will reduce Imperial's third-quarter output from Kearl.

title: Talos Says Its Gulf of Mexico Acreage Unaffected by Trump's Order
summary: Talos Energy confirmed that its operations in the Gulf of Mexico are unaffected by President Trump's executive order extending a moratorium on oil and gas operations in other parts of the Gulf and Atlantic. The company stated that 100% of its federal waters assets are in the Central and Western Gulf of Mexico Planning Areas, which are not subject to the order. Talos also highlighted the significant economic contributions of the U.S. Gulf of Mexico oil and gas industry.

title: Veronica Foley Is Precision Drilling’s ‘Key to Success’
summary: Veronica Foley, Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Corporate Secretary at Precision Drilling, is honored for her role in successfully defending the company against a major Fair Labor Standards Act lawsuit and securing shareholder approval for a critical executive compensation plan. Foley's strategic decision-making and leadership during these challenging times for Precision Drilling, and the oil and gas industry as a whole, have earned her significant recognition, including the 2020 Houston Corporate Counsel Business Litigation of the Year award. The article also highlights her personal journey and professional philosophy as an in-house counsel.

title: Exxon Refinery Wage and Hour Lawsuit Results in $4M Settlement
summary: ExxonMobil, PBF Energy Ltd., and Torrance Refining Co. agreed to a $4.4 million settlement in a class action lawsuit filed by workers. The lawsuit alleged that the companies denied meal and rest breaks and miscalculated payroll for employees working 12-hour shifts. The settlement is expected to cover 335 workers, with each potentially receiving approximately $9,500.

title: Exclusive: -Exxon downsizes global empire as Wall Street worries about dividend
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp faces a projected $48 billion shortfall through 2021 due to ill-timed investments and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to deep cuts in staff and projects. The financial strain has raised concerns among Wall Street investors about the sustainability of Exxon's once-sacrosanct dividend. The company is undertaking a worldwide review to cut expenses, including staff reviews and benefit reductions, while analysts believe a dividend cut is increasingly likely amidst falling oil prices and weakened demand.

title: Using Foreign Funds to Correct for a Sliding Dollar
summary: The dollar has recently been in decline relative to other foreign currencies, primarily due to low interest rates and a shift in the Fed's monetary policy. This can have varying implications for investors' portfolios depending on their holdings. Foreign stock and bond funds, particularly unhedged ones, can benefit from a weaker dollar, while U.S. companies with significant foreign revenue may also see improved profits.

title: ConocoPhillips Drops Request for Oil and Gas Flaring in West Texas After Challenge from Clean Air Groups
summary: ConocoPhillips has withdrawn its request for flaring permit extensions at 41 oil and gas sites in West Texas following a challenge from clean air advocacy groups. The company cited "operational changes" that made the extensions unnecessary, after the groups objected to the permits due to concerns about air quality and public health impacts from the released pollutants. This decision is seen by environmental advocates as a victory that underscores the need for stricter oversight from the Texas Railroad Commission on flaring activities.

title: ExxonMobil Unit Shuts Oil Sands Mine After Pipeline Spill
summary: ExxonMobil's Imperial Oil shut down its Kearl oil-sands mine in northern Alberta after a spill from a pipeline supplying diluent to the operation. This disruption, caused by a leak in Inter Pipeline Ltd.'s Polaris system, adds to the challenges faced by Canadian crude producers already struggling with infrastructure limitations and reduced demand. The shutdown directly impacts Imperial Oil and could affect other producers like Husky, BP, and Cenovus, though Imperial is pursuing mitigation steps.

title: REFILE-Exxon Mobil offers voluntary redundancy for Australian employees
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced a voluntary redundancy program for its Australian employees across various cities to navigate "unprecedented" market conditions. This move follows earlier reports that the U.S. oil company was preparing significant spending and job cuts to preserve its shareholder dividend amidst quarterly losses. An Exxon spokesman in Australia declined to comment on the percentage of staff targeted for reduction.

title: PetroChina and Ovintiv end joint venture deal, agree to split Alberta assets
summary: PetroChina Canada Inc. and Ovintiv Inc. have mutually terminated their eight-year joint venture in Alberta's Duvernay shale assets, agreeing to split the acreage and production equally. PetroChina Canada will create a new operating team to manage its share, with Ovintiv continuing operations until PetroChina is ready. This move signifies a major step in PetroChina's upstream capabilities in Canada.

title: What Dow Changes Mean For ETF Investors
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) is undergoing a significant shakeup, with Exxon, Pfizer, and Raytheon Technologies being replaced by Salesforce, Amgen, and Honeywell. These changes are designed to diversify the index and better reflect the American economy, particularly after Apple's stock split impacted the technology sector's weighting. For ETF investors tracking the DJIA, such as through DIA, these adjustments will inevitably alter portfolio returns and exposure.

title: Exxon Presses for Guyana Approval of Third Offshore Project
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is urging Guyana's new government to approve its third offshore oil project, Payara, which has been under review amid political uncertainty. The project, which is part of the Stabroek block operated by a consortium including Hess Corp and CNOOC Ltd, aims to develop over 8 billion barrels of recoverable resources. Guyana's new president, Irfaan Ali, has expressed concerns about the Production Sharing Agreement's generosity and plans to implement stricter local content and labor rules.

title: Exxon Mobil replaced by a software stock after 92 years in the Dow is a 'sign of the times'
summary: Exxon Mobil, a Dow component for 92 years, has been replaced by software company Salesforce, marking a significant shift in the index. This change, alongside Amgen and Honeywell International replacing Pfizer and Raytheon Technologies, reflects the declining prominence of the energy sector and the corresponding rise of technology stocks. The move is seen as a "sign of the times," highlighting the faltering energy industry against a backdrop of strong tech growth.

title: Exxon yanked from Dow after nearly a century
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. was removed from the Dow Jones Industrial Average after more than 90 years, a symbolic move reflecting the oil industry's recent struggles, including falling oil prices and climate concerns. This change saw SalesForce.com Inc., Amgen Inc., and Honeywell International Inc. replace Exxon, Pfizer Inc., and Raytheon Technologies Corp. While Exxon maintains its focus on shareholder value, critics argue the company is failing to adapt to a changing energy market.

title: Big Oil, meet Big Green
summary: The term "Supermajor" is increasingly shifting from large oil companies to major renewable energy producers like NextEra Energy, Iberdrola SA, and Ørsted A/S, whose valuations now exceed traditional oil giants such as Royal Dutch Shell and BP. This transition is driven by the economic downturn affecting oil stocks and the rising attractiveness of renewable projects due to falling costs and climate targets, prompting oil majors to invest heavily in green energy or face acquisitions. Experts predict a reallocation of capital from fossil fuels to renewables is essential for meeting net-zero emissions targets.

title: Exxon Mobil dropped from the Dow after nearly a century, replaced by Salesforce
summary: Exxon Mobil, a Dow Jones Industrial Average member since 1928, is being removed from the blue-chip index and replaced by Salesforce.com. Drug company Pfizer and Raytheon Technologies are also being replaced by Amgen and Honeywell respectively. These changes, effective August 31, were prompted by Apple's stock split and aim to better reflect the American economy.

title: Dow kicks out Exxon, Pfizer, Raytheon in biggest shake-up since 2013
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average is undergoing its biggest reshuffling in seven years, with Exxon Mobil Corp., Pfizer Inc., and Raytheon Technologies Corp. being replaced by Salesforce.com, Amgen Inc., and Honeywell International. This change reflects the declining influence of commodity companies and the rising dominance of technology firms, a trend amplified by Apple's stock split which reduced the sway of computer and software companies in the price-weighted index. The exclusions highlight a significant shift in the US economy and stock market, particularly the underrepresentation of technology in the Dow compared to other indexes.

title: Salesforce to replace Exxon in Dow Jones Industrial Average index next week
summary: Salesforce.com Inc, Amgen Inc, and Honeywell International Inc are set to join the Dow Jones Industrial Average index on August 31, replacing Exxon Mobil Corp, Pfizer Inc, and Raytheon Technologies Corp. This change follows Apple Inc's stock split, which prompted a rebalancing of the index's representation in the information technology sector.

title: Salesforce to replace Exxon in Dow Jones Industrial Average index next week
summary: Salesforce.com Inc, Amgen Inc, and Honeywell International Inc are set to replace Exxon Mobil Corp, Pfizer Inc, and Raytheon Technologies Corp in the Dow Jones Industrial Average index starting August 31. This change follows Apple Inc's stock split, which would have reduced the index's weight in the information technology sector.

title: Exxon Limits Guyana Output Due to Gas Injection Issues
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp has limited output at its Guyana offshore project to 100,000 barrels-per-day due to ongoing issues with natural gas reinjection. Mechanical problems with gas compressing equipment are preventing full reinjection, prompting Exxon to reduce production to avoid excessive flaring of natural gas. The company aims to restore full capacity of 120,000 bpd once the gas handling system is fully commissioned.

title: Brazil: Total Launches Phase 3 On the Giant Mero Field Development| Total.com
summary: Total and its partners have approved the investment for the third phase of the Mero project in Brazil's deep offshore, targeting a liquid treatment capacity of 180,000 barrels per day by 2024. This decision aligns with Total's strategy to develop giant projects in Brazil's deep-offshore, aiming for competitive production costs and a target of 150,000 barrels per day in Brazil by 2025. The Mero field, part of the Libra Consortium, has significant oil resources estimated at 3 to 4 billion barrels.

title: Shale driller Chaparral Energy files for bankruptcy due to pandemic woes
summary: Chaparral Energy Inc, an Oklahoma oil and gas producer, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on oil prices. This marks the second time the company has sought bankruptcy protection, previously doing so during the 2014-16 oil price slump. The filing follows warnings from the company about its ability to continue as a going concern amidst a historic plunge in commodity prices.

title: Gaurdie Banister Jr. elected to Dow Board of Directors
summary: Dow (NYSE: DOW) announced that Gaurdie Banister Jr., former president and CEO of Aera Energy LLC, has been elected to its Board of Directors, effective immediately. Mr. Banister brings extensive global business and leadership expertise, along with a strong background in engineering and the energy sector, to Dow's board. He will serve on the Environmental, Health, Safety and Technology and the Compensation and Leadership Development committees, further strengthening the board's industry leadership and diversity.

title: Oil giant taking stake in nuclear fusion startup
summary: Chevron Corp., the second-largest U.S. oil and gas company, has made a Series A investment in Zap Energy, a Seattle-based startup developing commercially scalable nuclear fusion reactors. This investment by Chevron’s Future Energy Fund marks its tenth and aligns with its strategy to explore breakthrough technologies for decarbonization and energy transition. Nuclear fusion is highlighted as a promising low-carbon energy source compared to conventional nuclear fission.

title: One carbon capture project stalls as another advances
summary: The Petra Nova carbon-capture project, the world's largest, has been mothballed by NRG Energy due to low oil prices making it unprofitable. This highlights the reliance of such projects on demand for CO2 from the oil sector for enhanced oil recovery. Conversely, another DOE-funded carbon-capture project, Cal Capture, is proceeding in California, planning to sequester CO2 from a gas-fired power plant rather than use it for oil production.

title: Collaborating to Benefit Communities
summary: ConocoPhillips actively engages with communities to foster open dialogue and build mutually beneficial relationships, exemplified by its Citizens Advisory Committee (CAC) in Texas's Eagle Ford region. The CAC, composed of local leaders and company employees, discusses industry matters, environmental concerns, safety practices, and community involvement. ConocoPhillips also utilizes "Leadership Roundtables" to communicate with elected officials and address local issues, demonstrating a commitment to being a responsible community partner.

title: LNG 101: The Complex Process of Financing Massive LNG Projects
summary: This article discusses the complex and lengthy process of financing massive LNG projects, highlighting how Total SE secured $14.9 billion for its Mozambique LNG project amidst the Covid-19 pandemic. It explains that such projects typically involve multiple sponsors, a syndicate of lenders including export credit agencies and commercial banks, and long-term supply agreements to mitigate risks. The financing process can take up to two years and is influenced by various factors such as project costs, host country, and market conditions.

title: BP walks away from the oil supermajor model it helped create
summary: BP is divesting from its oil supermajor model, a concept it helped create, under new CEO Bernard Looney. The company plans to significantly decrease oil and gas output, cut dividends by half, and invest up to $5 billion annually in renewable energy. This strategic shift puts BP, along with other European majors like Shell and Total, on a different path from US counterparts Exxon Mobil and Chevron, who continue to prioritize fossil fuels.

title: Exxon halts contributions to employee retirement plan
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is suspending the company's contribution to its U.S. employee retirement savings plan starting in October due to cost-cutting measures amid the pandemic. This decision follows back-to-back quarterly losses and significant reductions in project outlays and operating expenses. The United Steelworkers union has expressed opposition and is assessing options to protect members' benefits.

title: Exxon Mobil to Suspend 401(k) Match in October
summary: Exxon Mobil announced it will suspend its 401(k) match beginning in October 2020 as a cost-cutting measure due to the COVID-19 pandemic and global oversupply. The move impacts thousands of employees and follows the company's Q2 2020 loss of $1.1 billion. This decision aligns with a trend observed across other plan sponsors during the pandemic.

title: Chris Carr named Member of the Board of Directors at Hilton
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc. announced the appointment of Chris Carr, Chief Operations Officer of sweetgreen, to its board of directors, effective immediately. Mr. Carr will serve on the Nominating and ESG committee of the board and previously held various roles at Starbucks and ExxonMobil. He also serves on the board of REI and as a Trustee for Howard University and the University of San Diego.

title: Shell eligió a TGS para construir una nueva planta de gas en Vaca Muerta
summary: Shell Argentina has contracted Transportadora Gas del Sur (TGS) to build a new gas treatment plant in Vaca Muerta for its Bajada de Añelo block. TGS will provide midstream services including dehydration, filtering, regulation, and gas measurement with a capacity of up to 1 million cubic meters per day. This agreement solidifies TGS's presence in the Neuquén basin and allows Shell to focus on drilling and optimizing its development projects.

title: Energy transition to be topic in presidential race
summary: The 2020 presidential race is expected to prominently feature the topic of energy transition, with Democratic nominee Joe Biden advocating for renewable energy and reduced fossil fuel dependence, while President Trump supports the oil and gas industry. Industry experts note that energy transition has always been a constant throughout history, driven by innovation and technology in response to societal needs and environmental concerns. The debate centers on the pace and scope of this transition, with some predicting rapid change and others a more gradual shift spanning decades.

title: Ivanhoe Mines and Franco-Nevada Look Favorable Ahead of Earnings
summary: This article highlights the favorable positions of Ivanhoe Mines and Franco-Nevada ahead of their earnings reports, despite a general decline in S&P 500 profits and U.S. GDP due to the coronavirus pandemic. It discusses how certain sectors, particularly tech and metals/mining, have thrived, with specific attention given to Ivanhoe's copper production and Franco-Nevada's performance as a gold royalty company, both benefiting from rising metal prices and strategic market conditions. The author also touches on the broader market sentiment, gold's performance, and other economic indicators.

title: E&E News: Judges toss $20M fine for Exxon refinery complex
summary: A federal appeals court has overturned a $20 million penalty against Exxon Mobil stemming from a 2012 refinery fire, ruling that the company cannot be held liable under the Clean Air Act because it lacked the intent to release hazardous chemicals. The court found that prior rulings by the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas did not adequately establish intent. This decision could significantly impact how environmental violations are prosecuted, particularly regarding accidental releases.

title: Valero swings back to profit in 2nd quarter
summary: Valero Energy Corp. reported a $1.3 billion profit in the second quarter of 2020, a significant rebound from a $1.9 billion loss in the first quarter, despite revenues falling 64 percent year-over-year due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company slashed operating expenses and maintained its target to cut capital spending by $400 million to adapt to reduced fuel demand.

title: Reliance overtakes Exxon to become world's No 2 energy firm
summary: Reliance Industries Ltd has surpassed Exxon Mobil Corp to become the world's second-largest energy company after Saudi Aramco, driven by investor interest in its digital and retail ventures. The Indian conglomerate, led by Mukesh Ambani, saw its market value climb to US$189 billion, while Exxon's declined amid a global plunge in fuel demand. This shift reflects Ambani's strategic pivot towards technology and retail, successfully attracting significant investments into its Jio Platforms unit.

title: Precision Drilling second-quarter loss surges as pandemic weakens demand for oil
summary: Precision Drilling Corp. reported a significant surge in its second-quarter loss to $48.9 million, up from $13.8 million a year earlier, with revenues plummeting 47% to $189.8 million due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on oil demand and prices. The company expects a muted third-quarter rebound and aims to reduce 2020 cash outflows by up to $150 million through further cost-cutting and capital expenditure reductions. CEO Kevin Neveu stated these actions have financially and competitively positioned the company for an eventual industry recovery.

title: Jeff Bezos' Net Worth Jumps $13 Billion USD in Single Day
summary: Jeff Bezos' net worth increased by $13 billion USD in a single day, setting a new record for the highest individual increase since 2012, driven by a 7.9% surge in Amazon's stock price. This boost pushed his total fortune to $189.3 billion USD in 2020. His ex-wife, Mackenzie Bezos, also saw her net worth rise by $4.6 billion USD, making her the 13th-richest person globally.

title: Jeff Bezos is now personally worth more than the market valuation of Exxon, Nike, and McDonald’s
summary: Jeff Bezos's net worth surged by $13 billion in a single day, marking the largest daily jump recorded by the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. His fortune now stands at $189.3 billion for 2020, exceeding the market capitalization of major corporations like Exxon Mobil, Nike, and McDonald's. This increase is attributed to a 7.9% rise in Amazon shares amid optimism about online shopping trends during an economic downturn.

title: Eni seeks to sell assets in Norway, Congo
summary: Eni SpA is looking to sell assets in Norway and the Republic of Congo due to the oil slump and a company-wide push to reduce spending and pursue a carbon-reduction program. In Norway, its majority-owned Var Energi AS plans to sell the Jotun FPSO, valued at about $1 billion, while in Congo, Eni is working with advisers to sell a package of operated assets. The move comes as crude prices are down significantly and energy producers are offloading marginal activities.

title: Are Traders Ready to See Oil Prices Go to $0 Again?
summary: Oil traders are contemplating the possibility of oil prices dropping to $0 again, reminiscent of the April 2020 lows caused by the coronavirus pandemic. While prices have rebounded due to supply cuts and easing lockdowns, the risk of renewed declines exists if COVID-19 cases surge and demand falters. The article discusses leveraged ETFs like GUSH for those betting on price increases and DRIP for those on the bearish side.

title: Giveaways created a poverty sinkhole. Then the virus hit
summary: Property tax exemptions offered to oil companies in Louisiana have exacerbated poverty and health disparities in communities surrounding refineries, particularly impacting Black neighborhoods in Shreveport. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted these long-standing issues, revealing significantly higher mortality rates among Black residents in these areas due to underlying health conditions linked to pollution and a lack of public services resulting from the tax giveaways. Local efforts to reform these tax incentives, such as the Industrial Tax Exemption Program (ITEP), are facing ongoing challenges despite some initial successes in regaining local control over property tax revenue.

title: Fracking Firms Fail, Rewarding Executives and Raising Climate Fears
summary: As U.S. oil and gas companies rapidly face bankruptcy due to a global price war and reduced demand, concerns are rising over abandoned wells left to leak planet-warming pollutants and cleanup costs burdening taxpayers. Despite these financial collapses, millions of dollars have been paid out in executive compensation, drawing criticism from financial analysts. Companies like MDC Energy, Whiting Petroleum, Chesapeake Energy, and Diamond Offshore Drilling compensated executives shortly before or during bankruptcy proceedings, highlighting a controversial trend in the industry.

title: Chesapeake Energy transformation of OKC came with a price
summary: Chesapeake Energy's extensive investment in Oklahoma City, spearheaded by founder Aubrey McClendon, dramatically transformed the city with developments like a sprawling campus and upscale shopping districts. However, this civic transformation coincided with a ballooning company debt that eventually led to Chesapeake filing for bankruptcy. Despite the company's financial struggles and McClendon's death, his legacy of civic impact, particularly on areas like the Boathouse District, continues to be recognized.

title: Duke Energy, Dominion Energy cancel contested Atlantic Coast Pipeline
summary: Duke Energy and Dominion Energy have canceled the multi-state Atlantic Coast Pipeline project, citing escalating costs and regulatory uncertainties. This decision comes despite a recent U.S. Supreme Court victory regarding a critical permit, due to continued opposition and delays. The $8 billion natural gas pipeline was designed to cross West Virginia and Virginia into North Carolina.

title: Exxon Mobil resists write-downs as oil, gas prices plummet
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. is notably resisting writing down the value of its U.S. shale assets despite plummeting oil and gas prices, setting it apart from its peers. Other major energy companies like BP PLC, Hess Corp., Occidental Petroleum Corp., Chevron Corp., and Royal Dutch Shell PLC have all taken significant impairments totaling billions of dollars due to the coronavirus-induced economic slowdown and lower energy prices. This stance has even led to an SEC complaint filed by some accountants, suggesting Exxon should recognize the diminished value of its shale driller XTO Energy.

title: Chesapeake Energy files for bankruptcy, as details emerge of wine cellars and botox
summary: Chesapeake Energy, a key player in the U.S. shale revolution, filed for bankruptcy protection due to heavy debt and a drop in oil and gas prices. The restructuring will wipe out $7 billion in debt, and the company has secured additional financing to continue operations at a reduced capacity. Details emerging from the company's past finances reveal extravagant spending under former CEO Aubrey McClendon, including wine cellars and botox treatments.

title: ‘Google of oil and gas’ files for bankruptcy
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp., once the second-largest natural gas producer in the country and a pioneer of the fracking boom, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The company's filing follows a decade of struggling with debt and the legacy of its late founder, Aubrey McClendon, exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic. Despite efforts to reduce debt by $20 billion and lay off thousands of workers, the company was unable to remain solvent.

title: Vaca Muerta Shale Oil and Gas Field
summary: The Vaca Muerta field in Argentina is a significant shale oil and gas development, encompassing conventional and unconventional resources. Various companies, including YPF, Total, Shell, and ExxonMobil, are involved in its exploration and production, with projects aimed at increasing shale gas and oil output. Future plans include further development of blocks and a natural gas liquefaction facility to support continued growth.

title: Chesapeake’s fate marks the end of an era in U.S. shale
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp., once a pioneer in shale drilling, is facing bankruptcy, signaling the end of an era for U.S. shale and potentially the largest corporate casualty in the industry. The company's financial struggles, exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic and years of debt, highlight the broader challenges faced by many North American energy explorers. This situation underscores the unraveling of the shale model established by Chesapeake and its late co-founder Aubrey McClendon, leaving an uncertain future for smaller operators and the industry as a whole.

title: Oxy Starts Returning Staff to U.S. Gulf of Mexico after Storm
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp has begun returning staff to its Gulf of Mexico facilities after Tropical Storm Cristobal moved away. The company plans to fully restaff by Tuesday and resume production once safe. This move follows other energy companies preparing to restart oil and gas production in the region after evacuations and shutdowns.

title: Oil Traders Fret Over Rising Inventories, Questionable Production Cuts
summary: Oil prices experienced volatility due to rising inventories and debates over production cuts among top producers like OPEC+. The extension of current cuts, particularly the 9.7 million barrels per day agreement, is crucial for market stability, as failure to do so could lead to a selling spree, while extending cuts could have longer-term bearish effects on shale production forecasts. Investors can gain exposure to oil through ETFs such as IEO, USOU, and GUSH, with OILK offering an actively managed strategy for WTI crude oil futures.

title: ExxonMobil’s delayed FID on Mozambique project should come next year -official
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp's final investment decision (FID) on its $30 billion gas project in Mozambique's Cabo Delgado province, which was postponed due to the coronavirus and oil price slump, is now expected in 2021. The project, known as Rovuma LNG, is seen as crucial for Mozambique's economic transformation, despite facing challenges from militant Islamists in the region. Other major oil companies like Total and Eni are also involved in projects in the area.

title: Chevron plans sweeping job cuts with 6,000 employees at risk
summary: Chevron Corp. announced plans to cut its global workforce by 10 to 15 percent, affecting about 6,000 non-gas station employees, in response to the Covid-19 pandemic and record-low oil prices. The job cuts are part of an effort to streamline operations, achieve $1 billion in operating expense savings, and may signal similar actions among other major oil companies. This move follows broader job losses within the energy sector, particularly in oilfield services and North American independent producers.

title: BlackRock votes to split CEO, chairman roles at Exxon Mobil
summary: Top fund manager BlackRock Inc. announced it voted in favor of splitting the CEO and chairman roles at Exxon Mobil Corp. and opposed the re-election of two directors due to concerns over Exxon's approach to climate risks. BlackRock, a significant shareholder, highlighted the need for independent leadership and greater urgency in addressing climate-related financial disclosures. This move came despite Exxon shareholders rejecting all four shareholder resolutions.

title: BlackRock says voted to split CEO, chairman roles at Exxon Mobil
summary: Top fund manager BlackRock Inc. announced it voted in favor of splitting the CEO and chairman roles at Exxon Mobil Corp. and against the reelection of two directors due to concerns over the company's approach to climate risks. Exxon shareholders rejected the proposals, with the independent chairman proposal failing to pass. BlackRock, the second-largest institutional owner of Exxon, cited a lack of independent leadership and insufficient progress on climate-related financial disclosures.

title: Exclusive: Chevron to cut up to 15% of staff amid restructuring
summary: Chevron Corp plans to cut 10% to 15% of its global workforce, representing about 4,500 to 6,750 jobs, as part of a restructuring effort to align with projected activity levels amid a sharp drop in oil prices and demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This move follows a 30% reduction in its 2020 spending and previous voluntary job cuts. Most of the reductions are expected to occur this year, with additional severance and benefits offered to affected U.S. employees.

title: Exxon, Chevron face shareholders as oil faces uncertain future
summary: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are facing shareholder meetings amidst a global oil crash caused by the coronavirus pandemic, raising questions about the future of oil demand and climate change policies. Despite the challenges, analysts believe these U.S. oil giants are well-equipped to weather the storm due to their strong balance sheets and diversified operations, potentially allowing them to redefine themselves and acquire struggling rivals. However, shareholder resolutions regarding independent board chairmen and differing outlooks on future oil demand highlight ongoing debates within the industry.

title: Chevron Buys More Marcellus Shale
summary: Chevron has expanded its Marcellus shale holdings by purchasing drilling rights for an additional 228,000 acres, following its 2011 acquisition of Atlas Energy. This move aims to secure more gas-rich land amidst a booming U.S. natural gas sector, despite environmental concerns and falling domestic gas prices. The acquisition is estimated to be worth $1.6 billion.

title: Chevron Nigerian Rig Fire Finally Burns Out
summary: A natural gas fire on a Chevron Corp. rig off the coast of Nigeria, which killed two people, finally stopped burning after 46 days. Though the fire is out, Chevron acknowledged the possibility of gas flowing from the well and is drilling a relief well to permanently plug the site. The Nigerian government attributes the explosions, which occurred on January 16 and killed a man from India and another from France, to a "gas kick" or buildup of gas pressure.

title: Unravelling the climate footprint of U.S. liquefied natural gas
summary: This article examines the significant climate footprint of U.S. liquefied natural gas (LNG), particularly from the Permian Basin, challenging its portrayal as a clean energy source for Europe. It highlights high levels of methane emissions and flaring, which compromise the climate benefits of replacing coal, and discusses the EU's proactive stance on methane emissions. The piece also points out the complexities and inconsistencies in measuring and comparing methane emissions across different gas-producing regions globally.

title: Midland-based Propetro, makes dramatic employee layoffs
summary: Propetro Holding Corp. laid off 150 workers and plans to cut up to 28% of its hydraulic fracturing fleets, representing a 9.5% staff reduction, in response to the oil price drop and Covid-19. The company also announced compensation reductions for its board and management and approved a short-term stockholder rights plan to protect its capital structure and ensure fair treatment for shareholders during potential takeovers.

title: Chesapeake Energy considers bankruptcy after losing more than $8B in first quarter
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp. announced it is considering bankruptcy after posting a net loss of $8.3 billion in the first quarter of 2020, largely due to low commodity prices and depressed demand caused by COVID-19. The company also disclosed that executive bonuses were cut, while a new quarterly bonus program was created for rank and file employees. While bankruptcy is an option, the company is also exploring other strategic alternatives to restructure its debt and align its capital structure.

title: Kevin O'Leary: If you're worried about dividend cuts, it's 'time to use actively managed ETFs'
summary: Kevin O'Leary suggests that actively managed ETFs are a valuable tool for investors concerned about dividend cuts and market volatility, particularly in an uncertain market environment. He highlights O'Shares FTSE U.S. Quality Dividend ETF (OUSA) as an example of an actively managed fund that focuses on companies with high-quality balance sheets and lower likelihood of cutting dividends. O'Leary emphasizes that in these times, quality really matters and active management can help cherry-pick sound investments.

title: Rio Grande LNG and BND amend lease, amid global oil and gas market uncertainty
summary: The Port of Brownsville (BND) and NextDecade’s Rio Grande LNG project have amended their lease agreement, linking its start to a financial investment decision (FID) for the first phase, with a deadline in May 2021 and a possible extension. This amendment comes amidst global oil and gas market uncertainty and delays experienced by several other LNG projects in Texas due to the COVID-19 pandemic and oversupply. The project faces local opposition and legal challenges, with environmental groups welcoming the FID delay.

title: Tankers Round the Cape as Glut Snarls Ports
summary: Due to a global oil glut caused by the coronavirus pandemic, supertankers are undertaking unusual, longer voyages around South Africa's Cape of Good Hope to delay cargo delivery as storage fills up and generate profit from contango market conditions. These rare detours, which avoid the Suez Canal, also capitalize on historically low fuel prices and offer a way for suppliers to manage an oversupplied market. The extended routes highlight the significant impact of the current market disruption on the global shipping industry.

title: Halliburton lays off 1,000 at Houston headquarters
summary: Halliburton has laid off 1,000 employees at its Houston headquarters due to record low crude prices and a "dramatic business downturn." This action follows earlier furloughs and is part of broader global reductions, bringing the company's workforce down from 55,000 to about 50,000 worldwide. The company has also implemented significant cost-cutting measures, including executive pay cuts and a reduction in its capital budget, to navigate the challenging market conditions.

title: Shell to divest natural gas wells in Pennsylvania
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is set to sell its natural gas assets in Tioga County, Pennsylvania, to National Fuel Gas Co. This sale will further expand National Fuel's presence in the state, positioning it as one of the top shale producers. The article notes this transaction while also referencing a broader trend of declining natural gas production and optimism from other Marcellus producers for 2021.

title: Value Tilt – Don’t Give Up on Your Small-Cap Value Strategy
summary: This article argues against giving up on a small-cap value investing strategy despite recent underperformance. The author, Dr. Jim Dahle, explains the rationale behind factor investing in small value stocks, including risk and behavioral biases, and presents data indicating historical long-term outperformance. He discusses why now, given the undervaluation and underperformance of small-cap value, is a good time to stick with or even implement such a tilt, cautioning that it is a long-term decision.

title: Exxon Mobil eyes Irving property sale
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. is looking to sell off about 100 acres of surplus land surrounding its Irving headquarters, including a 35-acre parcel for which it is seeking new office zoning. The energy firm's plan involves rezoning part of the Las Colinas land for offices, indicating a strategic move to divest non-core real estate assets in a popular corporate area. This comes as Irving's planning and zoning commission is set to consider the request.

title: Exxon reports historic loss, closes 75% of Permian rigs
summary: Major U.S. oil producers like Exxon Mobil, ConocoPhillips, and Chevron reported historic losses in the first quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global oil demand. Companies are cutting spending and production, particularly in the Permian Basin, and expect the recovery to be slow, with low prices persisting through the end of the year.

title: Chesapeake Energy preparing bankruptcy filing
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp is preparing a potential bankruptcy filing due to a severe rout in energy prices and significant debt obligations. The company is in early discussions with creditors about debtor-in-possession financing, potentially totaling $1 billion, to sustain operations during bankruptcy proceedings. Chesapeake faces looming debt maturities and interest expenses exceeding $1 billion this year, and has seen its credit rating cut deep into junk territory by Moody's Investor Service.

title: Exxon Posts Historic Loss on Rout With Chevron in Retreat
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. reported its first loss in at least three decades, amounting to $610 million, and plans to cut hundreds of thousands of barrels of daily output. Meanwhile, Chevron Corp. slashed $2 billion from its spending plan and accelerated supply curbs, highlighting the financial impact of the coronavirus pandemic on oil giants. These actions reflect the historic falloff in oil demand and the need for significant cost-cutting measures.

title: What Traders Should Know About the Oil Crash
summary: This article explains the oil crash of April 2020, detailing how global events like the pandemic and price wars led to negative oil futures prices. It offers advice to traders on navigating this volatile market, including understanding risks, considering green energy with caution, and exploring sympathy plays. The piece emphasizes the importance of research, a strong trading plan, and caution in unprecedented market conditions.

title: U.S. oil plunges 25%, Brent falls below $20 a barrel
summary: U.S. crude oil plunged 25% and Brent crude fell below $20 a barrel due to a lack of available storage and weak fuel demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Global fuel demand is down 30% and roughly 85% of worldwide onshore storage was full last week. Retail investment vehicles like the United States Oil Fund LP are shifting holdings to later-dated contracts to avoid similar losses experienced a week prior.

title: What's Driving the Multi Pad Drilling Market Size? Prominent
summary: This article discusses the multi-pad drilling market, highlighting its growth potential, key trends, and competitive landscape. It segments the market by application (onshore, offshore) and pad size, providing regional analysis with a focus on North America, Western Europe, and Asia Pacific as key growth areas. The report profiles major players such as ExxonMobil, Devon Energy, and Chevron, offering an overview of global market trends and opportunities.

title: Trump orders Chevron to halt oil production in Venezuela
summary: The Trump administration ordered Chevron to stop oil production in Venezuela by December 1, as part of efforts to pressure the Maduro regime. This move, while having limited financial impact on Chevron, deals a significant blow to Venezuela's oil industry. Chevron, which has a long history in Venezuela, will be allowed to maintain a limited presence for essential operations.

title: ExxonMobil starts building $10 billion China petrochemical complex
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp has begun construction on its $10 billion petrochemical complex in Huizhou, China. This facility, which includes a 1.6 million tonnes per year ethylene plant, marks one of the few mega petrochemical projects in China wholly owned by a foreign investor.

title: Eaton adds Lori J. Ryerkerk to its board
summary: Eaton (NYSE: ETN) has appointed Lori J. Ryerkerk, chairman, president, and CEO of Celanese Corp. (NYSE: CE), to its board of directors, effective April 22, 2020. Ryerkerk brings extensive experience from the energy industry, including previous roles at Shell Downstream Inc., Hess Corp., and ExxonMobil. She succeeds Todd M. Bluedorn, who served on Eaton's board for 10 years.

title: Exxon Mobil starts building $10 billion China petrochemical complex: Xinhua
