summary: Exxon Mobil Corp has commenced construction of its $10 billion petrochemical complex in Huizhou, China. This facility includes a 1.6 million tonnes per year ethylene plant and is notable as one of the few mega petrochemical projects in China wholly owned by a foreign investor. The project was announced by state news agency Xinhua.

title: Oil plunges below zero for first time; Marathon refinery remains open
authors: Damian J. Troise and Alex Veiga
summary: Oil futures plummeted below zero for the first time in history, reaching negative $37.63 per barrel for May delivery, due to a severe collapse in demand from the coronavirus pandemic and a lack of storage capacity. While an international standard for oil also fell, the Detroit Marathon Petroleum Corp. refinery continued operations, monitoring the market as other global markets reacted to the unprecedented plunge. Simultaneously, the broader stock market saw declines, with the S&P 500 down 1.8%, though some tech companies gained.

title: Oil prices dip below zero as producers forced to pay to dispose of excess
summary: US crude oil prices plummeted to negative values for the first time in history, reaching -$38 a barrel, as an oversupply due to the coronavirus crisis overwhelmed storage facilities. Producers were forced to pay buyers to take crude, highlighting the severe impact of reduced demand. While prices rebounded slightly on Tuesday, the long-term outlook remains uncertain, with calls for a shift towards sustainable energy sources.

title: ConocoPhillips Cuts Oil Output, Spending Again
summary: ConocoPhillips announced significant cuts to its planned spending and oil production, along with the suspension of its share repurchase program, in response to the collapse in oil prices due to coronavirus impact. The company plans to reduce spending by 35%, operational capital expenditures by $1.6 billion, and cut oil production by approximately 225,000 barrels per day across its Canadian and U.S. operations. These measures follow similar actions by other major oil and gas producers grappling with drastically reduced demand and low crude prices.

title: ‘Gigantic impact’: Chesapeake Energy’s complex legacy
summary: Chesapeake Energy, once a fracking pioneer and a significant contributor to Oklahoma City's development, is grappling with overwhelming debt and a collapsed petroleum market. The company recently executed a one-for-200 reverse stock split to avoid delisting from the NYSE, signaling its struggle for survival amidst a complex legacy that includes both economic impact and environmental concerns. The article delves into the company's boom-and-bust history, the controversial leadership of co-founder Aubrey McClendon, and the broader implications of its trajectory for the energy industry and local communities.

title: Exxon raises $9.5 billion to load up on cash while debt market still open to new deals
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp raised $9.5 billion in new debt to bolster its finances, taking advantage of still-open debt markets amid investor confidence gradually returning. The oil producer secured the debt at a lower borrowing cost compared to a month ago, selling five different bonds with durations ranging from five to 31 years. This move is part of a broader trend of highly-rated U.S. companies raising cash due to economic uncertainty from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Guangdong pushes forward on Exxon Mobil project in Huizhou
summary: Guangdong provincial government and Exxon Mobil Corporation held a video conference to discuss the construction of the Huizhou ethylene project. Both parties expressed their commitment to pushing the project forward despite the global economic impact of the pandemic. Exxon Mobil stated it would not change its investment plans in China and its development strategy in Guangdong.

title: Exxon Mobil cuts spending plans, reduces expansion budget as coronavirus hits oil demand
summary: Exxon Mobil has significantly reduced its 2020 capital spending by 30% to $23 billion, in response to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on oil demand and prices. This cut is deeper than most rivals, with major impacts on U.S. shale production and deferred investment decisions on projects in Mozambique and Guyana. Despite the spending cuts, the company has maintained its shareholder dividend.

title: Just in: Exxon Mobil delays FID for the Rovuma LNG project in Mozambique
summary: Exxon Mobil has delayed the final investment decision (FID) for the Rovuma LNG project in Mozambique, previously scheduled for later in the year, as part of broader spending cuts. The oil and gas supermajor reduced its 2020 capital budget by 30%, or $10 billion, to $23 billion, and aims to cut operating expenses by 15% in response to low energy prices and collapsing demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. These cuts primarily affect Permian Basin operations and will also delay some Guyanese field development activities.

title: Rockets target US oil company in Iraq’s Basra province
summary: At least three rockets targeted the site of the American oil field service company Halliburton in Iraq's Basra province, marking the first such attack on US energy interests in recent months. While no casualties were reported and oil production was unaffected, the incident fuels tensions, with pro-Iran militias in Iraq having previously pledged to target US interests. Security forces found a rocket launcher and defused unused rockets nearby.

title: Rockets target US oil company site in southern Iraq
summary: Three rockets landed near the site of US oilfield service company Halliburton in Basra, southern Iraq, marking the first such attack since last summer against US oil companies in the region. No damage or casualties were reported, and a rocket launcher was later found with unused missiles. Oil production and export operations were unaffected, and the area was largely empty due to foreign personnel evacuation amidst the coronavirus crisis.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | A Top Occidental Petroleum Executive Is Out as Company Grapples With Oil Rout
summary: A top executive at Occidental Petroleum Corp., Oscar Brown, has been "forced out" of the company amid challenges from an ill-timed acquisition, declining crude prices, and substantial debt. Brown, who was a key lieutenant to CEO Vicki Hollub and instrumental in the Anadarko Petroleum acquisition, served as senior vice president over strategy, business development, and supply chain. The $38 billion Anadarko deal included a costly $10 billion investment from Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway.

title: Oil Storage So Full That Traders May Stow It on Pipe Networks
summary: The US oil glut is growing so rapidly that storage facilities are nearing capacity, leading pipeline operators to worry that traders might use pipelines for temporary storage to await better prices. Plains All American Pipeline LP is requiring proof of buyers for crude shipments to prevent this, while Colonial Pipeline Co. has warned clients that unreserved fuel will be sold off. This situation highlights rising concerns about overwhelming storage capacity and the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on demand.

title: Oil crash leaves Exxon, Chevron dividends safe -- for now
summary: In the wake of a significant oil market crash driven by a Saudi Arabia-Russia price war and the COVID-19 pandemic, the dividends of ExxonMobil and Chevron are under threat but still considered safe "for now." Both companies have seen their stock prices plummet, leading Chevron to cut capital spending and halt share buybacks to conserve cash. Analysts believe the companies will prioritize dividend payments as long as possible due to their strong balance sheets and the importance of dividends to their investor base.

title: Exxon notifies contractors, vendors of spending cuts over coronavirus
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is notifying its contractors and vendors of impending near-term cuts in capital and operating expenses due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company plans to announce these reductions once finalized, indicating a need to significantly lower costs in the current unprecedented environment. Exxon has already begun reducing production at its Baton Rouge refinery and cut 1,800 contract workers, with expectations to also delay a $30-billion liquefied natural gas plant in Mozambique.

title: Coronavirus causes ConocoPhillips to temporarily cancel flights for workers to North Slope fields
summary: ConocoPhillips has canceled flights for hundreds of workers to Alaska's North Slope for two weeks to prevent the spread of COVID-19, asking critical personnel to extend their rotations. Other oil companies like BP are continuing screenings for workers, while the virus has led to plunging oil prices and a slowdown in the North Slope oil patch. All companies are implementing measures like social distancing and health screenings, with no confirmed cases on the North Slope at the time of the report.

title: Crude Oil Continues To Crater As Short Crude ETFs Gain
summary: Crude oil prices are crashing due to a price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia, exacerbated by diminished demand from the coronavirus pandemic. Analysts predict oil could fall to $20 or even $10 a barrel, leading to significant gains for inverse crude oil ETFs such as SCO, DTO, and DNO. Goldman Sachs and Rystad Energy have drastically cut their oil demand forecasts for 2020.

title: In Conflict of Interest, Interior Secretary Met With Halliburton Lobbyists
summary: The article exposes potential conflicts of interest involving former Interior Secretary David Bernhardt and Halliburton Energy Services. Despite a recusal agreement due to his past legal work for Halliburton, Bernhardt met with lobbying groups representing the company. These meetings raise concerns about the spirit, if not the letter, of ethical guidelines regarding government officials and their previous private sector clients.

title: U.S. shale producers deepen spending, output cuts as oil prices slump
summary: U.S. shale producers are rapidly deepening spending and output cuts in response to a sharp decline in oil prices, triggered by OPEC's decision to flood a market already suffering from reduced demand due to the coronavirus. Major shale independents like Diamondback Energy Inc. and Parsley Energy Inc. have announced significant reductions in drilling and well completions to maintain cash flow, leading to a sharp drop in their share prices and impacting oilfield service firms. Analysts predict that U.S. oil production growth will be near zero compared to 2019, with further reductions in spending expected as investors are less willing to finance the sector than in previous downturns.

title: Colorado hits Suncor with record air pollution violation penalties over its Commerce City refineries
summary: Colorado has issued record air pollution violation penalties against Suncor Energy for its Commerce City refineries. The penalties include significant fines and require millions of dollars to be invested in improving community air quality and reducing emissions. This action follows previous apologies from Suncor executives and ongoing legal challenges from Colorado communities regarding the refinery's impact.

title: Exxon calls for stricter methane regulations
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has called for strengthening methane emissions regulations, publishing its internal guidelines as a model for industry and governments. The company's CEO, Darren Woods, hopes this framework will assist other operators in reducing the sector’s methane emissions, as investor and consumer pressure mounts despite the Trump administration's rollback of Obama-era standards. Exxon's move follows similar actions by European oil and gas firms and highlights a growing industry sentiment that voluntary reductions are insufficient.

title: Santos Contracts Valaris Rig for Van Gogh Phase 2
summary: Santos Ltd. announced a final investment decision for the Van Gogh Infill Development Phase Two Project offshore Western Australia, contracting the Valaris MS1 mobile offshore drilling unit. The project involves drilling three new horizontal dual-lateral production wells and subsea tieback into existing infrastructure, with first oil expected late next year. This follows the successful Phase One, which delivered higher reserves for lower costs.

title: Guyana holds crucial election ahead of expected oil boom
summary: Guyana is holding a crucial election that will determine which party oversees an anticipated oil boom, with over eight billion barrels of oil and gas discovered offshore. The election comes at a pivotal moment as economic forecasts predict an 86% GDP growth for 2020, but concerns remain about potential resource curse, corruption and the terms of the deal with ExxonMobil. Indigenous leaders are also campaigning to ensure that the country's wealth benefits all its citizens and to address long-standing issues of poverty and land rights.

title: NRG eyes private option despite earnings turnaround
summary: NRG Energy, despite a significant earnings turnaround in 2019 ($4.4 billion from $268 million in 2018), is struggling with a lagging stock price, leading CEO Mauricio Gutierrez to consider taking the company private. This move echoes competitor Calpine's 2018 privatization and could allow NRG to escape public market scrutiny and potentially re-engage in ventures like renewables. The company's financials proved strong last year, buoyed by high wholesale electricity prices during an August heat wave, but its share price remains a concern for executives.

title: JPMorgan Will Stop Lending to Coal Companies
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. announced it will cease doing business with coal companies and restrict financing for Arctic drilling projects. The bank plans to phase out existing coal company loans by 2024 and will only fund new coal-powered plants that include carbon capture technology. This move comes as JPMorgan also committed $200 billion in financing for clean and renewable energy companies by 2025.

title: USA Compression Partners Cuts 2020 Capex
summary: USA Compression Partners LP (USAC) has reduced its 2020 capital expenditures and equipment orders due to the industry downturn, forecasting spending of US$110-120 million and acquiring 56,000 hp of compressors, down from US$150 million and 132,000 hp in 2019. Despite "strong headwinds" in the energy industry, CEO Eric Long anticipates stable cash flows from long-term, high-horsepower contracts and sees continued opportunities in chemical, LNG export, and power generation sectors.

title: See Where 'X' Marks The Spot For XLE
summary: The Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE) experienced a poor start to 2020, being the worst-performing sector in January, largely due to sliding oil prices and concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. Despite being in bear market territory and nursing an 11% loss, some market observers believe a rebound could be possible given that energy is one of the least expensive sectors. The article discusses technical support and resistance levels for XLE, including its late-2018-through-2019 lows at $54 and 2010 lows at $49.

title: Westlake Chemical agrees to report plastic pellet spills under activist shareholder pressure
summary: Westlake Chemical Corp. has agreed to publicly report its plastic pellet spills due to pressure from the activist shareholder group As You Sow. This decision follows similar commitments from other major plastics producers like Exxon Mobil, Chevron Phillips Chemical, and Dow Chemical, and comes after Formosa Plastics settled a major lawsuit over a plastic pellet spill for $50 million. Westlake will include this data in its 2020 sustainability report, which will be published in 2021.

title: ExxonMobil, Canada enter landmark settlement in NAFTA arbitration
summary: ExxonMobil and Canada have reached a multi-million-dollar settlement in a long-running NAFTA arbitration case. The dispute, which lasted 16 years, concerned the amount of money the energy giant was required to spend on research.

title: A Canadian Energy Company Bought an Oregon Sheriff’s Unit
summary: A Canadian energy company, Pembina Pipeline Corp., funded a specialized unit within the Coos County Sheriff’s Office in Oregon for nearly four years to handle security concerns related to its proposed Jordan Cove Energy Project. This unit, established to monitor opposition and acquire riot control equipment, highlights an unusual partnership between a public law enforcement agency and a private corporation. Critics argue this arrangement biases law enforcement and raises constitutional questions regarding free speech and public safety.

title: All eyes on Exxon and Chevron after BP pledges to go carbon neutral
summary: BP's commitment to go carbon neutral by 2050 intensifies pressure on U.S. oil giants Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. to similarly expand their climate efforts beyond operational emissions. While European peers are investing in low-carbon energy, Exxon and Chevron remain focused on their core oil and gas businesses, viewing climate change as a technology problem yet to be solved, and prioritizing higher returns. This stance puts them at odds with shareholder groups and an increasingly climate-conscious investment landscape.

title: Martinez Named to Top Latinos Leaders in Corporate America
summary: Alumna Maria Martinez ’01, MBA ’06, was recognized by Latino Leaders Magazine as one of the top Latino Leaders in Corporate America, serving as the Vice President of Human Resources & Administration at Murphy Oil Corporation. She is noted for her leadership in global HR programs and her community involvement with organizations like the Greater Houston Women’s Chamber of Commerce. Martinez credits her two degrees from the University of St. Thomas for providing a strong foundation for her professional success.

title: Exxon Mobil’s stock drops to decade low after Goldman says it’s time to sell
summary: Exxon Mobil's stock fell to its lowest point in a decade after Goldman Sachs analyst Neil Mehta recommended selling due to concerns about the oil giant missing its investment return targets. The stock dropped 2.2%, making it the biggest loser in the Dow Jones Industrial Average on Monday. This decline marked the 13th fall in 14 days for Exxon Mobil's shares.

title: Exxon Mobil and Chevron Help Fuel Investor Revolt
summary: Weak earnings reports from Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp., following Royal Dutch Shell Plc's earlier debacle, are contributing to investor dissatisfaction in the oil majors. The energy sector's weighting in the S&P 500 Index has fallen to a four-decade low, highlighting increasing vulnerability for these companies and a lack of investor confidence. The results suggest a prolonged challenge for these large oil companies to regain shareholder trust.

title: Pemex Claims Ownership of Lion's Share of Zama Field
summary: Mexico's state oil company Pemex is claiming the majority ownership of resources in the Zama offshore field, conflicting with Talos Energy Inc.'s interpretation. This dispute adds to tensions between the Mexican government and the private sector, as both companies vie for operator status of the significant oil field. The resolution of this issue, which could impact Mexico's energy production and revenue, is expected to be determined through technical means and discussions with the Energy Ministry.

title: Exxon Mobil closes at lowest since October 2013
summary: Exxon Mobil shares reached their lowest closing price since October 2013, driven by falling oil prices stemming from the widening coronavirus outbreak. The decline was also impacted by a regulatory filing from Exxon indicating weaker fourth-quarter results due to issues in its chemicals and refining segments, leading analysts to lower their outlooks for the stock.

title: Exxon, Chevron earnings bring worries about oil prices to the forefront
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. are facing increased scrutiny from Wall Street as they prepare to report fourth-quarter earnings, amidst negative sentiment for the energy sector and declining oil prices. Both integrated energy giants are scheduled to report earnings and conduct conference calls with analysts on Friday.

title: Pizza Inn Express Opens Inside Exxon Station in Arkansas
summary: Pizza Inn Express has opened a new location inside a renovated Exxon station in Danville, Ark., offering specialty pizzas, sandwiches, wings, and appetizers. Owned and operated by David Blackmon, this marks his fourth Pizza Inn Express location, with Blackmon Oil Co. also contributing STEM grants to local high schools. Rave Restaurant Group, the parent company of Pizza Inn Express, and ExxonMobil, are expanding their presence in the U.S. with this new opening.

title: Oklahoma Oil Rig Explosion Wrongful Death Trial Begins in Oklahoma
summary: A wrongful death trial has begun in Oklahoma against National Oilwell Varco (NOV) following a January 2018 oil rig explosion that killed five men. Families of the victims claim NOV was primarily responsible due to a failure in providing proper operational oversight, a charge NOV disputes, attributing fault to another company, Red Mountain Operating, LLC. The families have already reached settlements with several other companies involved in the incident.

title: There Is a Fund for Everything. But Why?
summary: The article discusses the proliferation of niche thematic Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs) that aim to profit from specific trends like cannabis, pet care, or even adult obesity. While fund managers use these to stand out in a bull market, experts question their necessity and highlight their complexity, higher costs, and increased risk compared to broad-index funds. The piece advises caution, suggesting these funds are best suited for a small portion of a risk-taker's portfolio rather than as core holdings.

title: Activists cheer BlackRock's landmark climate move but call for vigilance
summary: BlackRock, the world's biggest asset manager, announced a significant shift in its investment strategy, divesting $500m from coal-related businesses due to climate risks. Environmentalists hailed this as a major breakthrough but urged continued vigilance and further action, emphasizing that these initial steps are just the beginning of necessary changes in the financial sector to combat climate change. Activists and financial experts alike called for BlackRock to leverage its substantial shareholder power to push for immediate, concrete climate actions from companies it invests in.

title: District Court Overturns OFAC Fine Against Exxon
summary: A U.S. District Court overturned a $2 million OFAC fine against ExxonMobil for contracts signed by Igor Sechin of Rosneft, arguing OFAC failed to provide fair notice of its sanction interpretations. The decision highlights the importance of clear guidance from OFAC and urges companies to seek clarification when regulations are unclear. The ruling suggests OFAC may need to be more explicit about when interpretive guidance for one sanctions program applies to others.

title: Understanding the Emissions Challenge
summary: Integrated oil companies are facing increasing pressure to reduce emissions from investors and regulators. This article assesses their efforts, highlighting that while many have adopted targets, Scope 3 emissions (90% of total) remain largely beyond their control. Investments in renewable power generation and increasing natural gas production are identified as the most impactful strategies for reducing full-cycle emissions.

title: The 10 Biggest Carbon-dioxide Emitting Firms In The World
summary: This article identifies the ten largest corporate emitters of carbon dioxide globally, responsible for a significant portion of greenhouse gas emissions since 1965. It details each company's emissions, origin, and some of their initiatives or controversies related to climate change. The article also highlights the impact of investor pressure in driving companies towards decarbonization efforts.

title: Cenovus sets bold sustainability targets
summary: Cenovus Energy Inc. announced ambitious environmental, social, and governance (ESG) targets for 2030, focusing on climate & greenhouse gas emissions, Indigenous engagement, land & wildlife, and water stewardship. The company aims to reduce emissions intensity by 30% and hold absolute emissions flat by 2030, with a long-term ambition for net-zero emissions by 2050. These targets are integrated into Cenovus's strategy to enhance business resilience and foster long-term sustainability.

title: Imperial Oil, Canada's Exxon Subsidiary, Ignored Its Own Climate Change Research for Decades, Archive Shows
summary: Imperial Oil, Exxon’s Canadian subsidiary, publicly denied climate change for decades while its own research recognized the reality and dangers of global warming. Archival documents reveal that Imperial Oil started commissioning environmental studies in the 1960s and by the 1990s, internal researchers had analyzed ways to reduce carbon footprints, yet the company leadership chose to obfuscate the science and focused on new business opportunities from a warming Arctic. This strategy of denial and delay was employed despite understanding the severe environmental impact of their operations and the necessity of transitioning to sustainable energy.

title: Mobil SA se queda con la mayoría de Sierra Chata
summary: Mobil Argentina SA, a subsidiary of ExxonMobil, has acquired Total Austral SA's stake in the Sierra Chata area, becoming the majority shareholder with 54.45%. This move makes Mobil a key partner with Pampa Energía SA in the Vaca Muerta shale and tight gas project. The acquisition involved an initial payment of $33.64 million and strengthens Mobil's presence in Argentina's unconventional energy sector.

title: Fiserv and ExxonMobil will Enable Consumers to Fill Up by Asking Alexa to Pay at the Pump
summary: Fiserv and ExxonMobil announced a partnership to allow consumers to pay for fuel at over 11,500 Exxon and Mobil stations using Amazon Alexa. This new voice-activated payment method, powered by Fiserv's digital commerce technology and Amazon Pay, will be available later in 2020 and demonstrated at CES 2020. It aims to provide a frictionless and secure transaction experience for consumers in Alexa-enabled vehicles or using other Alexa mobility devices.

title: Energy stocks surge, as crude oil prices spike on Middle East tensions
summary: Energy stocks experienced a broad surge in premarket trading on Friday as crude oil prices spiked due to Middle East tensions following a U.S. airstrike. The SPDR Energy Select Sector ETF saw a 1.4% gain, with major components like Exxon Mobil Corp., Occidental Petroleum Corp., and Chevron Corp. all rising. This rally in energy stocks contrasted with a broader market downturn, as S&P 500 futures sank and crude oil futures shot up significantly.

title: Exxon Wins U.S. Suit Over $2 Million Ukraine-Sanctions Fine
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. won a lawsuit challenging a $2 million fine imposed by the U.S. Treasury Secretary for alleged violations of Ukraine-related sanctions. A U.S. District Judge ruled that Exxon was not given sufficient notice that its 2014 contracts with a Russian ally would violate the sanctions. The sanctions were put in place after Russia annexed Crimea.

title: ABB committed to serving Bartlesville
summary: ABB has reaffirmed its long-term commitment to Bartlesville by acquiring its facility near Bison Road for $17 million and an additional 18 acres for future expansion. This move reinforces their satisfaction with the Bartlesville operation's performance. The Bartlesville Development Authority supported this growth by offering no-cost land for expansion that generates quality employment and sales tax revenue.

title: TGS finaliza construcción de gasoducto en Vaca Muerta
summary: Transportadora Gas del Sur (TGS) has completed the construction of a 150 km gas pipeline and an conditioning plant in Vaca Muerta, Neuquén, Argentina. This infrastructure will allow for the capture and transport of up to 60 MMm3/d of unconventional gas from the Neuquén basin to the national transportation network. The project, completed in record time, is deemed crucial for accelerating the development of gas production in Vaca Muerta, with companies like Pluspetrol, YPF, Pampa Energía, Total, Shell, GyP, and Tecpetrol already injecting gas into the new system.

title: Oil Boom Begins in Guyana as Exxon Produces First Liza Crude
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. and its partners have produced the first commercial crude from Guyana's offshore Liza field, signaling a significant economic boost for the small South American nation. Output from the first phase is expected to reach 120,000 gross barrels of oil per day in the coming months, with the initial cargo set to be sold soon. This development positions Guyana to potentially produce 750,000 barrels per day by 2025.

title: Year in Review: 2019 Was A Pivotal Year for American Oil and Natural Gas
summary: 2019 proved to be a pivotal year for the American oil and natural gas industry, marked by record production and export achievements that reshaped global energy markets. The U.S. became a net exporter of petroleum products and solidified its position as the world's leading oil and natural gas producer. These advancements have not only driven significant economic growth and job creation but also contributed to substantial reductions in emissions and considerable savings for American families.

title: Natural Gas Extraction Opportunities in the Mississippian Barnett Shale
summary: The Barnett Shale in North-central Texas is becoming a major source of natural gas, offering low-cost extraction opportunities due to advancements in technology. Despite senior companies moving to other regions, smaller E&P firms are finding success by re-working existing wells and utilizing established infrastructure. The US is set to become a net energy exporter by 2020, with rising global demand for natural gas, particularly from countries like China.

title: News Content Hub - Industry leader: Quintin Kneen, President and CEO, Tidewater Inc
summary: Quintin Kneen, President and CEO of Tidewater Inc., is aggressively reshaping the company's fleet, management, and IT infrastructure to prepare for a market recovery and further industry consolidation. He has implemented significant organizational changes, including management shakeups and board reductions, and is focusing on cost-efficiency, technology leverage, and cultural transformation to improve decision-making and generate cash flow. Tidewater is also actively managing its fleet, including scrapping older vessels, acquiring new ones, and divesting non-returning assets, while considering strategic mergers to strengthen its market position.

title: Satellite observations reveal extreme methane leakage from a natural gas well blowout
summary: Satellite observations using the Tropospheric Monitoring Instrument (TROPOMI) revealed a major methane leak from a natural gas well blowout in Ohio in 2018. The leak, which lasted 20 days, emitted an estimated 120 ± 32 metric tons of methane per hour, a rate twice that of the Aliso Canyon event in 2015. This single event's total methane emission was comparable to a significant fraction of annual anthropogenic emissions from several European countries, highlighting the importance of satellite monitoring for unexpected large-scale greenhouse gas releases.

title: Transocean Rig to Mobilize in Caribbean
summary: Transocean has secured a one-year contract for its Development Driller III semisubmersible rig to operate offshore Trinidad and Tobago. The contract is expected to commence in the second quarter of 2020 and contribute approximately $91 million to Transocean's backlog. The rig, capable of ultra-deepwater drilling, is currently contracted to ExxonMobil Corp.

title: Exxon Mobil scores win in New York climate change lawsuit
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp won a significant victory in a New York climate change lawsuit, with a judge ruling that the company did not defraud investors by hiding the true cost of climate change regulation. The judge found that the New York State Attorney General's case lacked sufficient evidence to prove investors were misled. This ruling represents the first major decision in several climate change lawsuits against oil companies.

title: Natural Gas Boom Fizzles as a U.S. Glut Sinks Profits (Published 2019)
summary: A decade after being heralded as the fuel of the future, the U.S. natural gas industry is experiencing a bust due to a significant glut in supply, leading to sinking profits and company write-downs. Chevron's $10 billion to $11 billion asset write-down, mainly in shale gas holdings, highlights the industry's over-optimism and the current oversupply situation. This market downturn is exacerbated by the falling costs of renewable energy and growing international gas production, suggesting a potentially prolonged slump.

title: Exxon to Export First Oil from Guyana in Early 2020
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp and Hess Corp are set to export the first crude oil from Guyana in early 2020, marking a significant milestone for the Latin American nation. A consortium including these companies and CNOOC Ltd has discovered over 6 billion barrels of recoverable oil and gas, with production expected to reach 750,000 bpd. The Liza project, Guyana's first crude grade, will be processed by Exxon at its refineries, while Hess eyes spot sales and CNOOC plans shipments to China.

title: Exxon Mobil wins lawsuit over climate change risks
summary: Exxon Mobil won a lawsuit filed by the New York Attorney General's office, which alleged the company duped investors about the financial impact of climate change regulations. A state judge ruled there was no proof of material misstatements that misled reasonable investors, emphasizing the case was about securities fraud, not climate change itself. The lawsuit had sought significant restitution to shareholders and was seen as a test case for how investors perceive energy companies' futures in a warming world.

title: Exxon Mobil found not guilty in climate change accounting case
summary: A New York judge found Exxon Mobil not guilty in a lawsuit accusing the company of deceiving investors about the cost of climate-change regulations. The judge stated that the New York Attorney General's office failed to prove that Exxon Mobil made material misstatements to investors, emphasizing that it was a securities fraud case, not a climate change case. Despite the ruling, the Attorney General maintained that Exxon Mobil misled investors and vowed to continue fighting to hold companies responsible for actions impacting financial health.

title: Oklahoma tornadoes: Oklahoma energy companies contribute millions to relief efforts
summary: Several prominent Oklahoma energy companies, including Chesapeake Energy Corp., Devon Energy Corp., and Continental Resources Inc., have collectively pledged over $7 million towards relief efforts following this week's deadly tornadoes. Companies like Continental and ConocoPhillips are also facilitating additional donations and matching employee contributions. These contributions aim to support organizations like the American Red Cross and the OK Strong Disaster Relief Fund to aid affected families and communities.

title: New Vaca Muerta concessions awarded to YPF, Vista
summary: Neuquén province has granted new concessions in the Vaca Muerta shale formation to Vista Oil and Gas and YPF. Vista will invest US$32mn in its Águila Mora block, while YPF will invest US$60mn in its Loma Amarilla Sur block, both focusing on horizontal well development. These awards mark a continued push by companies to expand shale development into the northern parts of the Neuquina basin.

title: Drilling Down: Top 10 drilling rig companies in Texas and their customers
summary: This article identifies the top 10 drilling rig companies and their top customers in Texas, based on exclusive data from Enverus as of November 26, 2019. It highlights Helmerich & Payne as the leading operator with 117 horizontal rigs and notes that Exxon Mobil leads in rig count among customers. The article also discusses the impact of low oil prices on the industry and the overall U.S. rig count.

title: How To Invest In An Oil Contango
summary: This article explains contango and backwardation in oil futures markets and how they impact traders. It provides strategies for investors to navigate a contango market, such as constantly monitoring the futures curve, investing directly in oil companies or energy ETFs, and employing a hybrid model using different ETFs.

title: Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones is on the prowl in this overlooked shale play
summary: Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones, through his company Comstock Resources Inc., is aggressively pursuing shale gas assets in Louisiana's Haynesville play, considering it the best for low-cost hydrocarbons. This strategy involves potential acquisitions exceeding $1 billion, including rumored talks with Chesapeake Energy Corp. and the recent acquisition of Covey Park Energy LLC, as Jones doubles down on natural gas despite a glut in the market and a significant drop in Comstock's share price.

title: Exclusive: Exxon aims to sell $25 billion of assets to focus on mega-projects - sources
summary: Exxon Mobil plans to sell up to $25 billion of oil and gas fields in Europe, Asia, and Africa in its largest asset sales in decades. This move aims to free up cash to focus on mega-projects and appease investors unhappy with weak cash generation and oil output. The disposals would allow Exxon to increase spending on new developments in key regions while reducing its presence in parts of Europe and Southeast Asia.

title: Couche-Tard Sells CrossAmerica Partners
summary: Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. has sold its entire ownership interest in CrossAmerica Partners to investment entities controlled by Joe Topper, the founder of CrossAmerica, for an undisclosed amount following a strategic review. Concurrently, Couche-Tard and CrossAmerica announced an asset exchange agreement, involving Couche-Tard's U.S. dealer business and CrossAmerica's interest in CST Fuel Supply LP. This transaction allows both companies to focus on their core businesses and aims to create value for their respective shareholders and unit holders.

title: New York CIO Leadership Association 2019: Michael Braine
summary: This article profiles Michael Braine, the Corporate CIO for Tapestry, Inc., a New York-based house of luxury brands including Coach, Stuart Weitzman, and Kate Spade. It highlights his responsibilities in establishing a common digital core for shared services and synergy, as well as transforming the IT organization. The profile also mentions his previous role as CIO for Luxottica Retail and his leadership experience at SAP Retail, Inc. and ExxonMobil Corporation.

title: Gulfport Energy workforce reduced by 13%
summary: Gulfport Energy Corp. announced a 13% reduction in its workforce, eliminating 44 jobs primarily in Oklahoma, and suspended its $400 million stock repurchase program. These actions come amid a 66% drop in the company's stock price over the past year due to low oil and natural gas prices. The company also reported a net loss of $48.8 million in the third quarter.

title: Ecopetrol y OXY cierran acuerdo de inversión en la Cuenca Permian en EE.UU.
summary: Ecopetrol and OXY have finalized their joint venture investment agreement in the Permian Basin in the U.S., which was first announced in July. Ecopetrol made an initial payment of approximately US$876.5 million for its 49% stake in the Rodeo Midland Basin LLC. This alliance is expected to add around 160 million barrels of proven oil equivalent reserves for Ecopetrol by the end of 2019.

title: Everything So Far Has Failed: Why Exxon Mobil Is Being Taken to Court Over Climate Change
summary: Exxon Mobil is facing a wave of climate change litigation, with a New York trial being the first of its kind to target a fossil fuel company directly. The case, People of the State of New York v. Exxon Mobil Corp., focused on alleged securities fraud regarding Exxon's representations to shareholders about climate risks. This litigation, alongside similar cases in Massachusetts and other states, aims to hold the fossil fuel industry accountable for contributing to the climate emergency and for misleading the public about scientific consensus.

title: Making An Impact With Green Bond ETFs
summary: This article discusses green bonds as a concrete way for investors to finance eco-friendly projects, contrasting them with general ESG investments which often face data and definition problems. It highlights two green bond ETFs, VanEck Vectors Green Bond ETF (GRNB) and iShares Global Green Bond ETF (BGRN), explaining their different selection criteria, performance, and yield.

title: Second Failed Brazil Oil Auction Has Officials Attacking Rules
summary: Brazil experienced its second consecutive failed oil auction, leading government officials and the head of the state-run producer to criticize current bidding rules. Most major oil companies avoided bidding, with only one of five available blocks receiving a bid, prompting the Economy Minister to express concern about the difficulty of doing business in Brazil.

title: Chesapeake Warns On Risk to Business From Sagging Oil Prices
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp. has warned that its ability to remain in business is at risk if oil and natural gas prices stay low. The company stated there is "substantial doubt" about its going concern status and that tightening loan agreements could lead to a debt default, causing investors to sell off shares and bonds. This highlights the ongoing challenges for drillers recovering from the 2014-2015 commodity price collapse.

title: Anna Williams, Jacob Jurlina (Published 2019)
summary: Anna Frances Williams and Jacob Jarrett Jurlina were married on November 2, 2019, in Louisville, Ky. Both 32, Anna works for Shell Oil Company in Houston, and Jacob is a finance manager at Ridgewood Energy Corporation, an oil and gas private equity firm also in Houston. The article provides details about their professional backgrounds, education, and parents.

title: Massachusetts Sues Exxon Mobil for Deceptive Climate Messaging
summary: Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey has filed a lawsuit against Exxon Mobil, accusing the company of deceptive climate messaging that evolved from outright denial to "greenwashing" its products. The suit, broader than similar litigation in New York, highlights Exxon's alleged manipulation of public perception through advertisements and misleading claims about its environmental efforts and product benefits, while simultaneously obstructing climate policy. It draws parallels to the Big Tobacco litigation, suggesting that Exxon deliberately misled the public and investors about the severity of climate change and its fossil fuel production plans.

title: Second offshore wind project announced
summary: Massachusetts has announced Mayflower Wind as the developer for its second offshore wind project, an 804-megawatt installation south of Nantucket, projected for completion by 2025. This project will join Vineyard Wind in advancing the state's clean energy goals, aiming to create jobs and significantly reduce carbon emissions. The state is actively working towards its 2027 goal of 1,600 megawatts from offshore wind production to meet increasing energy demands and environmental targets.

title: Encana leaves for U.S., changes name as industry veterans lament ‘heart-wrenching’ decision
summary: Encana Corp., a major Canadian oil and gas company, is moving its head office to the United States and rebranding as Ovintiv Inc. The decision, which comes amid struggles in Alberta's energy sector and political debate over environmental policies, allows Encana access to larger U.S. investment funds. The move has been criticized by industry veterans and politicians, despite the company's assurance of no job losses in Canada.

title: Sasol removes several execs, including co-CEOs, amid cost overruns at Lake Charles plant
summary: Sasol Ltd. has removed its co-CEOs, Bongani Nqwababa and Stephen Cornell, and several other top executives due to the ballooning cost and delays of its $12.9 billion Lake Charles Chemicals Project. Fleetwood Grobler will assume the role of CEO, responsible for the final stages of the project. The board attributed the issues to a "lack of competence" and transparency, with costs increasing significantly from original estimates despite the project being 99% complete.

title: Exxon Mobil seeks buyer for Montana refinery
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is looking to sell its 60,000 barrel per day Billings, Montana refinery. Representatives from large refiners like Valero Energy Corp and Marathon Petroleum Corp have toured the facility, but a smaller refiner is considered a more likely buyer. Exxon previously tried to sell this plant and its Joliet, Illinois refinery to PBF Energy in 2016, and the Billings plant is still expected to fetch around $500 million.

title: Stopping Global Warming Will Cost $50 Trillion: Morgan Stanley Report
summary: A Morgan Stanley report estimates that $50 trillion in investment will be needed over the next three decades to stop global warming and achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. This monumental investment will be allocated across five key areas of zero-carbon technology: renewables, electric vehicles, carbon capture and storage, hydrogen, and biofuels. The report also highlights specific companies poised to benefit from this spending and cautions about significant global GDP loss if climate targets are not met.

title: Economy on the right path, Hafeez Shaikh tells US investors
summary: Dr. Abdul Hafeez Shaikh, Adviser to the Prime Minister on Finance and Revenue, informed US investors that Pakistan's economy is stabilizing and encouraged them to expand their investments in the country. During his visit to the US for the IMF/WB annual meetings, Shaikh met with various financial institutions' representatives, including the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, Islamic Development Bank, and IFC, to discuss funding for Pakistan's development. He emphasized the government's efforts to improve the ease of doing business in Pakistan.

title: Exclusive: SEC probes oilfield firm ProPetro over accounting, disclosures: sources
summary: Oilfield services supplier ProPetro Holding Corp is under investigation by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission concerning potential securities laws violations related to its financial disclosures and internal controls. The probe follows an internal board review that led to executive changes and expense reimbursements. ProPetro's shares fell significantly after the investigation was disclosed.

title: ExxonMobil Corp. considering cracker plant in Beaver County
summary: ExxonMobil Corp. is exploring the possibility of building a petrochemical cracker plant in Beaver County, Pennsylvania, similar to Shell Chemicals' existing facility. Company brokers have visited the area to renew discussions, and while ExxonMobil is considering multiple locations, a decision for a regional site could come by year-end. This potential development excites local leaders due to its economic benefits, despite some concerns about infrastructure stress.

title: The story of Smilin’ Jack, Wilmington’s huge pumpkin-shaped oil tank
summary: The article details the 67-year-old Halloween tradition of "Smilin' Jack," a giant pumpkin face painted on an 80,000-barrel oil tank at the Phillips 66 refinery in Wilmington. The tradition started in 1952 when Union Oil operators noticed the tank's pumpkin-like appearance after a primer coat. Smilin' Jack features a 73-foot grin and 18-foot tall eyes, with the tradition including costumed characters and caramel corn for visitors.

title: Billie Jean King Leadership Award Recipient
summary: Ursula Burns, former Chairman and CEO of Xerox Corporation and VEON, Ltd., has been named the 2020 Billie Jean King Leadership Award recipient due to her influential career dedicated to diversity and breaking barriers for women leaders. As the first Black woman to head a Fortune 500 company, Burns has consistently advocated for gender and racial diversity in corporate America. She will receive the award at the Women's Sports Foundation 2020 Salute to Women in Sport event on October 14.

title: Exclusive: ExxonMobil scouts potential cracker sites in Beaver County
authors: Paul J. Gough and Tim Schooley
summary: ExxonMobil is reportedly searching for a potential site in Beaver County for a new petrochemical facility. Brokers representing the company were in the area discussing the possibility of building a cracker plant to serve its customers. This development follows other significant petrochemical investments in the region.

title: World's top three asset managers oversee $300bn fossil fuel investments
summary: The world's three largest asset managers, BlackRock, Vanguard, and State Street, collectively oversee $300bn in fossil fuel investments, utilizing private savings and pension contributions. Data shows these firms have grown significant stakes in carbon-intensive companies since the Paris Agreement and have often opposed climate-related shareholder motions. While offering "climate-friendly" funds, they face scrutiny for their substantial fossil fuel holdings and the conflicting nature of their business models.

title: Exxon Mobil considers sale of M'sian offshore assets for up to $3 billion - Bloomberg
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is reportedly considering selling its Malaysian upstream offshore assets for an estimated $2 billion to $3 billion. This potential divestment comes as part of Exxon's broader plan to offload about $15 billion in non-strategic assets by 2021, following a recent sale of its Norwegian operations. The sale considerations are currently at a preliminary stage.

title: Halliburton Awarded License for Gravel Pack Completions
summary: Halliburton has been awarded an international license for ExxonMobil's patented Non-Aqueous Fluid Gravel Packing (NAFPac) technique. This technology allows for running gravel-pack screens in non-aqueous fluid, gravel packing the well, and then displacing to completion brine all in a single trip, increasing installation success and overall reliability. The NAFPac technique has been utilized in over 150 applications and aims to provide cost-effective and productive completions for clients.

title: Is the U.S. Oil Industry Dominant? On the Verge of Oblivion? Neither (Published 2019)
summary: The US oil industry has shown surprising resilience to geopolitical tensions and attacks on oil production, suggesting neither dominance nor impending oblivion. Despite significant disruptions like sanctions, tanker seizures, and a drone attack on Saudi Arabia that impacted 6% of world production, oil markets have remained relatively stable. This unexpected stability is attributed to the strength gained by the United States in oil markets, even without being a low-cost producer.

title: Las acciones argentinas lograron sortear el derrumbe en Wall Street: cuál ganó más
summary: Argentine stocks defied a general downturn on Wall Street, which saw major U.S. indices fall by an average of 1.7%. While global economic recession fears impacted American companies like American Express, Apple, and Exxon Mobil, Argentine ADRs such as Banco Macro (+4%), Grupo Financiero Galicia (+2.7%), and Banco Supervielle (+2.6%) saw gains. The local S&P Merval index also rose by 2.3%, with Transportadora de Gas del Norte leading with a 7.2% increase.

title: How Big Oil Of The Past Helped Launch The Solar Industry Of Today
summary: This article details how major oil companies, particularly Exxon and Atlantic Richfield (ARCO), played a significant role in the early development of the solar industry. Driven by strategic concerns about oil supply and diversification, these companies invested in research, development, and manufacturing of solar photovoltaic technology, laying a crucial foundation for today's multibillion-dollar solar industry. Despite their early leadership, oil companies eventually divested from solar as oil prices stabilized, though their contributions to cost reduction and market expansion were substantial.

title: Hibernia Platform Resumes Production
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced on Friday that production has resumed at its Hibernia oil platform in Canada, which had been shut down last month due to a power outage. The Hibernia platform has been operating since 1997 and is located approximately 315 km (200 miles) east of St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, with ExxonMobil holding the largest stake.

title: Enterprise Products Partners builds multibillion dollar empire ‘chasing demand’
summary: Enterprise Products Partners has built a multi-billion dollar empire by rapidly identifying and exploiting opportunities in the energy market, particularly through strategic investments in pipelines, processing plants, and export terminals. Founded in 1968, the company now dominates the U.S. crude oil, ethane, propane, and butane export markets, leveraging its significant infrastructure and a strategy of "chasing demand" to maintain profitability. Despite market challenges, Enterprise continues to expand its reach with new projects and investments, especially at the Mont Belvieu complex and along the Houston Ship Channel.

title: Argos Resources looking new partners to participate in Falklands oil industry
summary: Argos Resources reported an interim loss of US$176,000 for the first half of 2019 but confirmed it is adequately financed for the next 12 months due to quarterly payments from Noble Energy Falklands Ltd and Edison International SPA. These payments stem from the two companies' withdrawal from the PL001 production license in the North Falkland Basin. Argos is now seeking new partners for the license's development and is in discussions with the Falkland Islands government to extend the permit.

title: Big Oil CEOs talk climate change, methane and why they need gas
summary: During Climate Week in New York, CEOs from major oil and gas companies like Shell, Exxon Mobil, Total, and Occidental Petroleum discussed climate change, methane emissions, and the role of natural gas. They emphasized the industry's responsibility in the energy transition, the need for technological evolution, and the importance of initiatives like carbon capture and methane leakage detection. The discussions highlighted the challenge of balancing rising energy needs with climate concerns.

title: EX-99.1
summary: Talos Energy Inc. announced two separate agreements with BP and ExxonMobil for new exploration opportunities in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico. Talos will partner with BP on the Puma West prospect, retaining a 25% working interest, and has acquired a 100% working interest in the Hershey prospect from ExxonMobil, becoming the designated operator. These transactions aim to leverage Talos's technical expertise and infrastructure to unlock significant oil-weighted resources.

title: 7 Oil ETFs to Buy to Invest in Black Gold
summary: This article identifies seven Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) that offer investors a way to capitalize on the short-term fluctuations in crude oil prices, which can be significant despite long-term trends favoring cleaner energy. It details various types of oil-related ETFs, from direct crude futures exposure to investments in oil services, exploration and production, and global energy companies, catering to different risk appetites and investment strategies within the "black gold" market.

title: ExxonMobil Looks to Sell Australian Assets
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is seeking to sell its 50% stake in the Gippsland Basin oil and gas development in Australia's Bass Strait, part of a global portfolio review; the sale could fetch up to $3 billion. The aging fields, which have been a primary supplier for southeastern Australia, are seeing declining output. Potential bidders are expected to include other companies operating in the Bass Strait, such as Mitsui & Co, Beach Energy, and Cooper Energy, possibly forming a consortium due to the significant price.

title: Imperial Oil CEO Rich Kruger to retire at year end, after nearly 7 years in the role
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. announced that CEO Rich Kruger will retire at the end of the year after nearly seven years in the role. Brad Corson, formerly of Exxon Mobil Corp.'s upstream ventures, has been appointed president and will assume the CEO position on January 1, 2020. The company's stock has seen an 8.3% decline over the past 12 months, contrasting with a 3.8% gain for the S&P 500 during the same period.

title: Oil prices soar after attacks on Saudi facilities
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 15% after drone attacks on Saudi Arabian facilities disrupted 5% of global oil supply. Analysts warn that sustained outages could push prices higher, while the US and Saudi Arabia attribute the attacks to Iran, escalating regional tensions. The long-term impact on consumer fuel prices remains uncertain, with some experts suggesting initial increases, while others point to existing market adjustments and reserves.

title: Why the Saudi oil attack is a ‘big deal’ that could be a ‘game changer’ in stock markets and crude prices
summary: The article discusses the significant impact of the Saudi oil attacks on global energy markets and crude prices, calling it a "game changer." S&P Global Platts forecasts a potential $5 to $10 per barrel spike in Brent oil prices due to the disruption. The attacks on Saudi Aramco’s Abqaiq plant and a nearby oil field on September 14, 2019, resulted in a shutdown that could temporarily cut approximately 50% of Saudi Arabia's crude oil production.

title: Low-cost fracking offers boon to oil producers, headaches for suppliers
summary: A new electric fracking technology, powered by natural gas, is enabling oil producers like EOG Resources, Royal Dutch Shell, and Exxon Mobil to cut well costs by up to $350,000, reducing pollution and noise. While this innovation benefits producers, it creates significant challenges for oilfield service providers due to high construction costs for the new e-frac fleets and an unfavorable economic imbalance. Despite the benefits, widespread adoption is slow because service companies are unwilling to invest in expensive new equipment given the current market and the disproportionate savings for producers.

title: New Report Finds Record-Breaking U.S. Natural Gas Reserves
summary: A new report by the Potential Gas Committee and the American Gas Association reveals that U.S. recoverable natural gas reserves have reached a record high of 3,374 trillion cubic feet (Tcf), marking a 20 percent increase over the 2016 assessment. This increase is attributed to technological innovations in shale, conventional, and tight gas extraction, particularly in the Atlantic and Mid-Continent regions. The report emphasizes the economic and environmental benefits of natural gas, while noting that some presidential candidates are considering policies that could negatively impact this sector.

title: US Judge Rejects Exxon, Shell Nigeria Case
summary: A U.S. judge rejected Exxon Mobil Corp's and Royal Dutch Shell Plc's attempt to revive a $1.8 billion arbitration award against Nigeria's state-run oil company, Nigerian National Petroleum Corp (NNPC). The judge cited public policy and due process considerations, noting that the original award was set aside by Nigerian courts and appeals are still pending there. The companies had sought to enforce the award stemming from a 1993 contract dispute over oil extraction.

title: Hess Announces Arrival of Liza Destiny Offshore Guyana
summary: Hess Corporation announced the arrival of the Liza Destiny, Guyana's first oil production vessel, at the Stabroek Block after a 42-day journey from Singapore. This Floating, Production, Storage and Offloading (FPSO) vessel is crucial for the Liza Phase 1 development, which is expected to start by Q1 2020 and produce up to 120,000 gross barrels of oil per day. Hess Guyana Exploration Ltd. holds a 30 percent interest in the Stabroek Block, with ExxonMobil and CNOOC Petroleum Guyana Limited holding 45 percent and 25 percent respectively.

title: BP Exits Alaska After 60 Years in $5.6 Billion Hilcorp Sale
summary: BP has announced its departure from Alaska after six decades, selling its entire business in the state to Hilcorp Energy Co. for $5.6 billion. This deal includes BP's operating stake in Prudhoe Bay and all its Alaskan pipelines, marking the largest acquisition in Hilcorp's history and forming the majority of BP's two-year, $10 billion divestment plan. The move reflects BP's strategy to align investments with its long-term goals while Alaska's oil production continues to decline.

title: TechnipFMC celebrates subsea milestone in Brazil
summary: TechnipFMC celebrated a significant milestone in Brazil with the delivery of its 600th subsea tree. This subsea tree, destined for ExxonMobil’s Liza field off Guyana, was signed by company officials and Guyanese employees during an event in Rio de Janeiro. The achievement highlights TechnipFMC's long-standing presence and commitment to quality in the subsea industry.

title: California rare earths miner races to refine amid U.S.-China trade row
summary: MP Materials, owner of the only U.S. rare earths mine, is investing $200 million and hiring significantly to restart domestic rare earths refining by next year. This move comes as China escalates tariffs on rare earth imports, fueling U.S. national security concerns over its reliance on China for processing these critical minerals. The company aims to reduce U.S. dependence on China for rare earth processing and potentially encourage further domestic investment in magnet production.

title: Equinor expands its cooperation with YPF for offshore exploration in Argentina
summary: Equinor and YPF have signed an agreement to jointly explore the CAN 100 offshore block in the North Argentinian Basin, expanding their existing partnership. This collaboration strengthens Equinor's position in offshore Argentina and allows YPF to benefit from Equinor's global offshore experience. The CAN 100 block is the largest in the North Argentinian Basin, covering 15,000 km2.

title: Chevron is a better bet than Exxon, Barclays says
summary: Barclays analysts, led by Jeanine Wai, initiated coverage on Chevron and Exxon Mobil, recommending Chevron over Exxon. While both companies are driven by West Texas's Permian Basin, Chevron's "superior" cash position gives it an edge. Barclays rated Chevron the equivalent of a buy and Exxon the equivalent of neutral shares.

title: Chevron is a better bet than Exxon, Barclays says
summary: Barclays analysts rated Chevron as a better investment than Exxon, citing Chevron's "superior" cash position. The Permian Basin is a key factor for both companies, but Chevron was given a "buy" rating while Exxon received a "neutral" rating from the analysts led by Jeanine Wai.

title: Hibernia Platform Resumes Production
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced that production has resumed at Canada's Hibernia oil platform after a spill in mid-July. The company stated that the platform will gradually return to full production in a safe and environmentally responsible manner. ExxonMobil holds the largest stake in the Hibernia project, which has been producing oil since 1997.

title: Exxon Mobil says Hibernia oil platform resumes production
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced that production has resumed at its Hibernia oil platform after a spill in mid-July. The company stated that the platform will gradually return to full production in a safe and environmentally responsible manner. The Hibernia platform, which has been operational since 1997, is located east of St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, and ExxonMobil holds the largest stake in the project.

title: Shell Awards Prelude FLNG Contract
summary: Shell Australia has awarded Flowserve Corp. a five-year general maintenance services contract for its Prelude Floating Liquefied Natural Gas (FLNG) facility. Flowserve will support the facility from its Quick Response Center (QRC) in Darwin, expanding its services and creating new local employment opportunities. Prelude FLNG, operated by Shell, began shipping LNG earlier this year and is described as the largest offshore floating facility ever built.

title: Delek US to acquire stake in Wink to Webster Pipeline in Texas
summary: Delek US has agreed to acquire a 15% stake in the Wink to Webster Pipeline joint venture, which is set to develop a 1,046km-long pipeline capable of transporting over one million barrels of crude oil and condensate daily from the Permian Basin to the Texas Gulf Coast. The net investment for Delek US is estimated between $340-$380m, with the pipeline expected to be operational in the first half of 2021. This move aims to enhance Delek US's midstream portfolio and generate commercial opportunities.

title: Crude curtailment 'no way to run a railroad,' says Imperial Oil CEO
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. CEO Rich Kruger criticizes Alberta's crude curtailment program, stating it has made crude-by-rail uneconomical and should end. He plans to significantly reduce rail movements due to eroding profitability, despite the program's success in reducing crude inventories and discounts. Imperial Oil also announced strong second-quarter results, beating analyst expectations, and identified the cause of a fractionation tower collapse at its Sarnia refinery.

title: Cómo será el nuevo gasoducto a Vaca Muerta
summary: The Argentine government has called for tenders to construct a new central gas pipeline to Vaca Muerta, which will be the country's third transport concession. The project will be divided into two main stages, connecting Tratayén to Salliqueló and then extending to San Nicolás, with an estimated cost of $800 million for the first stage. Strict operational experience requirements narrow down potential operators primarily to Transportadora Gas del Sur (TGS) or Transportadora Gas del Norte (TGN).

title: Flames, smoke billow from ExxonMobil plant
summary: A fire erupted at ExxonMobil's Baytown, Texas, refining and chemical plant complex, injuring over 30 people and prompting a shelter-in-place order for nearby residents. The fire originated in a Propylene Recovery Unit, and while its impact on production is unknown, all Exxon staff were accounted for, and air quality monitoring is underway. This incident marks the latest in a series of petrochemical industry fires in the Houston area.

title: Chevron, Exxon earnings: Shale M&A is high on the list of investor concerns
summary: Chevron and Exxon Mobil are preparing to report their second-quarter earnings. A primary concern for investors remains the ongoing M&A activity in the U.S. shale sector, highlighted by Chevron's recent loss in the bid for Anadarko Petroleum to Occidental.

title: Chevron, Exxon earnings: Shale M&A is high on the list of investor concerns
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. are preparing to report second-quarter earnings, with investor attention focused on U.S. shale M&A activities and concerns about flagging oil demand. Chevron's upcoming earnings report will be particularly scrutinized as it follows their failed bid for Anadarko Petroleum Corp., which was ultimately acquired by Occidental Petroleum Corp.

title: Chevron Gets Approval to Keep Producing Oil in Venezuela
summary: Chevron Corp. and four oil services companies received U.S. government approval to continue oil production in Venezuela, extending a sanctions waiver for three months until October 25. This decision allows Chevron, the only major U.S. producer still in the country, to maintain its joint venture with Petroleos de Venezuela SA, ensuring U.S. interests remain while avoiding potential asset transfers to other nations. The U.S. government uses sanctions to pressure the Maduro regime, and Venezuela's opposition has guaranteed protection of Chevron's assets under a new government.

title: Giant gas stations turning into Speedway stations
summary: Giant gas stations are being rebranded as Speedway stations following a $23.3 billion merger in 2018 between Marathon Petroleum Corp. and Andeavor. Marathon, which operates Speedway, acquired Andeavor's shares, creating the largest refiner in the United States and expanding Speedway's convenience store count significantly. The cambio primarily affects visual branding and rewards programs, with gas and merchandise remaining largely similar, although fountain drink prices have been lowered.

title: Tapping the opportunities of U.S. liquefied natural gas
summary: This article discusses the revolution in global energy markets driven by the abundance of U.S. natural gas and LNG plants, especially highlighting developments in Cameron Parish, Louisiana. It emphasizes the complexities and challenges for U.S. companies in this evolving market, including increasing competition and geopolitical uncertainties. The authors suggest that success depends on best-in-class capabilities in sales, marketing, trading, capital project execution, and operational excellence.

title: Louis Vuitton Owner Bernard Arnault Replaces Microsoft’s Bill Gates as World’s 2nd Richest Person
summary: Bernard Arnault, owner of Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy (LVMH), has surpassed Bill Gates to become the world's second-richest person according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Arnault's net worth rose to US$107.6 billion due to a US$39 billion gain in 2019 alone, pushing Gates to the third position. This shift highlights the significant wealth accumulation of top billionaires.

title: Decreto de Necesidad y Urgencia para licitar el nuevo gasoducto desde Vaca Muerta
summary: Argentina is set to launch a national and international public tender for a new gas pipeline from Vaca Muerta, supported by an Emergency Decree (DNU) signed by President Mauricio Macri. The pipeline aims to connect the Neuquén subzone to Salliqueló and the Greater Buenos Aires/Litoral subzones, alleviating transport congestion and enabling increased natural gas production and exports. The project, estimated at $1.5 billion, will be financed by firm contracts with gas producers and power generators, with the DNU fast-tracking the process to ensure operability by winter 2021 and avoid significant economic losses.

title: Santana becomes Wabtec CEO
summary: Rafael Santana, former CEO of GE Transportation, began his new role as CEO of Westinghouse Air Brake Technologies Corp. (Wabtec) on Monday, July 1. Santana, 47, previously led Wabtec's Chicago-based freight division and takes over from the retiring Raymond Betler. Wabtec, a Fortune 500 company, has approximately 27,000 employees and annual revenues of about $8 billion.

title: Is US Energy Independence On Its Way?
summary: The article discusses the concept of US energy independence, defining it primarily as becoming a net energy exporter. It highlights the US's progress towards this milestone through increased domestic oil and natural gas production and emphasizes the significant role of midstream companies in supporting this shift, despite the continued need for some energy imports due to refining requirements.

title: Devon Energy bringing office to Hobbs, New Mexico second in oil and gas rig count
summary: Devon Energy is opening a new office in Hobbs, New Mexico, to house 40 employees, strengthening its presence in the Permian Basin. This move comes as New Mexico maintains a stable oil and gas rig count, tying with Oklahoma for second place nationally, despite a slight decline in the overall Permian Basin rig count. The article also touches on oil price fluctuations and rising U.S. oil inventory amidst global economic tensions.

title: Fund face-off: Are your investments LGBTQ-friendly?
summary: This article compares two exchange-traded funds (ETFs) with opposing views on LGBTQ+ issues: the Inspire Global Hope ETF (BLES), which screens against LGBTQ+ activism based on biblical convictions, and the InsightShares LGBT Employment Equality ETF (PRID), which invests in companies with proactive LGBTQ+ policies. While PRID has outperformed BLES financially, its inclusion of companies like Exxon Mobil and Lockheed Martin raises questions about overall ethical alignment. The author emphasizes the importance of thoroughly examining fund holdings due to potential "greenwashing" in the ethical ETF market.

title: Is Oil on Its Way Back up to $100 Per Barrel?
summary: This article examines the factors contributing to the 2019 surge in crude oil prices, including OPEC+ production cuts, geopolitical tensions in Iran, Libya, and Venezuela, and US sanctions. It discusses whether these factors are strong enough to push oil back to $100 per barrel and highlights differing forecasts from various institutions and analysts. The piece concludes by noting the significant influence of Saudi Arabia's output decisions and the upcoming OPEC+ meeting.

title: Husband’s response to Kentuckian Kelly Craft’s government email complicates UN nomination
summary: The article details how an email response from coal magnate Joseph Craft, husband of U.S. ambassador Kelly Craft, to an EPA email addressed to his wife is complicating her nomination to be U.S. ambassador to the United Nations. Critics and ethics experts are raising concerns about the blurring of roles and potential conflicts of interest given Joseph Craft's coal industry ties and Kelly Craft's initial skepticism about climate change, despite her recent statements. This situation highlights ongoing concerns about the Trump administration's relationship with the coal industry and its impact on environmental policy.

title: Linde plans $1.4 billion Singapore expansion, signs Exxon supply deal
summary: Linde announced a $1.4 billion investment to expand its Singapore gasification facilities to support Exxon Mobil Corp's integrated refining complex expansion. The project will involve building additional gasifiers and processing units, enabling Linde to supply hydrogen and synthesis gas to Exxon and other Jurong Island customers by 2023. This expansion aligns with new IMO regulations on marine fuel emissions.

title: Pembina Peace Pipeline Expansion, Alberta, Canada
summary: The Pembina Peace Pipeline, a natural gas liquids and condensate pipeline in Alberta, Canada, is undergoing multiple expansion phases to increase its capacity to 1.3 million barrels a day. Phases four and five were completed in late 2018, while phases six, seven, and eight are scheduled for commissioning between 2020 and 2022, with an estimated combined cost of $1.73 billion. These expansions will involve new pipelines, pump stations, and terminal upgrades to accommodate growing customer demand and increased production from various resource plays.

title: US said readying to evacuate contractors from Iraqi base due to security threat
summary: The U.S. is reportedly preparing to evacuate nearly 400 contractors from the Balad military base in Iraq due to unspecified security threats, amid heightened tensions between Washington and Tehran. These contractors work for Lockheed Martin Corp and Sallyport Global. This move follows recent rocket attacks on Iraqi bases hosting U.S. troops and assets.

title: Oscar Sardi, CEO de TGS: “Vaca Muerta tiene que ser una política de Estado”
summary: Oscar Sardi, CEO of Transportadora Gas del Sur (TGS), emphasizes the critical importance of Vaca Muerta as a state policy for Argentina's energy future, highlighting its immense potential and the need for significant infrastructure investments. TGS is investing $300 million in a new gas pipeline in Vaca Muerta and plans to participate in the tender for the new Transportadora Gas del Centro, aiming to increase gas transport capacity and reduce imports. Sardi discusses the company's financial performance, its investment plans, and its satisfaction with current gas prices despite the country's economic situation.

title: Chevron Phillips Chemical in $15 billion bid to acquire Nova Chemicals
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical (CPCHEM) has made a US$15 billion bid to acquire Nova Chemicals, a move that would make CPCHEM the third-largest polyethylene producer in North America and the largest producer of high-density polyethylene (HDPE) in the region. The acquisition is expected to create significant synergies in the polyethylene and polystyrene sectors, expanding CPCHEM's geographic market reach and technological edge. This deal underscores the trend of "Big Oil" diversifying into the petrochemical sector as a growth engine and a means for margin security amidst a consolidating market and challenging economic outlook.

title: Italian Energy Giant Rejects Suspected Iran Oil
summary: Italian oil company Eni SpA rejected a shipment of suspected Iranian crude oil, citing specifications that did not match its contract and properties consistent with Iranian crude. This incident highlights the challenges energy companies face in navigating US sanctions against Iran, due to the Iranian regime's deceptive shipping practices like ship-to-ship transfers and disabling tracking systems. The rejected cargo, originally believed to be Iraqi oil from Nigeria’s Oando PLC, had been transferred multiple times before reaching Eni.
source: National Council of Resistance of Iran - NCRI
source_domain: National Council of Resistance of Iran - NCRI

title: Anadarko approves $20 billion LNG export project in Mozambique
summary: U.S. energy firm Anadarko Petroleum Corp has approved a $20 billion gas liquefaction and export terminal in Mozambique, marking Africa's largest single LNG project. This decision was largely expected and is set to transform Mozambique's economy while positioning the project to meet growing Asian and European energy demands. The project secured long-term buyers despite a recent slump in LNG prices, demonstrating industry confidence in future demand.

title: Have It All, Part 9 - Marathon Petroleum/Andeavor Logistics’ Permian Crude Gathering System
summary: This article, part of the "Have It All" series, examines Marathon Petroleum/Andeavor Logistics’ evolving crude gathering system in the Permian Basin. It discusses how the system, initially small, has grown to become a key integrated asset within its owners' larger value chain, connecting crude production to refineries or export terminals. The piece also details the complex mergers and acquisitions involving MPC, MPLX, and Andeavor Logistics that shaped the current infrastructure.

title: 10 Things You Didn’t Know About WESCO International CEO John Engel
summary: This article details ten facts about John J. Engel, the CEO of WESCO International, highlighting his educational background, significant net worth, career milestones, and his roles in various influential business organizations. It covers his financial compensation, stock holdings, and leadership positions beyond WESCO, including directorships and memberships in prominent business councils. The article also touches upon the challenges he faced early in his CEO tenure during the Great Recession.

title: Energy Investing Showdown: Midstream/MLPs vs. Majors vs. Broader Energy
summary: This article compares midstream/MLPs, integrated energy majors (like Exxon and Chevron), and broader energy investments, highlighting their defensive characteristics and performance.
