Midstream has outperformed this year due to its fee-based business model and resilience to commodity price volatility. The article also discusses tradeoffs in yield, oil price sensitivity, and diversification for investors considering these energy investment options.

title: Saudi’s Sabic, Exxon Mobil approve Texas chemical plant plan
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp and Saudi Basic Industries Corp (Sabic) have formally approved the construction of a new chemical complex in Texas. The project, located near Corpus Christi, will be the world’s largest steam cracker and is expected to generate $50 billion in "economic output" within its first six years. This joint venture marks Sabic's first outside Saudi Arabia and highlights the growing importance of petrochemicals as a driver for global oil and gas markets.

title: Inside General Electric's moves to turn off the lights at its venture capital arm
summary: General Electric is looking to sell off its venture capital arm, GE Ventures, which has invested in hundreds of companies since its founding in 2013. The portfolio, valued at approximately $500 million, is considered to be of moderate strength and is subject to significant discounts in the secondary market. GE Ventures is effectively no longer making new investments as it seeks a buyer and evaluates strategic options.

title: Exxon-Sabic Texas Project to Create Nearly 7,000 Jobs
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. and Saudi Basic Industries Corp. (SABIC) are moving forward with the construction of a 1.8-million-metric-ton ethane steam cracker complex near Corpus Christi, Texas. This project is projected to create over 6,600 jobs, including 6,000 during construction and more than 600 permanent operational jobs with an average annual salary of $90,000. Construction is expected to begin in the third quarter of 2019, with startup slated for 2022, marking SABIC's first joint venture with ExxonMobil outside of Saudi Arabia.

title: Eni enters into cooperation pact with KazMunayGas
summary: Kazakhstan’s state-owned oil and gas company KazMunayGas (KMG) and Eni’s affiliate, Agip Caspian Sea B.V., signed a memorandum of cooperation to expand their relationship. The pact focuses on technological cooperation in hydrocarbon exploration and production, co-development opportunities, and staff training for KMG. This agreement strengthens their long-term partnership, particularly as partners in the giant Kashagan field.

title: Plug and Play Announces Partnership with Phillips 66
summary: Plug and Play, a global innovation platform, announced a partnership with Phillips 66, a diversified energy manufacturing and logistics company. Phillips 66 will join Plug and Play's Energy & Sustainability platform to connect with innovative startups focusing on areas like workforce safety, operational efficiency, and supply chain. This collaboration aims to bridge Houston's energy industry with Silicon Valley's technological advancements.

title: Exxon Mobil to pay $1M to settle oil spill in Yellowstone River
summary: A judge has approved an agreement for Exxon Mobil Corp. to pay $1.05 million to settle federal pollution violations stemming from a 2011 pipeline break that released 63,000 gallons of crude oil into Montana's Yellowstone River. This settlement resolves the final federal enforcement case against Exxon regarding the incident. Exxon had previously paid $12 million for natural resource damage, $2.6 million for pipeline safety and state pollution violations, and spent an estimated $135 million on cleanup and repairs.

title: Devon Energy Announces Strategic Exit of Canadian Business for CAD $3.8 Billion
summary: Devon Energy announced its strategic exit from its Canadian business, agreeing to sell its assets to Canadian Natural Resources Limited for CAD $3.8 billion (USD $2.8 billion). This sale is a key step in Devon's transformation into a U.S. oil growth business, with proceeds earmarked for debt reduction. The company also plans to divest its Barnett Shale gas assets by the end of 2019 to complete its focus on high-return U.S. oil plays.

title: Canadian Natural buys assets for $3.8-billion as Devon Energy exits Canada’s oil patch
summary: Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. is acquiring the Alberta assets of Devon Energy Corp. for $3.8-billion, marking another foreign company's exit from Western Canada's oil fields. The acquisition is expected to boost CNRL's earnings per share and free cash flow, making it Canada's largest crude producer. The deal highlights ongoing challenges for Alberta's oil industry, including limited export capacity and regulatory concerns.

title: Plains All American enters joint venture to expand Red River Pipeline
summary: Plains All American Pipeline has formed a joint venture with Delek US to expand the capacity of its Red River Pipeline. This $128 million deal will boost the pipeline's capacity from 150,000 to approximately 235,000 barrels per day by the first half of 2020. The expansion aligns with Plains' strategy to optimize existing systems and allows Delek, an existing customer, to significantly increase its committed capacity on the pipeline.

title: Suncor’s hydrogen-cyanide emissions exceeded permit last year; Colorado now weighing refinery’s request to increase limit
summary: Suncor Energy's Commerce City refinery exceeded its permit limit for hydrogen cyanide emissions in 2018, releasing 14.1 tons against a 12.8-ton limit. Colorado health officials have not penalized Suncor and are currently considering the refinery's request to increase its permit limit for hydrogen cyanide to 19.9 tons annually, raising concerns among residents and environmental advocates about air quality and regulatory oversight. The article highlights the ongoing debate between environmental concerns, community health impacts, and the state's regulatory approach to industrial pollution.

title: Saudi oil giant Aramco strikes deal to buy US natural gas from Sempra Energy
summary: Saudi Aramco has signed an agreement with Sempra Energy to buy 5 million tons of liquefied natural gas (LNG) per year for 20 years from Sempra's proposed Port Arthur, Texas export terminal. This deal signifies Aramco's push to become a major player in the global gas market and provides a significant boost for Sempra in financing the multi-billion dollar facility. If finalized, it would be one of the largest LNG deals ever signed, enabling Aramco to nearly double its total gas production and compete more directly with global energy companies.

title: Imperial Oil Resources Ltd.: 2019 Harmattan Offering
summary: Imperial Oil Resources Limited, on behalf of ExxonMobil Canada Energy, has initiated a process for the disposition of its Harmattan asset in central Alberta. The offering includes over 85,000 gross/49,000 net hectares with 2018 average production of 4,500 BOE per day, 54% liquids, primarily from Cardium, Viking, and Mississippian formations. Interested parties can access a virtual data room starting May 23, 2019, with non-binding proposals due by June 27, 2019.

title: When fairness matters, more disclosure is key
authors: Martin E. Kovnats and Sean Mason
summary: This article discusses the evolving role and scrutiny of fairness opinions in Canadian mergers and acquisitions. It highlights how courts and regulators are increasingly demanding greater disclosure, transparency regarding fee arrangements, and detailed analysis to support these opinions, moving beyond just stating independence or flat fees. The piece suggests that issuers should provide more comprehensive disclosure, methodology, and analysis to ensure their fairness opinions are robust and accepted in legal challenges.

title: Four 3X Leveraged Oil ETFs to Get Slick With Trading
summary: Despite U.S.-China trade tensions, oil and gas operators remain optimistic about commodity prices for the rest of 2019, anticipating a price range of $65-$75 per barrel. This optimism is driving continued capital spending and potential growth. For ETF traders looking to capitalize on this outlook, the article highlights four 3X leveraged oil ETFs: United States 3x Oil (USOU), UBS ETRACS ProShares Dly 3x Lng Crud ETN (WTIU), VelocityShares 3x Lng Crude Oil ETN New (UWT), and ProShares UltraPro 3x Crude Oil ETF (OILU).

title: Where Does the United States Export Oil?
summary: The United States' crude oil exports in 2018 were primarily directed to Canada (19%), Korea (12%), and China (11%), with the top five countries accounting for 57% of total exports. When petroleum products are included, Mexico becomes the top destination. The industry is also developing infrastructure, such as Enterprise Products Partners' new export terminal, to support increasing crude oil exports.

title: Occidental CEO Battles Oil-Field Giant to Rule the Permian Basin
Jordan Cove LNG slows spending, delays project to wait for permits
summary: Pembina Pipeline Corp., the backer of the Jordan Cove LNG project, is cutting its projected spending by half and delaying the project's startup by a year as it awaits key state and federal permits. The company plans to spend $50 million this year on the $10 billion project, down from a previous forecast of $100 million, while facing a challenging market with plummeted LNG prices in Asia and competition from other export facilities. Analysts like Robert McCullough suggest the project faces a significant cost disadvantage and question its viability given current market conditions and stronger competitors.

title: Exxon Mobil sues Cuba for $280 million over expropriated property
summary: Exxon Mobil sued Cuba's state-owned Cuba-Petroleo and CIMEX Corp for $280 million over assets seized after Fidel Castro's revolution, becoming the first corporation to sue Cuba since the Trump administration allowed a long-dormant section of the 1996 Helms-Burton Act to take effect. The lawsuit targets a refinery, gasoline stations, and other properties, aligning Exxon Mobil with other large claimants and potentially increasing international pressure on Cuba. Cuba maintains its nationalization of property was legal and that the lawsuit violates international law.

title: Exxon OKs $2B Baytown chemical expansion project
summary: Exxon has approved a $2 billion chemical expansion project in Baytown, Texas, which is part of its larger $20 billion "Growing the Gulf" initiative. This expansion signifies a continued investment in the region and follows several other significant projects by Exxon, as highlighted by related articles mentioning refinery expansions and LNG export projects.

title: DowDuPont Is Splitting Into 3 Companies. Here’s Everything You Need to Know.
summary: DowDuPont, the world's largest chemical conglomerate with $86 billion in 2018 sales, is splitting into three independent companies: Dow, DuPont, and Corteva. Dow will focus on commodity chemicals, DuPont on specialty chemicals, and Corteva on agricultural chemicals and seeds. This article explains the rationale behind the split, details what each new company will produce, and offers advice for investors on understanding the upcoming changes and investment opportunities.

title: Top 2019 GOM Equity Producers
summary: A combined Chevron and Anadarko entity would top the list of 2019 Gulf of Mexico equity producers, according to Rystad Energy, yielding over 400,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. BP plc and Royal Dutch Shell plc secured second and third positions, respectively, while Equinor ASA and Fieldwood Energy LLC rounded out the top five. The article also mentions recent acquisition activities impacting the GOM production landscape, including Chevron's bid for Anadarko and Murphy Oil Corporation's acquisition of deepwater GOM assets.

title: IEEFA Argentina: Vaca Muerta development stalled?
summary: The provincial government controlling Argentina's Vaca Muerta oil and gas reserves faces challenges in spurring serious development from concession holders, with many companies not announcing plans for increased investment as their pilot phases end. Of 13 concessions ending pilot periods soon, eight have not declared development plans, leading the government to demand action. This inaction raises concerns about Argentina's ability to meet its ambitious energy production goals and suggests some companies may be engaging in "real estate speculation" rather than active development.
source: Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA)
source_domain: Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA)

title: Asphalt | bp Products and services | bp America
summary: BP America provides asphalt products and solutions for roadway construction and maintenance, operating one of the largest asphalt-producing refineries in Whiting, IN, and state-of-the-art terminals in Chicago and Bartlett, IL. They offer a range of performance-graded asphalt binders suitable for paving and industrial applications, serving customers across the Midwest, US, and Canada. The company emphasizes its expertise and customer support through an experienced sales, marketing, and technical team.

title: New Orleans Sues Oil and Gas Companies to Preserve Wetlands, But Is That Enough?
summary: New Orleans has filed a lawsuit against 11 oil and gas companies, accusing them of destroying surrounding wetlands, similar to other suits filed by Louisiana parishes. Mayor LaToya Cantrell stated the city and its people have been harmed, with their way of life threatened by the loss of coastal wetlands. The suit alleges violations of the state's Coastal Zone Management Act of 1978, by failing to restore damage or clean up hazardous waste, contributing to the rapid land loss that exacerbated the impact of Hurricane Katrina.

title: Occidental Petroleum outbids Chevron for Anadarko Petroleum
summary: Occidental Petroleum has outbid Chevron for Anadarko Petroleum with a cash-and-stock offer valued at approximately $57 billion, a 20 percent premium over Chevron's $33 billion deal. This move intensifies the competition for Anadarko's assets, especially its lucrative Permian Basin position, Gulf of Mexico presence, and a natural gas project in Mozambique, amid rising U.S. crude prices. The takeover would significantly boost Occidental's position in the Permian Basin, with the company aiming to complete the combination by the end of the year.

title: Allstate Insurance to create 1,300 new jobs in major expansion of Irving operations
summary: Allstate Insurance Co. plans a significant expansion of its Irving operations, creating 1,300 new jobs and investing $11 million over the next five years. The company will receive a $2.6 million grant from the Texas Enterprise Fund and up to $2.8 million from the city of Irving, contingent on job creation milestones. This expansion will make Allstate the second-largest employer in Irving.

title: Robots in the Permian? Climate concerns drive innovation
summary: Oil supermajors like Chevron and Exxon Mobil are heavily investing in the Permian Basin, using advanced automation, cloud computing, and AI to maximize oil extraction. This strategy is seen as a hedge against future climate change regulations and potential drops in oil demand, allowing for quick returns and flexibility. However, environmentalists criticize the focus on fossil fuels, and some experts question the feasibility of the desired automation and the long-term sustainability of shale production.

title: Exxon Mobil makes new oil discovery offshore Guyana
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced a new oil discovery offshore Guyana in the Turbot area of the Stabroek Block, bringing the total estimated oil-equivalent barrels to over 5.5 billion. This marks the thirteenth discovery in the block, considered one of the largest in the world over the last decade, with partners Hess Corp and China National Offshore Oil Corporation.

title: Chevron buying Anadarko, will likely take over operations of Roraima Block
summary: Chevron Corp. announced a $33-billion acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum Corp., a deal that will significantly expand Chevron's presence in U.S. shale oil and African liquefied natural gas, positioning it among the top global energy companies. This acquisition means Chevron will likely take over Anadarko's operations on the Roraima Block offshore Guyana, where Anadarko's exploration was previously halted by a Venezuelan Navy interception. The deal is expected to create a formidable competitor to ExxonMobil and Royal Dutch Shell, with Chevron planning to divest $15 billion to $20 billion in assets to reduce debt and return cash to investors.

title: Chevron Leaps to `Ultramajor' Oil Status With Anadarko Deal
summary: Chevron Corp. has agreed to acquire Anadarko Petroleum Corp. in a $33 billion cash-stock deal, significantly expanding its U.S. shale oil and African liquefied natural gas assets. This acquisition propels Chevron into the top tier of global energy companies, putting it on par with the production levels of Exxon Mobil Corp. and Royal Dutch Shell Plc. The combined entity's cash flow in the prior year would have surpassed Exxon's.

title: Chevron vaults into new league by buying Anadarko for $33 billion
summary: Chevron announced a $33 billion cash-and-stock deal to acquire Anadarko Petroleum, significantly boosting its position in the Permian Basin, Gulf of Mexico, and LNG business in Mozambique. This acquisition transforms Chevron from the fourth largest producer among major drillers to the second, creating what analysts are calling an "UltraMajor." The deal is expected to close in the second half of the year, subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals, and includes plans for increased stock buybacks and asset divestitures.

title: Chevron vaults into new league with $33B acquisition of Anadarko, one of Colorado's largest oil and gas operators
summary: Chevron announced its acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum for $33 billion in a cash-and-stock deal, significantly expanding its operations in deepwater exploration and particularly in the Permian Basin and Delaware Basin. This move vaults Chevron from the fourth to the second-largest producer among major drillers, making it an "UltraMajor" and enhancing its LNG business and presence in Colorado. The deal, which includes a bump in stock buybacks and asset divestitures, is pending shareholder and regulatory approval and reflects a strategic move amidst volatile oil prices.

title: Chevron Buys Anadarko
summary: Chevron Corp. has agreed to acquire Anadarko Petroleum Corp. for $33 billion, a move that significantly boosts Chevron's footprint in Permian shale oil and liquefied natural gas. The deal, valued at $50 billion including debt, is expected to enhance free cash flow and earnings per share for Chevron within a year of closing, and generate $1 billion in cost synergies.

title: Chevron, Anadarko Beyond 'Just a Shale Deal,' as Global Options Expand
summary: Chevron announced a $33 billion merger with Anadarko Petroleum Corp., creating the No. 1 U.S. producer with expanded global natural gas and oil opportunities. The deal, valued at $50 billion including debt, significantly strengthens Chevron's position in the Permian Basin, deepwater Gulf of Mexico, and LNG export business while aiming for $2 billion in annual synergies. Analysts view this as a strategic move beyond just shale, propelling Chevron into the top echelon of global oil and gas producers.

title: Brownsville: Three LNG Facility Projects on Track to Commence Exports in 2023-2024
summary: Three major LNG facility projects in Brownsville, including Rio Grande LNG, Texas LNG, and Annova LNG, are moving forward to begin exports in 2023-2024. These projects, located at the Port of Brownsville, involve significant investment, job creation, and environmental considerations. Regulatory approvals are progressing, with Final Investment Decisions and construction anticipated in the near future.

title: Second Large Plastics Manufacturer — Chevron Phillips Chemical — Agrees to Report on Plastic Pollution Pellet Spills
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical Co. has agreed to publically report on spills of pre-production plastic pellets, known as nurdles, following engagement with the Plastic Pollution Coalition member As You Sow. This agreement comes after similar action by ExxonMobil and mandates reporting on pellet loss, recovery, best practices, and supply chain engagement, with third-party auditing to verify data. The move aims to increase transparency regarding plastic pellet pollution, which is a significant source of ocean microplastic and harmful to marine life.

title: Celanese names Lori Ryerkerk as new CEO
summary: Celanese Corp. announced that Lori Ryerkerk will succeed Mark Rohr as CEO, effective May 1, 2019. Rohr will transition to Executive Chairman, focusing on shareholder value and the company's 2020 growth strategy, while Ryerkerk brings 35 years of experience in petrochemicals and refining, including leadership roles at Royal Dutch Shell and ExxonMobil. Both expressed excitement about the transition and the company's future growth and performance.

title: Exxon hires ex-BP crude oil trader in Singapore
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp has hired former BP crude oil trader Ruddin Dhilawala to enhance its trading capabilities in Singapore. This marks the company's second external hire for its Singapore crude oil trading desk since July, as part of Exxon's broader strategy to expand into energy trading by building an experienced global team and strengthening risk-management systems to boost profits.

title: BP already hit its methane targets. Or did it?
summary: BP announced it met its ambitious methane emissions target of 0.2 percent of total production by the end of 2018, just a year after setting it. This rapid achievement raises questions among environmental groups about the methodologies used and the transparency of the data, as they advocate for clearer demonstration and validation of such claims in the industry. The company's actions are set against a backdrop of increasing scrutiny on natural gas's climate impact and ongoing efforts to roll back federal methane regulations.

title: Andrew Clyde’s Salary Hits $5.94M at Murphy USA
summary: Murphy USA CEO Andrew Clyde earned $5.94 million in total compensation in 2018, an increase from the previous year. Other top executives, including Mindy K. West and John A. Moore, also received significant compensation, as did members of the company's board of directors. The details were disclosed in a proxy statement filed with the SEC, ahead of the company's annual stockholders meeting where re-election of some board members and a non-binding vote on executive compensation are on the agenda.

title: ExxonMobil weighs operating in Israel, looking for off-shore oil and gas blocks
summary: ExxonMobil is considering operating in Israel, potentially becoming the first major oil company to do so. Executives from Exxon reportedly met with Israeli Energy Minister Yuval Steinitz to discuss bidding in an upcoming auction for offshore oil and gas exploration rights. The firm has already secured a $50,000 data deal from Israel's energy ministry ahead of the June auction.

title: Aspen Oil Sands Project, Alberta- Solvent-assisted SAGD technology
summary: The Aspen Oil Sands Project in Alberta is an Imperial Oil-developed steam-assisted gravity drainage (SAGD) oil sands project employing solvent-assisted SAGD technology to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and water usage. The C$2.6bn phase one development, expected to start production in 2022, will produce 75,000 barrels of bitumen per day, with plans for a phase two expansion to 150,000 bpd. Key contractors include Babcock & Wilcox Enterprises and Acden Lakeshore Contracting.

title: Baker Hughes eyes LNG market for growth in 2019
summary: Baker Hughes is targeting the liquefied natural gas (LNG) market as a significant area for growth in 2019, securing high-profile contracts for turbines and equipment for new export terminals globally. The company's Turbomachinery & Process Solutions Division, which contributed over a fourth of its 2018 revenue, is focused on providing technology that enables efficient and lower-emission LNG production. Recent projects in Siberia, British Columbia, and Texas highlight the momentum in the LNG industry, with Baker Hughes anticipating substantial revenue from these ventures.

title: Crude by rail volumes fall as Calgary-based Imperial Oil cuts Alberta shipments
summary: Crude-by-rail shipments from Western Canada significantly dropped in February, reaching their lowest level since May of the previous year. This decline was largely attributed to Imperial Oil Ltd.'s decision to cut its rail shipments to near zero in response to the Alberta government's crude production curtailment program, which narrowed price differentials between Alberta and U.S. crude, making rail transport less economical. Imperial Oil had moved approximately 168,000 barrels per day by rail in December, nearly half of Canada's total crude-by-rail exports at that time.

title: Citgo, Valero try to return Venezuelan oil following sanctions
summary: Top U.S. buyers of Venezuelan oil, including Citgo and Valero, are attempting to return millions of barrels of crude due to U.S. sanctions imposed on Venezuela and its state-run oil company, PDVSA. Over 6 million barrels of Venezuelan crude are in limbo, as U.S. firms cannot pay PDVSA, and the Guaido administration lacks bank accounts to receive funds. This situation has led to stranded tankers, accumulating demurrage fees, and a scramble by PDVSA to avoid further export shortfalls amid declining oil shipments.

title: Venezuela must pay Conoco over $8 billion - World Bank
summary: The World Bank ruled that Venezuela must pay ConocoPhillips over $8 billion as compensation for the 2007 expropriation of its oil assets by Hugo Chavez's government. This makes ConocoPhillips the largest beneficiary in claims stemming from nationalizations in Venezuela, although the company may face challenges in collecting the payment given Venezuela's history with arbitration cases and its current economic crisis.

title: Larry Prince Obituary - Sandy Springs, GA
summary: Larry L. Prince, born October 4, 1938, passed away peacefully on March 5, 2019, in Atlanta. He had a distinguished nearly 47-year career at Genuine Parts Company, including 15 years as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, and served on numerous corporate and community boards. He is survived by his wife Sandra, son Larry L. Prince, Jr., sister Susie P. Haines, and nephew Tyrone Shelton.

title: SASREF partners with Aon to create Leadership Development Program (QAED) to nurture Saudi talent
summary: SASREF, a joint venture of Saudi Aramco and Shell International, has collaborated with Aon to launch a specialized Leadership Development Program (QAED). This initiative aims to enhance the skills and competencies of over 90 SASREF professionals to support strategic business growth and align with Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 goal of nurturing Saudi talent. The program utilized Aon's assessment tools and executive coaching to develop leaders for long-term organizational impact.

title: CrossAmerica Partners Closes Out 2018 With Flurry of Activity
summary: CrossAmerica Partners LP finalized plans for 192 convenience stores acquired from Circle K's parent company, Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc., making significant progress on the dealerization process. The company also secured a new supply contract for former Jet-Pep sites and achieved $9.5 million in cost savings through synergies with Couche-Tard. CrossAmerica plans to continue growth initiatives in 2019 without requiring additional capital, focusing on fuel strategic reviews, rebranding efforts, and evaluating third-party acquisitions.

title: Is LNG the New Oil?
summary: The global LNG market is rapidly growing, impacting international relations and geopolitical strategies due to its role in energy transformation and security. The U.S. has emerged as a significant player, influencing global LNG trade dynamics with its market-based approach and flexible contracts, leading to intense competition and shifting energy policies worldwide. This transformation has positioned LNG in international political discourse, drawing parallels to how oil has historically influenced global affairs.

title: Exxon's Cyprus gas discovery adds another giant to East Med collection
summary: ExxonMobil has made a significant gas discovery, Glaucus-1, offshore Cyprus, estimated at 5 to 8 trillion cubic feet, adding to the East Mediterranean's growing gas resources. While this solidifies the region's position as an exploration hotspot, infrastructure bottlenecks, geopolitical disputes with Turkey, and the lack of sufficient local markets complicate the commercialization and export plans for this and other regional finds. Exxon may need to collaborate with other developers like Eni and Total to support a greenfield LNG development for export.

title: Exxon Resumes Seismic Survey in Guyana
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp has resumed seismic exploration for oil and gas off the coast of Guyana after a December incident with the Venezuelan navy. Guyana says vessels have traveled unimpeded since the incident and is promoting its oil and gas opportunities, while Exxon explores the southeast portion of the Stabroek block. The restart of operations comes amid an ongoing territorial dispute with Venezuela and discussions around a potential environmental permit for Exxon's Liza oil field development and future contracts with the Guyanese government.

title: Activist-shareholders-push-TransDigm-on-greenhouse-gas
summary: Activist shareholders, including representatives of the New York City comptroller and five city retirement systems, are pressuring Cleveland-based aerospace component maker TransDigm Group Inc. to adopt a policy to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions in line with the Paris Agreement. While TransDigm's board is asking shareholders to vote against the proposal, arguing their decentralized business model makes a top-down approach impractical, experts note a growing trend of investors pushing for more specific environmental, social, and governance (ESG) initiatives. Companies in energy and transportation are particularly targeted, and law firms advise proactive goal-setting to avoid shareholder-driven policies.

title: San Patricio County approves tax incentives for Steel Dynamics mill
summary: San Patricio County officials have approved a 10-year tax abatement agreement to attract a proposed $1.8 billion Steel Dynamics flat roll steel mill. The incentives include 100% tax abatement for the first three years, dropping to 70% for years 4-10, contingent on the company meeting employment benchmarks such as creating 500 full-time jobs with health benefits. Although Steel Dynamics has not yet made a final decision on the mill's location, local leaders are actively competing to secure the project for the county.

title: Canada operations
summary: ExxonMobil, through its Canadian affiliates Imperial Oil Limited and ExxonMobil Canada (EMC), conducts integrated oil and gas activities across Canada. Imperial Oil is Canada’s largest petroleum refiner and a major producer of crude oil, natural gas, and petrochemicals, while EMC focuses on offshore oil and gas projects in Atlantic Canada and holds petroleum assets in Western and Northern Canada. The company emphasizes its commitment to operational excellence, advanced technology, innovation, and career development for its employees in Canada.

title: The refining top 40: Marathon moves up
summary: The merger of Marathon and Andeavor has created a new number-one independent refiner in the US, Marathon Petroleum, with over three million barrels per day of refining capacity. This makes Marathon the first North American independent refiner to join the global top 5, displacing Rosneft and pushing Valero down in rankings. The article categorizes global refiners and predicts continued growth for global NOCs, a shrinking downstream portfolio for global majors, and a potential slowdown for regional independents.

title: Texas Shale Forces Big Oil Cost Revolution, Chevron CEO Says
summary: Chevron CEO Mike Wirth states that the low break-even costs in the Permian Basin are forcing Chevron, and the oil industry at large, to become significantly more efficient across all operations. He emphasizes a strategy of continuous cost discipline and preparing for lower energy prices, rather than betting on high prices. This approach allows Chevron to focus investment on high-return areas like the Permian, even as other projects are abandoned.

title: Sempra Energy begins startup process for Cameron LNG
summary: Sempra Energy has begun the startup process for its Cameron LNG project in Hackberry, Louisiana, marking a significant step in bringing the Gulf Coast's third liquefied natural gas complex into operation. Over 8,000 workers are involved in the effort to activate the first of three production units, with the goal of shipping the first cargo within weeks or months. This venture is a collaboration between Sempra and companies from Japan and France, aiming to meet growing global demand for LNG.

title: Exxon Reorganizing Exploration Units
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced a major reorganization of its global exploration businesses to counter years of weak oil and gas output. The restructuring will consolidate seven companies into three new entities, aiming to double profits by 2025 and better integrate upstream, downstream, and chemical segments. This move comes as CEO Darren Woods seeks to reset the company's trajectory after costly misfires under his predecessor.

title: Exxon's Darren Woods is about to do something its CEO hasn't done in 15 years
summary: ExxonMobil CEO Darren Woods is set to speak on an earnings conference call, breaking a 15-year company tradition previously held by his predecessor, Rex Tillerson. This change reflects increased pressure on Exxon after a significant stock drop and underperformance relative to peers. Woods will address fourth-quarter results, with analysts keenly watching for improvements in production, profit, refining performance, Permian basin output, and capital expenditure plans.

title: Enterprise Products Partners closes 2018 with $4.1 billion profit amid record shipments
summary: Enterprise Products Partners closed 2018 with a $4.2 billion profit, driven by record shipments of crude oil, natural gas, and natural gas liquids. The company exceeded analyst expectations for earnings per share in Q4 but missed revenue estimates. CEO Jim Teague highlighted 23 new operational and financial records set in 2018 due to increased volumes and higher marketing margins.

title: It's official: Chevron to buy Petrobras refinery
summary: Chevron officially announced its acquisition of Petrobras' refinery in Pasadena, marking it as Chevron's sole refinery in Texas. This move follows previous reports and coincides with expansion efforts in Chevron's Permian operations. The acquisition is a significant development for Chevron's presence in the Houston area.

title: Inside Imperial Oil Limited’s 20-Acre Campus in Quarry Park
summary: Imperial Oil Limited relocated its headquarters from downtown Calgary to a 20-acre campus in Quarry Park, focusing on a community-centric corporate culture and enhanced staff interaction. The LEED Gold certified campus features five office buildings, a 750-foot "Pipeline" corridor, and amenities such as a cafeteria, wellness center, and historical displays. The design prioritizes flexibility and collaboration with wireless phones, portable laptops, and unassigned desks.

title: Ex-Halliburton chairman Dave Lesar to start new oil-services company
summary: Former Halliburton chairman Dave Lesar is launching a new oilfield services company with funding from private equity firm CSL Capital Management. Lesar, who retired from Halliburton at the end of 2018, confirmed that his new venture will not compete with his previous company, despite having a non-compete clause. This move follows his previous remarks about wanting to remain involved in the oilfield services sector.

title: State Of American Energy 2019
summary: The "State of American Energy 2019" report, "America’s Generation Energy," highlights the crucial role of natural gas and oil in driving U.S. economic health, global security, and individual prosperity. API President and CEO Mike Sommers emphasized how this "Generation Energy" is reshaping the global energy balance, fueling manufacturing, and leading environmental progress. The report also detailed polling results showing strong American support for natural gas and oil, and panel discussions addressed infrastructure needs and the Renewable Fuel Standard.

title: CES 2019: Why IBM CEO Ginni Rometty's Opening Address Delivers
summary: IBM CEO Ginni Rometty's CES 2019 keynote address effectively dissected the future of technology and business opportunities, highlighting deep data, Broad AI, and IBM's new Q System One. She emphasized the importance of ethics, transparency, and preparing society for the future through "new collar jobs" and apprenticeship programs. Rometty demonstrated IBM's commitment to inclusive growth and practical innovation in the tech space.

title: DowDuPont Is Splitting Into 3 Companies. Here’s Everything You Need to Know.
summary: DowDuPont is splitting into three independent companies: Dow, DuPont, and Corteva, each focusing on different chemical sectors. Dow will handle commodity chemicals, DuPont specialty chemicals, and Corteva agricultural products. The article explains the rationale behind the split, details what each new company will produce, and provides insights for investors regarding stock trading, dividends, and valuations of the individual entities post-split.

title: Causas de corrupción podrían impedir inversiones estadounidenses en empresas argentinas
summary: US corruption concerns may hinder American investments in Argentine companies, particularly those with executives implicated in ongoing judicial cases. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) has warned that loans to firms like Tecpetrol, Genneia, and TGS, totaling over $800 million, will be contingent on rigorous reviews of executives and companies facing corruption investigations. Specific cases highlighted include Paolo Rocca of Techint and Jorge Brito of Genneia, impacting projects in gas and renewable energy crucial for Argentina's infrastructure.

title: Exxon Mobil withdraws application for $25-billion LNG project in B.C.
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. has withdrawn its environmental assessment application for a $25-billion LNG export facility in northern British Columbia, which it had proposed in 2015. The WCC LNG project, a partnership with Imperial Oil, was to be located in Tuck Inlet near Prince Rupert. This withdrawal is a blow to the West Coast LNG industry, which has seen many proposals but only one firm commitment.

title: 5 things to know in Texas energy this week
summary: The first export of liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Texas has been shipped from Cheniere Energy Inc.'s Corpus Christi facility. This announcement, made on Dec. 11, marks a significant milestone for the state's energy sector. The article highlights this as a key event in Texas energy for the week of December 17, 2018.

title: Stock of the week: Chevron
summary: Chevron announced a significant increase in its capital expenditure budget for 2019, marking the first such increase in four years, with a focus on high-return, short-cycle projects, particularly in its upstream business. Despite past struggles during low oil prices, Chevron has a strong dividend policy and improved financial ratios, positioning it well among its peers. The company's stock is trading within a consolidation range, with potential for upside given anticipated oil market rebounds.

title: News Content Hub - Why Seacor went electric
summary: Seacor Marine Holdings Inc. is embracing battery-hybrid propulsion technology to gain a competitive edge in the market, converting 12 platform supply vessels (PSVs) to hybrid power. This move is driven by the potential for significant fuel savings, reduced emissions, and increased operational efficiency and reliability, which also appeals to charterers. Seacor believes this early investment positions them as a leader in the hybrid vessel market.

title: Worlds biggest oil traders bribed Petrobras staff: prosecutors
summary: Prosecutors allege that top oil trading firms Vitol, Trafigura, and Glencore paid over $30 million in bribes to employees of Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrobras, between 2011 and 2014. The scheme involved Petrobras staff offering lower prices for oil and storage in exchange for kickbacks, a part of the wider "Car Wash" corruption probe. This revelation surfaces as Petrobras attempts to rebuild its reputation and pursue privatization plans.

title: Exclusive: Exxon, Chevron seek to exit Azerbaijan's oil after 25 years
summary: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are looking to sell their stakes in Azerbaijan's largest oilfield, Azeri-Chirag-Gunashli (ACG), after 25 years of involvement. Exxon aims to raise up to $2 billion for its 6.8 percent stake, while Chevron is selling its 9.57 percent stake in ACG and 8.9 percent interest in the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline, as both companies refocus on domestic production and other major projects. This move marks the retreat of U.S. majors from a project once hoped to diversify Europe's energy supply from Russia.

title: Synthetic Polymer Wax Market | Global Market Analysis Report - 2035
summary: The synthetic polymer wax market is projected to grow from USD 1.7 billion in 2025 to USD 2.9 billion by 2035, exhibiting a CAGR of 5.5%. Polyethylene wax is expected to dominate product types, and the lubricating segment will lead applications. This growth is driven by versatile applications across plastics, coatings, adhesives, and lubricants, with increasing demand for high-performance waxes.

title: Vessel Arrives At Cheniere's Corpus Christi LNG Plant
summary: A liquefied natural gas (LNG) vessel, the Maria Energy, arrived at Cheniere Energy Inc's Corpus Christi LNG export facility, marking the second vessel visit since production began in November. This arrival suggests the facility is actively producing LNG and could be its first cargo pickup, following the Sabine Pass terminal which has already delivered around 500 cargoes. The article details Cheniere's expansion plans with new liquefaction trains at both Corpus Christi and Sabine Pass terminals set to become operational in the coming years, contributing to the significant growth of U.S. LNG exports.

title: McKesson, nation's sixth largest company, is moving corporate HQ from California to Irving
summary: McKesson, the nation's sixth largest company by revenue and largest pharmaceutical distributor, is relocating its corporate headquarters from San Francisco to Irving, Texas in April. The move follows the establishment of a North Texas campus and aligns with a company-wide initiative to boost efficiency and save $300 million to $400 million annually. This relocation makes McKesson the second-largest company by revenue headquartered in North Texas and adds to the region's growing attraction for health care companies.

title: New DynaEnergetics manufacturin facility opens in Blum, Texas
summary: DynaEnergetics, a business of DMC Global Inc., has opened a new 74,000 sq ft manufacturing, assembly, and administrative facility in Blum, Texas. This expansion significantly boosts the production capacity of its DynaStage™ well perforating system, which has sold over 500,000 units in two years. The new facility includes multiple assembly lines, CNC turning centers, and automated shaped-charge production lines to meet growing customer demand.

title: Energy, Mining Stocks Drag TSX Lower
summary: The Canadian stock market, represented by the S&P/TSX Composite Index, declined on Tuesday due to renewed worries about U.S.-China trade disputes and weak commodity prices. Energy and mining stocks were the primary laggards, while healthcare and consumer discretionary sectors also saw sharp declines. The article details the performance of various individual stocks within these sectors, as well as the broader market performance in North America, Europe, and Asia.

title: Borr Drilling secures jackup contract from Royal Gate Energy
summary: Borr Drilling has secured a new two-month contract from Royal Gate Energy for its Norve rig in Equatorial Guinea, starting May 2019. Additionally, Borr Drilling converted five Letters of Intent into firm contracts, deploying rigs with Exxon Nigeria, First E&P Nigeria, Spirit Energy UK, and Kris Energy, along with another 10-month contract for Norve from an undisclosed client. This follows Borr Drilling's activation of four newbuild jackup rigs in anticipation of new agreements.

title: Pioneer Natural Resources sells pressure pumping assets to ProPetro
summary: Pioneer Natural Resources announced the sale of its pressure pumping business to ProPetro Holding Corp. for $400 million, comprised of cash and ProPetro stock. This deal establishes ProPetro as a strategic, long-term service provider to Pioneer for up to 10 years, expanding ProPetro's operations in the Permian Basin and allowing Pioneer to enhance capital efficiency. The transaction is expected to close in Q4 2018, subject to regulatory approval.

title: Halliburton CFO Leaves After 17 Months
summary: Chris Weber, Halliburton's CFO for 17 months, is leaving the company, with Lance Loeffler, VP of investor relations, named as his replacement. The change comes as Halliburton's shares have significantly declined, amid a tough environment for oil and gas stocks and infrastructure constraints affecting demand for its services. Loeffler, with his financial expertise and experience with the investment community, is expected to lead the company's financial strategy.

title: Chevron, Exxon Mobil weigh bids for Endeavor Energy
summary: Chevron Corp. and Exxon Mobil Corp. are reportedly considering first-round bids for the closely held oil producer Endeavor Energy Resources LP, which could be valued at approximately $15 billion including debt. ConocoPhillips and Royal Dutch Shell Plc may also participate in the auction, though Endeavor's founder prefers an initial public offering in 2019 to retain control. This potential sale highlights increased deal activity in the North American oil and gas market, particularly in the Permian Basin.

title: Dividends in Focus: The Dow 30
summary: This article analyzes the dividend performance of the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, highlighting those with attractive yields and long histories of consecutive dividend increases. It summarizes the Dow 30 using five charts focusing on dividend yield, consecutive increases, industry representation, best and worst payers, and total cash dividends paid in 2018. The article also provides detailed profiles of individual Dow components and their dividend growth history.

title: Meet the Guy Making T. Boone Pickens Richer
summary: Toby Loftin, founder of BP Capital Fund Advisors and TwinLine mutual funds, began managing T. Boone Pickens' family wealth in 2010. He launched BOON, an energy exchange-traded fund (ETF), in February 2018, which tracks the NYSE Pickens Oil Response Index. The article highlights Loftin's innovative approach to energy investing, particularly his ETF's design to adapt to changing energy markets and include end-users.

title: Imperial Oil going ahead with construction of $2.6B Aspen oilsands project
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. is moving forward with the construction of its $2.6-billion Aspen oilsands project in northern Alberta, less than a week after receiving provincial approval. The project is expected to add 75,000 barrels per day of bitumen production by 2022 and utilizes innovative solvent-assisted technology to reduce costs and environmental impact. This decision comes despite current discounts on Western Canadian Select bitumen, with Imperial betting on future pipeline solutions to alleviate export bottlenecks.

title: Chevron quarterly profit doubles as U.S. oil production jumps
summary: Chevron's quarterly profit doubled due to record oil and gas production and higher crude oil prices, despite one-time expenses. The company's net income significantly exceeded analysts' estimates, reflecting strong financial results for major oil companies in the third quarter. Shares saw a premarket rise but had declined in the preceding month.

title: Hess, Exxon Mobil Prep For More exploration offshore Guyana
summary: Hess Corp., Exxon Mobil, and CNOOC Nexen Petroleum are advancing their offshore Guyana exploration and development efforts. A second exploration vessel has arrived to accelerate activities, with an expectation of over 750,000 barrels of oil per day by 2025. Development phases for Liza and Payara fields are on track, with Hess calling its Guyana position "truly world class."

title: YPF plans US$ 4bn annual investment in oil and gas production
summary: Argentina's state-controlled oil company, YPF, plans to invest between US$4 and US$5 billion annually through 2022 to significantly boost oil and gas production, particularly in the Vaca Muerta formation. The company aims to raise production by 5-7% per year, with a focus on shale oil and gas, and plans to double its dividends over the next three years while reducing debt and increasing electricity generation capacity.

title: Chevron to pay $150 million in settlement with EPA for violating Clean Air Act
summary: Chevron will pay $150 million and incur an additional $2.95 million in civil penalties as part of a national settlement with the EPA, U.S. Department of Justice, and Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality. The settlement addresses repeated violations of the Clean Air Act, including a 2012 fire at its Richmond refinery that led to 15,000 residents seeking medical attention and other incidents in 2013 at its El Segundo and Pascagoula refineries. This settlement, totaling over $160 million, is the largest in EPA history for enforcing the Clean Air Act's risk management plan rule.

title: Another Plains All American Houston executive retires
summary: John vonBerg, an executive at Plains All American, has retired, following the former CEO Greg Armstrong. VonBerg joined the company in 2002. Plains All American is a Houston-based midstream energy infrastructure company.

title: Exxon is lobbying for a carbon tax. There is, obviously, a catch.
summary: ExxonMobil announced it would spend $1 million lobbying for a US carbon tax, a move that comes with a significant caveat: the company wants immunity from all future climate change lawsuits. This proposal is seen by some as a strategic move to establish climate policy on its own terms and prevent more stringent regulations, rather than a genuine concern for curbing emissions. The article discusses why Exxon might support a carbon tax, the limitations of their proposed $40 per ton price, and the controversy surrounding their demand for legal immunity from climate change litigation.

title: Kosmos Energy announces results of Pontoenoe-1 well
summary: Kosmos Energy's Pontoenoe-1 well offshore Suriname did not discover commercial hydrocarbons despite encountering high-quality reservoirs, as the primary objective proved water-bearing due to a lack of trap. The company believes there is still significant potential in Block 42, given evidence of a mature source and quality Cretaceous reservoir, and plans to test the next prospect in 2020. Kosmos, Hess, and Chevron are partners in exploring Block 42.

title: Chevron Quits Norway
summary: Chevron Corp. is selling its last remaining oil exploration license in Norway, signaling a full retreat from the North Sea basin to pursue higher returns elsewhere. This move follows similar divestments in the U.K. and Denmark, making Chevron the first oil major to completely exit Norway. The company's departure comes after its last major prospect in the region, Korpfjell, proved to be uncommercial.

title: The opportunities and threats for the Three Seas Initiative
summary: The Three Seas Initiative, led by Poland, aims to foster regional integration among 12 Central and Eastern European EU member states to improve energy, transportation, and digitalization infrastructure. This effort seeks to overcome historical failures in regional cooperation and reduce vulnerabilities, particularly concerning Russian influence, by developing north-south infrastructure links. While facing challenges in funding and skepticism from some EU members, the initiative has gained support from the US and is working to secure EU backing and investment for numerous proposed projects.

title: A Gulf Sale Would Be a Good Step for Exxon
summary: Exxon Mobil is reportedly exploring a sale of its Gulf of Mexico assets, a move seen as a positive step for the company. This action, though concerning a small fraction of its production, indicates progress in tightening its operations. Such a sale would help Exxon catch up to rivals who have been more effective in improving their return on capital.

title: Exclusive: Exxon explores sale of U.S. Gulf of Mexico assets - sources
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is considering the sale of many of its U.S. Gulf of Mexico assets as it focuses on other promising areas like Guyana, Brazil, and the Permian basin. The company has contacted a few parties to gauge interest, and any sale of assets, which currently produce about 50,000 barrels per day, would likely occur next year. This move comes as Exxon reviews its portfolio in response to higher oil prices and a shift in industry focus.

title: Exxon explores selling U.S. Gulf of Mexico assets – sources
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp (XOM.N) is considering selling many of its U.S. Gulf of Mexico assets as the company focuses on more promising oil-rich areas like Guyana, Brazil, and the Permian basin. The assets currently produce about 50,000 barrels per day of oil and include stakes in the Julia oil field, Hadrian South natural gas field, Heidelberg field, and Lucius oil and gas field. Qatar, which has existing partnerships with Exxon, is identified as a potential buyer for these assets.

title: Deep rubber ties push ExxonMobil forward
summary: ExxonMobil Chemical Co. highlights its long-standing commitment and leadership in key elastomer markets, including butyl rubber, EPDM, and thermoplastic vulcanizates. The company emphasizes its focus on supply security, product innovation, and strategic investments to meet growing demands in the automotive and tire industries, driven by global trends and sustainability efforts. ExxonMobil also discusses its efforts to adapt to evolving automotive technologies while continuing to optimize traditional businesses.

title: Fracking made the U.S. a major oil producer, but not energy independent
summary: Journalist Bethany McLean discusses her book "Saudi America" which explores the nuanced success of fracking, arguing that while it made the U.S. a major oil producer, it didn't lead to energy independence. She highlights that capital, rather than chemicals, is the key ingredient in fracking and that the industry's financial fragility makes the concept of energy independence illusory due to global oil pricing.

title: Arvin CA acts to protect residents from oil and gas
summary: The City of Arvin, CA, passed a setback ordinance on July 17, 2018, restricting new oil and gas wells within 300 feet of residential and commercial areas, marking the first such policy in an oil-producing California county. This achievement was supported by Earthworks' documentation of methane and VOC pollution at existing well sites using optical gas imaging. The article highlights the ongoing struggle against the oil and gas industry's influence in California and the need for further action to address existing wells and emissions.

title: Who is Gulf Coast Growth Ventures? And why should you know them?
summary: This article introduces Gulf Coast Growth Ventures, the local face of ExxonMobil's proposed $10 billion plastics manufacturing plant in San Patricio County, Texas. The project, which promises significant economic benefits and job creation, is currently on hold awaiting air permits from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality. The plant would produce monoethylene glycol and polyethylene, essential materials for various products, but faces opposition from some residents and environmental groups over concerns about pollution and property values.

title: Transocean to buy Ocean Rig in $2.7 billion deal
summary: Transocean Ltd announced its acquisition of Ocean Rig UDW Inc in a $2.7 billion cash-and-stock deal, marking its second major acquisition this year. This move signals renewed optimism in the offshore drilling sector following a recovery in global oil prices. The deal is expected to provide Transocean with nine ultra-deepwater drillships and two semisubmersibles, alongside projected annual cost savings.

title: Imperial Oil vows to employ oilsands technology to cut GHG intensity by 10%
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. announced a pledge to reduce its oilsands greenhouse gas emissions per barrel by 10 percent over the next five years. This reduction will be achieved through the implementation of new technologies at its Cold Lake oilsands wells, reaching full capacity at its Kearl oilsands mining project, and other efficiencies. The company expects further improvements if its proposed Aspen oilsands project receives regulatory approval.

title: Venezuela agrees to pay $2 billion over seizure of oil projects
summary: Venezuela's state oil company, PDVSA, has agreed to pay ConocoPhillips $2 billion as a settlement for the seizure of its oil projects more than a decade ago. The agreement, which allows PDVSA to pay over nearly five years, came after ConocoPhillips seized Venezuelan oil assets, impacting the country's exports. This settlement helps resolve one legal dispute, though ConocoPhillips is pursuing another arbitration case that could lead to a larger award.

title: ConocoPhillips and Venezuela's PDVSA reach $2 billion settlement
summary: ConocoPhillips and Venezuela's state-run oil company PDVSA have reached a $2 billion settlement agreement, resolving a long-standing dispute over the nationalization of Conoco's assets. This agreement will result in Conoco suspending legal enforcement and PDVSA making regular payments, potentially restoring a portion of Venezuela's lost oil exports by resuming shipping from Caribbean facilities. The settlement involves an initial payment of approximately $500 million within 90 days, with the remainder paid quarterly over 4.5 years.

title: Diamondback to buy Energen in $9.2 billion deal to boost its Permian presence
summary: Diamondback Energy announced an all-stock deal to acquire shale rival Energen for $9.2 billion, significantly expanding its footprint in the Permian Basin. This marks Diamondback's second acquisition in the Permian in a week, following a $1.2 billion deal for Ajax Resources. The acquisition values Energen's properties at approximately $65,000 per acre, reflecting the growing drive for scale and efficiency among West Texas shale producers.

title: Chesapeake Energy, Other Oil Stocks Fall as Libyan Production Returns
summary: Chesapeake Energy (CHK) and other oil stocks experienced a decline after Libyan oil production resumed, causing crude oil prices to fall. Despite bearish market sentiment driven by trade tensions and a stronger dollar, some analysts remain bullish on crude oil prospects for the rest of the year. Technical indicators suggest Chesapeake Energy's stock could face further downside, with traders advised to monitor key support and resistance levels.

title: Syncrude partner deals must ‘make sense’ for all: Imperial Oil CEO
summary: Imperial Oil CEO Rich Kruger states that commercial deals to improve Syncrude's reliability must be beneficial for all partners involved, responding to Suncor CEO Steve Williams' concerns about a lack of urgency. Imperial Oil, which owns 25% of Syncrude, is focused on improving efficiency and is open to commercial arrangements that enhance value for the project. The Syncrude upgrader is expected to return to full operation in September after a June power outage.

title: BP pays $10.5 billion for BHP shale assets to beef up U.S. business
summary: BP has agreed to acquire U.S. shale oil and gas assets from BHP Billiton for $10.5 billion, marking its largest deal in nearly two decades and significantly expanding its U.S. onshore footprint. This acquisition is seen as a transformational step for BP, allowing the company to increase its quarterly dividend and announce a $6 billion share buyback. The sale concludes BHP's challenging seven-year venture into shale, with proceeds to be returned to shareholders.

title: BP pays $10.5 billion for BHP shale assets to beef up US business
summary: BP has acquired U.S. shale oil and gas assets from BHP Billiton for $10.5 billion, marking its largest deal in nearly two decades and a significant expansion of its onshore operations in the U.S. This acquisition is seen as a transformational step for BP following the Deepwater Horizon disaster, enabling the company to increase its U.S. onshore oil and gas resources by 57% and boost earnings and cash flow per share. BHP plans to return the sale proceeds to shareholders, ending its seven-year investment in the shale business which had faced pressure from investors.

title: Exxon Mobil's ethane cracker in Baytown up and running
summary: Exxon Mobil's ethane cracker in Baytown, Texas, along with associated high-performance polyethylene lines in Mont Belvieu, has begun operations. This project represents Exxon's largest chemical investment within the United States to date. The article highlights several related Exxon Mobil projects, indicating ongoing significant investments in the Gulf Coast region.

title: The U.S. natural gas industry is leaking way more methane than previously thought
summary: A new study, synthesizing five years of research, suggests that methane emissions from U.S. oil and gas operations are significantly higher than current EPA estimates, with a leak rate of 2.3 percent compared to the EPA's 1.4 percent. This 60 percent difference has profound climate consequences given methane's potency as a greenhouse gas. The article highlights that while natural gas has climate benefits over coal, these benefits are reduced by leakage and could be far greater with lower leak rates.

title: A Threat to Shale’s Dominance Emerges 200 Miles off the Gulf Coast
summary: A quiet revolution is occurring in offshore drilling, potentially challenging shale's dominance. Despite the high costs and technical challenges associated with deep-water oil production, companies like Chevron Corp., Royal Dutch Shell Plc, and BP Plc have made their offshore operations leaner and safer after navigating significant industry setbacks. This newfound efficiency could signal a resurgence for deep-water drilling.

title: Honeywell sues Exxon Mobil over Onondaga Lake pollution, cleanup costs
summary: Honeywell has filed a federal lawsuit against Exxon Mobil Corp. and Buckeye Pipeline Co. to recoup some of the estimated $500 million it is spending on the cleanup of Onondaga Lake. Honeywell claims that Exxon Mobil and Buckeye are responsible for petroleum product leaks from the former Oil City area into the lake, contributing to the contamination. The lawsuit seeks an "equitable share" of cleanup costs, arguing that the companies have denied or unreasonably minimized their liability despite years of negotiations.

title: Syncrude Canada crude production offline through July -spokesman
summary: Syncrude Canada's oil sands facility, capable of producing up to 360,000 barrels per day, is offline at least through July following a power outage. This shutdown is expected to open up pipeline capacity for other Western Canada oil producers, potentially reducing the discount on Canadian heavy crude. Syncrude, a joint venture primarily owned by Suncor Energy Inc and Imperial Oil Ltd, is investigating the cause of the power transformer trip.

title: Empire Petroleum Picks Up Willoughby's Wholesale Distribution Business
summary: Empire Petroleum Partners LLC acquired the wholesale distribution business of Willoughby Inc., expanding Empire's presence in Tennessee, Mississippi, and Arkansas. This acquisition adds over 120 new dealer customers and strengthens Empire's relationships with major fuel brands. David Willoughby, former owner, will now focus on the growth of his transportation and commercial business.

title: U.S. drilling slows as pipelines fill to capacity
summary: U.S. drilling in the Permian Basin is slowing down due to pipeline capacity constraints, leading to a record number of unfinished wells. This bottleneck is forcing drillers to postpone fracking or even shut down existing wells, impacting smaller operators especially. Major players like Exxon Mobil are investing in new pipeline infrastructure to address the problem, as the situation is expected to worsen by late 2018 and early 2019.

title: Greenpeace Report: Too Far Too Often
summary: This Greenpeace report, "Too Far Too Often," details unethical and inappropriate tactics employed by Energy Transfer Partners (ETP) against opponents of the Dakota Access Pipeline (DAPL) and other projects. It highlights ETP's violations of Indigenous sovereignty, use of intimidation and lawsuits (including SLAPP suits), involvement in anti-protest legislation, reliance on aggressive private security firms like TigerSwan, and aggressive seizure of private property. The report also documents ETP's extensive history of hazardous liquid spills, environmental violations, and workplace safety issues, urging financial institutions to end relationships with the company due to these unacceptable practices.

title: Pioneers in petroleum: Meet Chevron's two new female VPs
summary: Chevron has appointed Kim McHugh and Liz Schwarze as its newest Vice Presidents, making them the first women to hold their respective roles within the company. Both executives are based in downtown Houston. This move highlights a changing landscape in the energy industry regarding female leadership.

title: Exxon Mobil reportedly growing energy trading segment
summary: Exxon Mobil is reportedly expanding its energy trading segment, with most new trading activities expected to occur at its Springwoods Village campus north of Houston. Reuters reports that Exxon's Houston trading floor has increased to employ as many as 70 workers as part of this growth. This expansion signifies Exxon's move to bolster its energy trading capabilities.

title: Chevron promotes first females to exploration, drilling and completions VP roles
summary: Chevron Corp. has promoted Liz Schwarze and Kim McHugh to Vice President roles in exploration, and drilling and completions, respectively. These promotions mark the first time females have held these positions at Chevron. Both newly appointed Vice Presidents will be based in Chevron's downtown Houston office.

title: The Johan Sverdrup drilling platform installed
summary: Equinor successfully installed the 22,000-tonne topside for the Johan Sverdrup drilling platform using the Pioneering Spirit, marking the first time this single-lift technology was used for new platform installation. This innovation allowed for significant savings in time and costs, and reduced health, environment, and safety risks. The drilling platform is expected to become operational in autumn 2018, with the entire first phase of the Johan Sverdrup field projected to start production in late 2019.

title: ExxonMobil estimates permitting, construction time as Taft, Ingleside envision boom
summary: ExxonMobil's Gulf Coast Growth Ventures project, a $10 billion ethylene cracker plant, is undergoing a lengthy permitting process with the TCEQ, with construction potentially beginning in 2019. Local towns like Taft and Ingleside anticipate significant economic benefits from the project, including job creation and an improved tax base, while also facing environmental concerns from some resident groups. Officials from both the company and local governments express confidence in the project's safety and economic impact, despite ongoing opposition and regulatory reviews.

title: Cheniere Energy formally approves third LNG unit at South Texas plant
summary: Cheniere Energy Inc. has formally approved the construction of a third liquefaction unit at its South Texas export terminal, marking the first new U.S. LNG project approved since 2015. This expansion reinforces Cheniere's leadership in the U.S. LNG market and is driven by significant global demand. The United States is projected to become the third-largest LNG exporter by 2020.

title: Oklahoma oil industry gains new focus
summary: The Oklahoma oil industry is shifting its focus from increasing production to improving financial health by repaying debt, generating free cash flow, and returning value to shareholders. Following a significant downturn, companies like Chesapeake, Continental Resources, and Devon Energy are prioritizing financial responsibility and drilling only the most profitable wells. This new strategy addresses Wall Street's demands and aims to stabilize stock prices in a volatile market.

title: Exxon and SABIC officially form JV for proposed $10B petrochem project
summary: Exxon Mobil and SABIC have officially formed a joint venture for their proposed $10 billion petrochemical project, Gulf Coast Growth Ventures. This move marks a significant milestone, allowing the companies to advance plans for the project, which includes an ethane cracker, a monoethylene glycol unit, and two polyethylene units. The project is expected to create 1.8 million tonnes of ethane.

title: Exxon or Chevron? This analyst says there’s one stock to pick
summary: Barclays analysts, led by Paul Cheng, recommend Chevron over Exxon Mobil Corp. despite both reporting mixed first-quarter results. The preference for Chevron stems from a "structural deterioration" in Exxon's project portfolio. They anticipate Chevron's first-quarter results will positively impact its shares.

title: Exxon or Chevron? This analyst says there’s one stock to pick
summary: Barclays analysts, led by Paul Cheng, recommend Chevron over Exxon Mobil Corp. despite both reporting mixed first-quarter results. The decision is based on a "structural deterioration" in Exxon's project portfolio. Chevron's first-quarter results are expected to positively impact its shares.

title: #BreakTheFrackingCycle International Actions Boost Movement Against Fracking & Rio Grande LNG
summary: A coalition of U.S. and European activists launched the #BreakTheFrackingCycle campaign to oppose the Rio Grande LNG export terminal and Rio Bravo Pipeline in South Texas. The campaign highlighted the entire "fracked gas cycle" from financing by Société Générale in France, extraction in the Eagle Ford Shale, transmission through Latinx communities, to potential import into Ireland. Actions took place in Texas, New York City, Ireland, France, and Germany, drawing international attention to the environmental and social impacts of the proposed projects.

title: Marathon Petroleum to buy Andeavor for more than $23B
summary: Marathon Petroleum is set to acquire Andeavor for over $23 billion. Andeavor CEO Greg Goff will join Marathon Petroleum Corp. as executive vice chairman following the proposed acquisition. Marathon Petroleum operates two large refineries in the Houston area.

title: Karl Jansen | National Managing Partner | Nottingham
summary: Karl Jansen is the National Managing Partner at Freeths, responsible for leadership, management, and strategy. With over 25 years as a corporate lawyer, he is recognized in Legal 500's Hall of Fame and Best Lawyers for Corporate Finance Law and Litigation. Jansen's notable work includes advising major transactions for companies like Travis Perkins, Tarmac, and Experian.

title: Exxon earnings could show benefits from rising oil prices
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. is expected to report first-quarter earnings, with Wall Street focusing on updates regarding the company's mega-projects. Despite crude-oil prices seeing two consecutive years of gains, Exxon's share performance has not reflected this trend. The upcoming earnings report on Friday provides an opportunity for Exxon to reverse this pattern.

title: Hess grabs new acreage next to Guyana’s Stabroek block
summary: Hess Corporation has expanded its footprint offshore Guyana by acquiring a 15 percent participating interest in the Kaieteur block, adjacent to the prolific ExxonMobil-operated Stabroek block. This acquisition significantly extends Hess's acreage in the Guyana-Suriname Basin, an area known for world-class oil discoveries. The company plans to conduct seismic data processing and evaluation for future drilling programs in the Kaieteur block, which lies in the same geological basin as Stabroek.

title: ConocoPhillips Awarded US$2bn for 2007 Oil Field Expropriation, Venezuela Claims Victory
summary: The International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) has ordered Venezuela's national oil company, PDVSA, to pay ConocoPhillips US$2.04 billion for the 2007 expropriation of its oil field assets. Venezuela claims victory despite the significant payout, stating the award is less than what was originally offered by Chavez and a small fraction of what ConocoPhillips sought. The ruling raises questions about enforcement given Venezuela's economic situation and PDVSA's declining oil production.

title: Chevron evacuates Venezuela executives following staff arrests
summary: U.S. oil major Chevron Corp has evacuated executives from Venezuela after two of its workers were imprisoned over a contract dispute with state-owned oil company PDVSA. The arrests are part of a broader government anti-corruption probe, creating difficult conditions for foreign oil firms operating in the country. Chevron, which has no plans to exit Venezuela, is facing escalating tensions and production declines in its joint ventures with PDVSA.

title: Brazilian company buys Shell downstream assets in Argentina
summary: Brazil's Raizen Combustiveis SA has agreed to acquire Royal Dutch Shell's downstream assets in Argentina for US$ 950 million. This acquisition includes 645 gas stations, a refinery in Buenos Aires, and various fuel terminals, giving Raízen a 20% market share in Argentina's fuel distribution. The move is part of Shell's broader strategy to divest US$30 billion by 2018, focusing on its upstream interests like the Vaca Muerta shale formation.

title: ¿Quiénes son los dueños de la energía en Argentina?
summary: This article examines the dominant players in Argentina's energy sector, highlighting the rise of local private capital groups like Pampa Energía and Bridas. It details their expansion in electricity and hydrocarbons following the country's economic changes in the early 2000s, which led to the departure of many foreign companies. The article also touches on the current favorable business climate under the Macri government, which has benefited these national energy giants.

title: News Update: Downstream
summary: This article provides an update on several downstream chemical industry projects. Westlake Chemical is expanding chlor-alkali, PVC, and VCM capacities across its facilities in Germany and Louisiana. ExxonMobil is commissioning its new ethane cracker in Baytown, Texas, while Lubrizol is expanding its global TPU production capabilities. Additionally, Total, Borealis, and NOVA Chemicals are forming a joint venture for petrochemicals on the U.S. Gulf Coast, including an ethane steam cracker and polyethylene units.

title: Imperial Oil, Exxon to sell natural-gas property in B.C.
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. and its partner Exxon Mobil Corp. are selling their Horn River shale-gas asset in British Columbia, marking another instance of a major producer divesting from Canada. This move follows Imperial's shelving of the project last year and aligns with a broader trend of large energy companies retreating from Canadian investments. The 239,000-acre property includes infrastructure and was once considered a key supply source for LNG exports.
